Pale, shivering, with rigid features and compressed lips, she looked an entirely altered being from the soft and timid creature she had been hitherto. She moved cautiously along the entry, paused one moment at her mistressâ€™ door, and raised her hands in mute appeal to Heaven, and then turned and glided into her own room. It was a quiet, neat apartment, on the same floor with her mistress. There was a pleasant sunny window, where she had often sat singing at her sewing; there a little case of books, and various little fancy articles, ranged by them, the gifts of Christmas holidays; there was her simple wardrobe in the closet and in the drawers:â€”here was, in short, her home; and, on the whole, a happy one it had been to her. But there, on the bed, lay her slumbering boy, his long curls falling negligently around his unconscious face, his rosy mouth half open, his little fat hands thrown out over the bedclothes, and a smile spread like a sunbeam over his whole face.
â€œPoor boy! poor fellow!â€ said Eliza; â€œthey have sold you! but your mother will save you yet!â€

No tear dropped over that pillow; in such straits as these, the heart has no tears to give,â€”it drops only blood, bleeding itself away in silence. She took a piece of paper and a pencil, and wrote, hastily,

â€œO, Missis! dear Missis! donâ€™t think me ungrateful,â€”donâ€™t think hard of me, any way,â€”I heard all you and master said tonight. I am going to try to save my boyâ€”you will not blame me! God bless and reward you for all your kindness!â€

Hastily folding and directing this, she went to a drawer and made up a little package of clothing for her boy, which she tied with a handkerchief firmly round her waist; and, so fond is a motherâ€™s remembrance, that, even in the terrors of that hour, she did not forget to put in the little package one or two of his favorite toys, reserving a gayly painted parrot to amuse him, when she should be called on to awaken him. It was some trouble to arouse the little sleeper; but, after some effort, he sat up, and was playing with his bird, while his mother was putting on her bonnet and shawl.
â€œWhere are you going, mother?â€ said he, as she drew near the bed, with his little coat and cap.
His mother drew near, and looked so earnestly into his eyes, that he at once divined that something unusual was the matter.

â€œHush, Harry,â€ she said; â€œmustnâ€™t speak loud, or they will hear us. A wicked man was coming to take little Harry away from his mother, and carry him â€™way off in the dark; but mother wonâ€™t let himâ€”sheâ€™s going to put on her little boyâ€™s cap and coat, and run off with him, so the ugly man canâ€™t catch him.â€

Saying these words, she had tied and buttoned on the childâ€™s simple outfit, and, taking him in her arms, she whispered to him to be very still; and, opening a door in her room which led into the outer verandah, she glided noiselessly out.
It was a sparkling, frosty, starlight night, and the mother wrapped the shawl close round her child, as, perfectly quiet with vague terror, he clung round her neck.

Old Bruno, a great Newfoundland, who slept at the end of the porch, rose, with a low growl, as she came near. She gently spoke his name, and the animal, an old pet and playmate of hers, instantly, wagging his tail, prepared to follow her, though apparently revolving much, in this simple dogâ€™s head, what such an indiscreet midnight promenade might mean. Some dim ideas of imprudence or impropriety in the measure seemed to embarrass him considerably; for he often stopped, as Eliza glided forward, and looked wistfully, first at her and then at the house, and then, as if reassured by reflection, he pattered along after her again. A few minutes brought them to the window of Uncle Tomâ€™s cottage, and Eliza stopping, tapped lightly on the window-pane.

The prayer-meeting at Uncle Tomâ€™s had, in the order of hymn-singing, been protracted to a very late hour; and, as Uncle Tom had indulged himself in a few lengthy solos afterwards, the consequence was, that, although it was now between twelve and one oâ€™clock, he and his worthy helpmeet were not yet asleep.

â€œGood Lord! whatâ€™s that?â€ said Aunt Chloe, starting up and hastily drawing the curtain. â€œMy sakes alive, if it anâ€™t Lizy! Get on your clothes, old man, quick!â€”thereâ€™s old Bruno, too, a pawin round; what on airth! Iâ€™m gwine to open the door.â€
And suiting the action to the word, the door flew open, and the light of the tallow candle, which Tom had hastily lighted, fell on the haggard face and dark, wild eyes of the fugitive.
â€œLord bless you!â€”Iâ€™m skeered to look at ye, Lizy! Are ye tuck sick, or whatâ€™s come over ye?â€
â€œIâ€™m running awayâ€”Uncle Tom and Aunt Chloeâ€”carrying off my childâ€”Master sold him!â€
Eliza comes to tell Uncle Tom that he is sold, and that she is running away to save her child.
â€œSold him?â€ echoed both, lifting up their hands in dismay.

â€œYes, sold him!â€ said Eliza, firmly; â€œI crept into the closet by Mistressâ€™ door tonight, and I heard Master tell Missis that he had sold my Harry, and you, Uncle Tom, both, to a trader; and that he was going off this morning on his horse, and that the man was to take possession today.â€

Tom had stood, during this speech, with his hands raised, and his eyes dilated, like a man in a dream. Slowly and gradually, as its meaning came over him, he collapsed, rather than seated himself, on his old chair, and sunk his head down upon his knees.
â€œThe good Lord have pity on us!â€ said Aunt Chloe. â€œO! it donâ€™t seem as if it was true! What has he done, that Masâ€™r should sell him?â€

â€œHe hasnâ€™t done anything,â€”it isnâ€™t for that. Master donâ€™t want to sell, and Missis sheâ€™s always good. I heard her plead and beg for us; but he told her â€™t was no use; that he was in this manâ€™s debt, and that this man had got the power over him; and that if he didnâ€™t pay him off clear, it would end in his having to sell the place and all the people, and move off. Yes, I heard him say there was no choice between selling these two and selling all, the man was driving him so hard. Master said he was sorry; but oh, Missisâ€”you ought to have heard her talk! If she anâ€™t a Christian and an angel, there never was one. Iâ€™m a wicked girl to leave her so; but, then, I canâ€™t help it. She said, herself, one soul was worth more than the world; and this boy has a soul, and if I let him be carried off, who knows whatâ€™ll become of it? It must be right: but, if it anâ€™t right, the Lord forgive me, for I canâ€™t help doing it!â€

â€œWell, old man!â€ said Aunt Chloe, â€œwhy donâ€™t you go, too? Will you wait to be toted down river, where they kill niggers with hard work and starving? Iâ€™d a heap rather die than go there, any day! Thereâ€™s time for ye,â€”be off with Lizy,â€”youâ€™ve got a pass to come and go any time. Come, bustle up, and Iâ€™ll get your things together.â€
Tom slowly raised his head, and looked sorrowfully but quietly around, and said,

â€œNo, noâ€”I anâ€™t going. Let Eliza goâ€”itâ€™s her right! I wouldnâ€™t be the one to say noâ€”â€˜tanâ€™t in natur for her to stay; but you heard what she said! If I must be sold, or all the people on the place, and everything go to rack, why, let me be sold. I sâ€™pose I can bar it as well as any on â€™em,â€ he added, while something like a sob and a sigh shook his broad, rough chest convulsively. â€œMasâ€™r always found me on the spotâ€”he always will. I never have broke trust, nor used my pass no ways contrary to my word, and I never will. Itâ€™s better for me alone to go, than to break up the place and sell all. Masâ€™r anâ€™t to blame, Chloe, and heâ€™ll take care of you and the poorâ€”â€

Here he turned to the rough trundle bed full of little woolly heads, and broke fairly down. He leaned over the back of the chair, and covered his face with his large hands. Sobs, heavy, hoarse and loud, shook the chair, and great tears fell through his fingers on the floor; just such tears, sir, as you dropped into the coffin where lay your first-born son; such tears, woman, as you shed when you heard the cries of your dying babe. For, sir, he was a man,â€”and you are but another man. And, woman, though dressed in silk and jewels, you are but a woman, and, in lifeâ€™s great straits and mighty griefs, ye feel but one sorrow!

â€œAnd now,â€ said Eliza, as she stood in the door, â€œI saw my husband only this afternoon, and I little knew then what was to come. They have pushed him to the very last standing place, and he told me, today, that he was going to run away. Do try, if you can, to get word to him. Tell him how I went, and why I went; and tell him Iâ€™m going to try and find Canada. You must give my love to him, and tell him, if I never see him again,â€ she turned away, and stood with her back to them for a moment, and then added, in a husky voice, â€œtell him to be as good as he can, and try and meet me in the kingdom of heaven.â€
â€œCall Bruno in there,â€ she added. â€œShut the door on him, poor beast! He mustnâ€™t go with me!â€
A few last words and tears, a few simple adieus and blessings, and clasping her wondering and affrighted child in her arms, she glided noiselessly away.

div.head:
Chapter VI
Discovery
div.p: Mr. and Mrs. Shelby, after their protracted discussion of the night before, did not readily sink to repose, and, in consequence, slept somewhat later than usual, the ensuing morning.
â€œI wonder what keeps Eliza,â€ said Mrs. Shelby, after giving her bell repeated pulls, to no purpose.
Mr. Shelby was standing before his dressing-glass, sharpening his razor; and just then the door opened, and a colored boy entered, with his shaving-water.
â€œAndy,â€ said his mistress, â€œstep to Elizaâ€™s door, and tell her I have rung for her three times. Poor thing!â€ she added, to herself, with a sigh.
Andy soon returned, with eyes very wide in astonishment.
â€œLor, Missis! Lizyâ€™s drawers is all open, and her things all lying every which way; and I believe sheâ€™s just done clared out!â€
The truth flashed upon Mr. Shelby and his wife at the same moment. He exclaimed,
â€œThen she suspected it, and sheâ€™s off!â€
â€œThe Lord be thanked!â€ said Mrs. Shelby. â€œI trust she is.â€

â€œWife, you talk like a fool! Really, it will be something pretty awkward for me, if she is. Haley saw that I hesitated about selling this child, and heâ€™ll think I connived at it, to get him out of the way. It touches my honor!â€ And Mr. Shelby left the room hastily.

There was great running and ejaculating, and opening and shutting of doors, and appearance of faces in all shades of color in different places, for about a quarter of an hour. One person only, who might have shed some light on the matter, was entirely silent, and that was the head cook, Aunt Chloe. Silently, and with a heavy cloud settled down over her once joyous face, she proceeded making out her breakfast biscuits, as if she heard and saw nothing of the excitement around her.
Very soon, about a dozen young imps were roosting, like so many crows, on the verandah railings, each one determined to be the first one to apprize the strange Masâ€™r of his ill luck.
â€œHeâ€™ll be rael mad, Iâ€™ll be bound,â€ said Andy.
â€œWonâ€™t he swar!â€ said little black Jake.

â€œYes, for he does swar,â€ said woolly-headed Mandy. â€œI hearn him yesterday, at dinner. I hearn all about it then, â€™cause I got into the closet where Missis keeps the great jugs, and I hearn every word.â€ And Mandy, who had never in her life thought of the meaning of a word she had heard, more than a black cat, now took airs of superior wisdom, and strutted about, forgetting to state that, though actually coiled up among the jugs at the time specified, she had been fast asleep all the time.

When, at last, Haley appeared, booted and spurred, he was saluted with the bad tidings on every hand. The young imps on the verandah were not disappointed in their hope of hearing him â€œswar,â€ which he did with a fluency and fervency which delighted them all amazingly, as they ducked and dodged hither and thither, to be out of the reach of his riding-whip; and, all whooping off together, they tumbled, in a pile of immeasurable giggle, on the withered turf under the verandah, where they kicked up their heels and shouted to their full satisfaction.
â€œIf I had the little devils!â€ muttered Haley, between his teeth.
â€œBut you haâ€™nt got â€™em, though!â€ said Andy, with a triumphant flourish, and making a string of indescribable mouths at the unfortunate traderâ€™s back, when he was fairly beyond hearing.
â€œI say now, Shelby, this yer â€™s a most extroâ€™rnary business!â€ said Haley, as he abruptly entered the parlor. â€œIt seems that gal â€™s off, with her young un.â€
â€œMr. Haley, Mrs. Shelby is present,â€ said Mr. Shelby.
â€œI beg pardon, maâ€™am,â€ said Haley, bowing slightly, with a still lowering brow; â€œbut still I say, as I said before, this yerâ€™s a singâ€™lar report. Is it true, sir?â€

â€œSir,â€ said Mr. Shelby, â€œif you wish to communicate with me, you must observe something of the decorum of a gentleman. Andy, take Mr. Haleyâ€™s hat and riding-whip. Take a seat, sir. Yes, sir; I regret to say that the young woman, excited by overhearing, or having reported to her, something of this business, has taken her child in the night, and made off.â€
â€œI did expect fair dealing in this matter, I confess,â€ said Haley.
â€œWell, sir,â€ said Mr. Shelby, turning sharply round upon him, â€œwhat am I to understand by that remark? If any man calls my honor in question, I have but one answer for him.â€
The trader cowered at this, and in a somewhat lower tone said that â€œit was plaguy hard on a fellow, that had made a fair bargain, to be gulled that way.â€

â€œMr. Haley,â€ said Mr. Shelby, â€œif I did not think you had some cause for disappointment, I should not have borne from you the rude and unceremonious style of your entrance into my parlor this morning. I say thus much, however, since appearances call for it, that I shall allow of no insinuations cast upon me, as if I were at all partner to any unfairness in this matter. Moreover, I shall feel bound to give you every assistance, in the use of horses, servants, &c., in the recovery of your property. So, in short, Haley,â€ said he, suddenly dropping from the tone of dignified coolness to his ordinary one of easy frankness, â€œthe best way for you is to keep good-natured and eat some breakfast, and we will then see what is to be done.â€

Mrs. Shelby now rose, and said her engagements would prevent her being at the breakfast-table that morning; and, deputing a very respectable mulatto woman to attend to the gentlemenâ€™s coffee at the side-board, she left the room.
â€œOld lady donâ€™t like your humble servant, over and above,â€ said Haley, with an uneasy effort to be very familiar.
â€œI am not accustomed to hear my wife spoken of with such freedom,â€ said Mr. Shelby, dryly.
â€œBeg pardon; of course, only a joke, you know,â€ said Haley, forcing a laugh.
â€œSome jokes are less agreeable than others,â€ rejoined Shelby.
â€œDevilish free, now Iâ€™ve signed those papers, cuss him!â€ muttered Haley to himself; â€œquite grand, since yesterday!â€

Never did fall of any prime minister at court occasion wider surges of sensation than the report of Tomâ€™s fate among his compeers on the place. It was the topic in every mouth, everywhere; and nothing was done in the house or in the field, but to discuss its probable results. Elizaâ€™s flightâ€”an unprecedented event on the placeâ€”was also a great accessory in stimulating the general excitement.

Black Sam, as he was commonly called, from his being about three shades blacker than any other son of ebony on the place, was revolving the matter profoundly in all its phases and bearings, with a comprehensiveness of vision and a strict lookout to his own personal well-being, that would have done credit to any white patriot in Washington.

â€œItâ€™s an ill wind dat blow nowhar,â€”dat ar a fact,â€ said Sam, sententiously, giving an additional hoist to his pantaloons, and adroitly substituting a long nail in place of a missing suspender-button, with which effort of mechanical genius he seemed highly delighted.

â€œYes, itâ€™s an ill wind blows nowhar,â€ he repeated. â€œNow, dar, Tomâ€™s downâ€”wal, course derâ€™s room for some nigger to be upâ€”and why not dis nigger?â€”datâ€™s de idee. Tom, a ridinâ€™ round de countryâ€”boots blackedâ€”pass in his pocketâ€”all grand as Cuffeeâ€”but who he? Now, why shouldnâ€™t Sam?â€”datâ€™s what I want to know.â€
â€œHalloo, Samâ€”O Sam! Masâ€™r wants you to cotch Bill and Jerry,â€ said Andy, cutting short Samâ€™s soliloquy.
â€œHigh! whatâ€™s afoot now, young un?â€
â€œWhy, you donâ€™t know, I sâ€™pose, that Lizyâ€™s cut stick, and clared out, with her young un?â€
â€œYou teach your granny!â€ said Sam, with infinite contempt; â€œknowed it a heap sight sooner than you did; this nigger anâ€™t so green, now!â€
â€œWell, anyhow, Masâ€™r wants Bill and Jerry geared right up; and you and I â€™s to go with Masâ€™r Haley, to look arter her.â€
â€œGood, now! datâ€™s de time oâ€™ day!â€ said Sam. â€œItâ€™s Sam datâ€™s called for in dese yer times. Heâ€™s de nigger. See if I donâ€™t cotch her, now; Masâ€™râ€™ll see what Sam can do!â€
â€œAh! but, Sam,â€ said Andy, â€œyouâ€™d better think twice; for Missis donâ€™t want her cotched, and sheâ€™ll be in yer wool.â€
â€œHigh!â€ said Sam, opening his eyes. â€œHow you know dat?â€

â€œHeard her say so, my own self, dis blessed morninâ€™, when I bring in Masâ€™râ€™s shaving-water. She sent me to see why Lizy didnâ€™t come to dress her; and when I telled her she was off, she jest ris up, and ses she, â€˜The Lord be praised;â€™ and Masâ€™r, he seemed rael mad, and ses he, â€˜Wife, you talk like a fool.â€™ But Lor! sheâ€™ll bring him to! I knows well enough how thatâ€™ll be,â€”itâ€™s allers best to stand Missisâ€™ side the fence, now I tell yer.â€

Black Sam, upon this, scratched his woolly pate, which, if it did not contain very profound wisdom, still contained a great deal of a particular species much in demand among politicians of all complexions and countries, and vulgarly denominated â€œknowing which side the bread is buttered;â€ so, stopping with grave consideration, he again gave a hitch to his pantaloons, which was his regularly organized method of assisting his mental perplexities.

â€œDer anâ€™t no sayingâ€™â€”neverâ€”â€˜bout no kind oâ€™ thing in dis yer world,â€ he said, at last. Sam spoke like a philosopher, emphasizing thisâ€”as if he had had a large experience in different sorts of worlds, and therefore had come to his conclusions advisedly.
â€œNow, sartin Iâ€™d a said that Missis would a scoured the varsal world after Lizy,â€ added Sam, thoughtfully.
â€œSo she would,â€ said Andy; â€œbut canâ€™t ye see through a ladder, ye black nigger? Missis donâ€™t want dis yer Masâ€™r Haley to get Lizyâ€™s boy; datâ€™s de go!â€
â€œHigh!â€ said Sam, with an indescribable intonation, known only to those who have heard it among the negroes.

â€œAnd Iâ€™ll tell yer more â€™n all,â€ said Andy; â€œI specs youâ€™d better be making tracks for dem hosses,â€”mighty sudden, too,â€”-for I hearn Missis â€™quirinâ€™ arter yer,â€”so youâ€™ve stood foolinâ€™ long enough.â€

Sam, upon this, began to bestir himself in real earnest, and after a while appeared, bearing down gloriously towards the house, with Bill and Jerry in a full canter, and adroitly throwing himself off before they had any idea of stopping, he brought them up alongside of the horse-post like a tornado. Haleyâ€™s horse, which was a skittish young colt, winced, and bounced, and pulled hard at his halter.
â€œHo, ho!â€ said Sam, â€œskeery, ar ye?â€ and his black visage lighted up with a curious, mischievous gleam. â€œIâ€™ll fix ye now!â€ said he.

There was a large beech-tree overshadowing the place, and the small, sharp, triangular beech-nuts lay scattered thickly on the ground. With one of these in his fingers, Sam approached the colt, stroked and patted, and seemed apparently busy in soothing his agitation. On pretence of adjusting the saddle, he adroitly slipped under it the sharp little nut, in such a manner that the least weight brought upon the saddle would annoy the nervous sensibilities of the animal, without leaving any perceptible graze or wound.
â€œDar!â€ he said, rolling his eyes with an approving grin; â€œme fix â€™em!â€
At this moment Mrs. Shelby appeared on the balcony, beckoning to him. Sam approached with as good a determination to pay court as did ever suitor after a vacant place at St. Jamesâ€™ or Washington.
â€œWhy have you been loitering so, Sam? I sent Andy to tell you to hurry.â€
â€œLord bless you, Missis!â€ said Sam, â€œhorses wonâ€™t be cotched all in a minit; theyâ€™d done clared out way down to the south pasture, and the Lord knows whar!â€
â€œSam, how often must I tell you not to say â€˜Lord bless you, and the Lord knows,â€™ and such things? Itâ€™s wicked.â€
â€œO, Lord bless my soul! I done forgot, Missis! I wonâ€™t say nothing of de sort no more.â€
â€œWhy, Sam, you just have said it again.â€
â€œDid I? O, Lord! I meanâ€”I didnâ€™t go fur to say it.â€
â€œYou must be careful, Sam.â€
â€œJust let me get my breath, Missis, and Iâ€™ll start fair. Iâ€™ll be bery careful.â€
â€œWell, Sam, you are to go with Mr. Haley, to show him the road, and help him. Be careful of the horses, Sam; you know Jerry was a little lame last week; donâ€™t ride them too fast.â€
Mrs. Shelby spoke the last words with a low voice, and strong emphasis.

â€œLet dis child alone for dat!â€ said Sam, rolling up his eyes with a volume of meaning. â€œLord knows! High! Didnâ€™t say dat!â€ said he, suddenly catching his breath, with a ludicrous flourish of apprehension, which made his mistress laugh, spite of herself. â€œYes, Missis, Iâ€™ll look out for de hosses!â€

â€œNow, Andy,â€ said Sam, returning to his stand under the beech-trees, â€œyou see I wouldnâ€™t be â€™t all surprised if dat ar genâ€™lmanâ€™s crittur should gib a fling, by and by, when he comes to be a gettinâ€™ up. You know, Andy, critturs will do such things;â€ and therewith Sam poked Andy in the side, in a highly suggestive manner.
â€œHigh!â€ said Andy, with an air of instant appreciation.

â€œYes, you see, Andy, Missis wants to make time,â€”dat arâ€™s clar to der most orâ€™nary â€™bserver. I jis make a little for her. Now, you see, get all dese yer hosses loose, caperinâ€™ permiscus round dis yer lot and down to de wood dar, and I spec Masâ€™r wonâ€™t be off in a hurry.â€
Andy grinned.

â€œYer see,â€ said Sam, â€œyer see, Andy, if any such thing should happen as that Masâ€™r Haleyâ€™s horse should begin to act contrary, and cut up, you and I jist lets go of ourâ€™n to help him, and weâ€™ll help himâ€”oh yes!â€ And Sam and Andy laid their heads back on their shoulders, and broke into a low, immoderate laugh, snapping their fingers and flourishing their heels with exquisite delight.

At this instant, Haley appeared on the verandah. Somewhat mollified by certain cups of very good coffee, he came out smiling and talking, in tolerably restored humor. Sam and Andy, clawing for certain fragmentary palm-leaves, which they were in the habit of considering as hats, flew to the horseposts, to be ready to â€œhelp Masâ€™r.â€

Samâ€™s palm-leaf had been ingeniously disentangled from all pretensions to braid, as respects its brim; and the slivers starting apart, and standing upright, gave it a blazing air of freedom and defiance, quite equal to that of any Fejee chief; while the whole brim of Andyâ€™s being departed bodily, he rapped the crown on his head with a dexterous thump, and looked about well pleased, as if to say, â€œWho says I havenâ€™t got a hat?â€
â€œWell, boys,â€ said Haley, â€œlook alive now; we must lose no time.â€
â€œNot a bit of him, Masâ€™r!â€ said Sam, putting Haleyâ€™s rein in his hand, and holding his stirrup, while Andy was untying the other two horses.

The instant Haley touched the saddle, the mettlesome creature bounded from the earth with a sudden spring, that threw his master sprawling, some feet off, on the soft, dry turf. Sam, with frantic ejaculations, made a dive at the reins, but only succeeded in brushing the blazing palm-leaf afore-named into the horseâ€™s eyes, which by no means tended to allay the confusion of his nerves. So, with great vehemence, he overturned Sam, and, giving two or three contemptuous snorts, flourished his heels vigorously in the air, and was soon prancing away towards the lower end of the lawn, followed by Bill and Jerry, whom Andy had not failed to let loose, according to contract, speeding them off with various direful ejaculations. And now ensued a miscellaneous scene of confusion. Sam and Andy ran and shouted,â€”dogs barked here and there,â€”and Mike, Mose, Mandy, Fanny, and all the smaller specimens on the place, both male and female, raced, clapped hands, whooped, and shouted, with outrageous officiousness and untiring zeal.

Haleyâ€™s horse, which was a white one, and very fleet and spirited, appeared to enter into the spirit of the scene with great gusto; and having for his coursing ground a lawn of nearly half a mile in extent, gently sloping down on every side into indefinite woodland, he appeared to take infinite delight in seeing how near he could allow his pursuers to approach him, and then, when within a handâ€™s breadth, whisk off with a start and a snort, like a mischievous beast as he was and career far down into some alley of the wood-lot. Nothing was further from Samâ€™s mind than to have any one of the troop taken until such season as should seem to him most befitting,â€”and the exertions that he made were certainly most heroic. Like the sword of Coeur De Lion, which always blazed in the front and thickest of the battle, Samâ€™s palm-leaf was to be seen everywhere when there was the least danger that a horse could be caught; there he would bear down full tilt, shouting, â€œNow for it! cotch him! cotch him!â€ in a way that would set everything to indiscriminate rout in a moment.

Haley ran up and down, and cursed and swore and stamped miscellaneously. Mr. Shelby in vain tried to shout directions from the balcony, and Mrs. Shelby from her chamber window alternately laughed and wondered,â€”not without some inkling of what lay at the bottom of all this confusion.

At last, about twelve oâ€™clock, Sam appeared triumphant, mounted on Jerry, with Haleyâ€™s horse by his side, reeking with sweat, but with flashing eyes and dilated nostrils, showing that the spirit of freedom had not yet entirely subsided.
â€œHeâ€™s cotched!â€ he exclaimed, triumphantly. â€œIf â€™t hadnâ€™t been for me, they might a bust themselves, all on â€™em; but I cotched him!â€
â€œYou!â€ growled Haley, in no amiable mood. â€œIf it hadnâ€™t been for you, this never would have happened.â€
â€œLord bless us, Masâ€™r,â€ said Sam, in a tone of the deepest concern, â€œand me that has been racinâ€™ and chasinâ€™ till the sweat jest pours off me!â€
â€œWell, well!â€ said Haley, â€œyouâ€™ve lost me near three hours, with your cursed nonsense. Now letâ€™s be off, and have no more fooling.â€

â€œWhy, Masâ€™r,â€ said Sam, in a deprecating tone, â€œI believe you mean to kill us all clar, horses and all. Here we are all just ready to drop down, and the critters all in a reek of sweat. Why, Masâ€™r wonâ€™t think of startinâ€™ on now till arter dinner. Masâ€™râ€™s hoss wants rubben down; see how he splashed hisself; and Jerry limps too; donâ€™t think Missis would be willinâ€™ to have us start dis yer way, no how. Lord bless you, Masâ€™r, we can ketch up, if we do stop. Lizy never was no great of a walker.â€

Mrs. Shelby, who, greatly to her amusement, had overheard this conversation from the verandah, now resolved to do her part. She came forward, and, courteously expressing her concern for Haleyâ€™s accident, pressed him to stay to dinner, saying that the cook should bring it on the table immediately.

Thus, all things considered, Haley, with rather an equivocal grace, proceeded to the parlor, while Sam, rolling his eyes after him with unutterable meaning, proceeded gravely with the horses to the stable-yard.

â€œDid yer see him, Andy? did yer see him?â€ said Sam, when he had got fairly beyond the shelter of the barn, and fastened the horse to a post. â€œO, Lor, if it warnâ€™t as good as a meetinâ€™, now, to see him a dancinâ€™ and kickinâ€™ and swarinâ€™ at us. Didnâ€™t I hear him? Swar away, ole fellow (says I to myself ); will yer have yer hoss now, or wait till you cotch him? (says I). Lor, Andy, I think I can see him now.â€ And Sam and Andy leaned up against the barn and laughed to their heartsâ€™ content.
â€œYer oughter seen how mad he looked, when I brought the hoss up. Lord, heâ€™d a killed me, if he dursâ€™ to; and there I was a standinâ€™ as innercent and as humble.â€
â€œLor, I seed you,â€ said Andy; â€œanâ€™t you an old hoss, Sam?â€
â€œRather specks I am,â€ said Sam; â€œdid yer see Missis up stars at the winder? I seed her laughinâ€™.â€
â€œIâ€™m sure, I was racinâ€™ so, I didnâ€™t see nothing,â€ said Andy.

â€œWell, yer see,â€ said Sam, proceeding gravely to wash down Haleyâ€™s pony, â€œI â€™se â€™quired what yer may call a habit oâ€™ bobservation, Andy. Itâ€™s a very â€™portant habit, Andy; and I â€™commend yer to be cultivatinâ€™ it, now yer young. Hist up that hind foot, Andy. Yer see, Andy, itâ€™s bobservation makes all de difference in niggers. Didnâ€™t I see which way the wind blew dis yer morninâ€™? Didnâ€™t I see what Missis wanted, though she never let on? Dat arâ€™s bobservation, Andy. I â€™spects itâ€™s what you may call a faculty. Faculties is different in different peoples, but cultivation of â€™em goes a great way.â€
â€œI guess if I hadnâ€™t helped your bobservation dis morninâ€™, yer wouldnâ€™t have seen your way so smart,â€ said Andy.

â€œAndy,â€ said Sam, â€œyouâ€™s a promisinâ€™ child, der anâ€™t no manner oâ€™ doubt. I thinks lots of yer, Andy; and I donâ€™t feel no ways ashamed to take idees from you. We oughtenter overlook nobody, Andy, cause the smartest on us gets tripped up sometimes. And so, Andy, letâ€™s go up to the house now. Iâ€™ll be bounâ€™ Missisâ€™ll give us an uncommon good bite, dis yer time.â€

div.head:
Chapter VII
The Motherâ€™s Struggle
div.p: It is impossible to conceive of a human creature more wholly desolate and forlorn than Eliza, when she turned her footsteps from Uncle Tomâ€™s cabin.

Her husbandâ€™s suffering and dangers, and the danger of her child, all blended in her mind, with a confused and stunning sense of the risk she was running, in leaving the only home she had ever known, and cutting loose from the protection of a friend whom she loved and revered. Then there was the parting from every familiar object,â€”the place where she had grown up, the trees under which she had played, the groves where she had walked many an evening in happier days, by the side of her young husband,â€”everything, as it lay in the clear, frosty starlight, seemed to speak reproachfully to her, and ask her whither could she go from a home like that?

But stronger than all was maternal love, wrought into a paroxysm of frenzy by the near approach of a fearful danger. Her boy was old enough to have walked by her side, and, in an indifferent case, she would only have led him by the hand; but now the bare thought of putting him out of her arms made her shudder, and she strained him to her bosom with a convulsive grasp, as she went rapidly forward.

The frosty ground creaked beneath her feet, and she trembled at the sound; every quaking leaf and fluttering shadow sent the blood backward to her heart, and quickened her footsteps. She wondered within herself at the strength that seemed to be come upon her; for she felt the weight of her boy as if it had been a feather, and every flutter of fear seemed to increase the supernatural power that bore her on, while from her pale lips burst forth, in frequent ejaculations, the prayer to a Friend aboveâ€”â€œLord, help! Lord, save me!â€

If it were your Harry, mother, or your Willie, that were going to be torn from you by a brutal trader, tomorrow morning,â€”if you had seen the man, and heard that the papers were signed and delivered, and you had only from twelve oâ€™clock till morning to make good your escape,â€”how fast could you walk? How many miles could you make in those few brief hours, with the darling at your bosom,â€”the little sleepy head on your shoulder,â€”the small, soft arms trustingly holding on to your neck?

For the child slept. At first, the novelty and alarm kept him waking; but his mother so hurriedly repressed every breath or sound, and so assured him that if he were only still she would certainly save him, that he clung quietly round her neck, only asking, as he found himself sinking to sleep,
â€œMother, I donâ€™t need to keep awake, do I?â€
â€œNo, my darling; sleep, if you want to.â€
â€œBut, mother, if I do get asleep, you wonâ€™t let him get me?â€
â€œNo! so may God help me!â€ said his mother, with a paler cheek, and a brighter light in her large dark eyes.
â€œYouâ€™re sure, anâ€™t you, mother?â€

â€œYes, sure!â€ said the mother, in a voice that startled herself; for it seemed to her to come from a spirit within, that was no part of her; and the boy dropped his little weary head on her shoulder, and was soon asleep. How the touch of those warm arms, the gentle breathings that came in her neck, seemed to add fire and spirit to her movements! It seemed to her as if strength poured into her in electric streams, from every gentle touch and movement of the sleeping, confiding child. Sublime is the dominion of the mind over the body, that, for a time, can make flesh and nerve impregnable, and string the sinews like steel, so that the weak become so mighty.

The boundaries of the farm, the grove, the wood-lot, passed by her dizzily, as she walked on; and still she went, leaving one familiar object after another, slacking not, pausing not, till reddening daylight found her many a long mile from all traces of any familiar objects upon the open highway.

She had often been, with her mistress, to visit some connections, in the little village of Tâ€”â€”, not far from the Ohio river, and knew the road well. To go thither, to escape across the Ohio river, were the first hurried outlines of her plan of escape; beyond that, she could only hope in God.

When horses and vehicles began to move along the highway, with that alert perception peculiar to a state of excitement, and which seems to be a sort of inspiration, she became aware that her headlong pace and distracted air might bring on her remark and suspicion. She therefore put the boy on the ground, and, adjusting her dress and bonnet, she walked on at as rapid a pace as she thought consistent with the preservation of appearances. In her little bundle she had provided a store of cakes and apples, which she used as expedients for quickening the speed of the child, rolling the apple some yards before them, when the boy would run with all his might after it; and this ruse, often repeated, carried them over many a half-mile.

After a while, they came to a thick patch of woodland, through which murmured a clear brook. As the child complained of hunger and thirst, she climbed over the fence with him; and, sitting down behind a large rock which concealed them from the road, she gave him a breakfast out of her little package. The boy wondered and grieved that she could not eat; and when, putting his arms round her neck, he tried to wedge some of his cake into her mouth, it seemed to her that the rising in her throat would choke her.

â€œNo, no, Harry darling! mother canâ€™t eat till you are safe! We must go onâ€”onâ€”till we come to the river!â€ And she hurried again into the road, and again constrained herself to walk regularly and composedly forward.

She was many miles past any neighborhood where she was personally known. If she should chance to meet any who knew her, she reflected that the well-known kindness of the family would be of itself a blind to suspicion, as making it an unlikely supposition that she could be a fugitive. As she was also so white as not to be known as of colored lineage, without a critical survey, and her child was white also, it was much easier for her to pass on unsuspected.

On this presumption, she stopped at noon at a neat farmhouse, to rest herself, and buy some dinner for her child and self; for, as the danger decreased with the distance, the supernatural tension of the nervous system lessened, and she found herself both weary and hungry.

The good woman, kindly and gossipping, seemed rather pleased than otherwise with having somebody come in to talk with; and accepted, without examination, Elizaâ€™s statement, that she â€œwas going on a little piece, to spend a week with her friends,â€â€”all which she hoped in her heart might prove strictly true.

An hour before sunset, she entered the village of Tâ€”â€”, by the Ohio river, weary and foot-sore, but still strong in heart. Her first glance was at the river, which lay, like Jordan, between her and the Canaan of liberty on the other side.

It was now early spring, and the river was swollen and turbulent; great cakes of floating ice were swinging heavily to and fro in the turbid waters. Owing to the peculiar form of the shore on the Kentucky side, the land bending far out into the water, the ice had been lodged and detained in great quantities, and the narrow channel which swept round the bend was full of ice, piled one cake over another, thus forming a temporary barrier to the descending ice, which lodged, and formed a great, undulating raft, filling up the whole river, and extending almost to the Kentucky shore.

Eliza stood, for a moment, contemplating this unfavorable aspect of things, which she saw at once must prevent the usual ferry-boat from running, and then turned into a small public house on the bank, to make a few inquiries.

The hostess, who was busy in various fizzing and stewing operations over the fire, preparatory to the evening meal, stopped, with a fork in her hand, as Elizaâ€™s sweet and plaintive voice arrested her.
â€œWhat is it?â€ she said.
â€œIsnâ€™t there any ferry or boat, that takes people over to Bâ€”â€”, now?â€ she said.
â€œNo, indeed!â€ said the woman; â€œthe boats has stopped running.â€
Elizaâ€™s look of dismay and disappointment struck the woman, and she said, inquiringly,
â€œMay be youâ€™re wanting to get over?â€”anybody sick? Ye seem mighty anxious?â€
â€œIâ€™ve got a child thatâ€™s very dangerous,â€ said Eliza. â€œI never heard of it till last night, and Iâ€™ve walked quite a piece today, in hopes to get to the ferry.â€

â€œWell, now, thatâ€™s onlucky,â€ said the woman, whose motherly sympathies were much aroused; â€œIâ€™m reâ€™lly consarned for ye. Solomon!â€ she called, from the window, towards a small back building. A man, in leather apron and very dirty hands, appeared at the door.
â€œI say, Sol,â€ said the woman, â€œis that ar man going to tote them barâ€™ls over tonight?â€
â€œHe said he should try, if â€™t was any way prudent,â€ said the man.

â€œThereâ€™s a man a piece down here, thatâ€™s going over with some truck this evening, if he dursâ€™ to; heâ€™ll be in here to supper tonight, so youâ€™d better set down and wait. Thatâ€™s a sweet little fellow,â€ added the woman, offering him a cake.
But the child, wholly exhausted, cried with weariness.
â€œPoor fellow! he isnâ€™t used to walking, and Iâ€™ve hurried him on so,â€ said Eliza.

â€œWell, take him into this room,â€ said the woman, opening into a small bed-room, where stood a comfortable bed. Eliza laid the weary boy upon it, and held his hands in hers till he was fast asleep. For her there was no rest. As a fire in her bones, the thought of the pursuer urged her on; and she gazed with longing eyes on the sullen, surging waters that lay between her and liberty.
Here we must take our leave of her for the present, to follow the course of her pursuers.

Though Mrs. Shelby had promised that the dinner should be hurried on table, yet it was soon seen, as the thing has often been seen before, that it required more than one to make a bargain. So, although the order was fairly given out in Haleyâ€™s hearing, and carried to Aunt Chloe by at least half a dozen juvenile messengers, that dignitary only gave certain very gruff snorts, and tosses of her head, and went on with every operation in an unusually leisurely and circumstantial manner.

For some singular reason, an impression seemed to reign among the servants generally that Missis would not be particularly disobliged by delay; and it was wonderful what a number of counter accidents occurred constantly, to retard the course of things. One luckless wight contrived to upset the gravy; and then gravy had to be got up de novo, with due care and formality, Aunt Chloe watching and stirring with dogged precision, answering shortly, to all suggestions of haste, that she â€œwarnâ€™t a going to have raw gravy on the table, to help nobodyâ€™s catchings.â€ One tumbled down with the water, and had to go to the spring for more; and another precipitated the butter into the path of events; and there was from time to time giggling news brought into the kitchen that â€œMasâ€™r Haley was mighty oneasy, and that he couldnâ€™t sit in his cheer no ways, but was a walkinâ€™ and stalkinâ€™ to the winders and through the porch.â€

â€œSarves him right!â€ said Aunt Chloe, indignantly. â€œHeâ€™ll get wus nor oneasy, one of these days, if he donâ€™t mend his ways. His masterâ€™ll be sending for him, and then see how heâ€™ll look!â€
â€œHeâ€™ll go to torment, and no mistake,â€ said little Jake.

â€œHe desarves it!â€ said Aunt Chloe, grimly; â€œheâ€™s broke a many, many, many hearts,â€”I tell ye all!â€ she said, stopping, with a fork uplifted in her hands; â€œitâ€™s like what Masâ€™r George reads in Ravelations,â€”souls a callinâ€™ under the altar! and a callinâ€™ on the Lord for vengeance on sich!â€”and by and by the Lord heâ€™ll hear â€™emâ€”so he will!â€

Aunt Chloe, who was much revered in the kitchen, was listened to with open mouth; and, the dinner being now fairly sent in, the whole kitchen was at leisure to gossip with her, and to listen to her remarks.
â€œSichâ€™ll be burnt up forever, and no mistake; wonâ€™t ther?â€ said Andy.
â€œIâ€™d be glad to see it, Iâ€™ll be bounâ€™,â€ said little Jake.
â€œChilâ€™en!â€ said a voice, that made them all start. It was Uncle Tom, who had come in, and stood listening to the conversation at the door.

â€œChilâ€™en!â€ he said, â€œIâ€™m afeard you donâ€™t know what yeâ€™re sayinâ€™. Forever is a dreâ€™ful word, chilâ€™en; itâ€™s awful to think on â€™t. You oughtenter wish that ar to any human crittur.â€
â€œWe wouldnâ€™t to anybody but the soul-drivers,â€ said Andy; â€œnobody can help wishing it to them, they â€™s so awful wicked.â€

â€œDonâ€™t natur herself kinder cry out on â€™em?â€ said Aunt Chloe. â€œDonâ€™t dey tear der suckinâ€™ baby right off his motherâ€™s breast, and sell him, and der little children as is crying and holding on by her clothes,â€”donâ€™t dey pull â€™em off and sells â€™em? Donâ€™t dey tear wife and husband apart?â€ said Aunt Chloe, beginning to cry, â€œwhen itâ€™s jest takinâ€™ the very life on â€™em?â€”and all the while does they feel one bit, donâ€™t dey drink and smoke, and take it oncommon easy? Lor, if the devil donâ€™t get them, whatâ€™s he good for?â€ And Aunt Chloe covered her face with her checked apron, and began to sob in good earnest.
â€œPray for them that â€™spitefully use you, the good book says,â€ says Tom.
â€œPray for â€™em!â€ said Aunt Chloe; â€œLor, itâ€™s too tough! I canâ€™t pray for â€™em.â€

â€œItâ€™s natur, Chloe, and natur â€™s strong,â€ said Tom, â€œbut the Lordâ€™s grace is stronger; besides, you oughter think what an awful state a poor critturâ€™s soul â€™s in thatâ€™ll do them ar things,â€”you oughter thank God that you anâ€™t like him, Chloe. Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™d rather be sold, ten thousand times over, than to have all that ar poor critturâ€™s got to answer for.â€
â€œSo â€™d I, a heap,â€ said Jake. â€œLor, shouldnâ€™t we cotch it, Andy?â€
Andy shrugged his shoulders, and gave an acquiescent whistle.

â€œIâ€™m glad Masâ€™r didnâ€™t go off this morning, as he looked to,â€ said Tom; â€œthat ar hurt me more than sellinâ€™, it did. Mebbe it might have been natural for him, but â€™t would have come despâ€™t hard on me, as has known him from a baby; but Iâ€™ve seen Masâ€™r, and I begin ter feel sort oâ€™ reconciled to the Lordâ€™s will now. Masâ€™r couldnâ€™t help hisself; he did right, but Iâ€™m feared things will be kinder goinâ€™ to rack, when Iâ€™m gone Masâ€™r canâ€™t be spected to be a pryinâ€™ round everywhar, as Iâ€™ve done, a keepinâ€™ up all the ends. The boys all means well, but they â€™s powerful carâ€™less. That ar troubles me.â€
The bell here rang, and Tom was summoned to the parlor.

â€œTom,â€ said his master, kindly, â€œI want you to notice that I give this gentleman bonds to forfeit a thousand dollars if you are not on the spot when he wants you; heâ€™s going today to look after his other business, and you can have the day to yourself. Go anywhere you like, boy.â€
â€œThank you, Masâ€™r,â€ said Tom.

â€œAnd mind yourself,â€ said the trader, â€œand donâ€™t come it over your master with any oâ€™ yer nigger tricks; for Iâ€™ll take every cent out of him, if you anâ€™t thar. If heâ€™d hear to me, he wouldnâ€™t trust any on yeâ€”slippery as eels!â€

â€œMasâ€™r,â€ said Tom,â€”and he stood very straight,â€”â€œI was jist eight years old when ole Missis put you into my arms, and you wasnâ€™t a year old. â€˜Thar,â€™ says she, â€˜Tom, thatâ€™s to be your young Masâ€™r; take good care on him,â€™ says she. And now I jist ask you, Masâ€™r, have I ever broke word to you, or gone contrary to you, â€™specially since I was a Christian?â€
Mr. Shelby was fairly overcome, and the tears rose to his eyes.
â€œMy good boy,â€ said he, â€œthe Lord knows you say but the truth; and if I was able to help it, all the world shouldnâ€™t buy you.â€

â€œAnd sure as I am a Christian woman,â€ said Mrs. Shelby, â€œyou shall be redeemed as soon as I can any way bring together means. Sir,â€ she said to Haley, â€œtake good account of who you sell him to, and let me know.â€
â€œLor, yes, for that matter,â€ said the trader, â€œI may bring him up in a year, not much the wuss for wear, and trade him back.â€
â€œIâ€™ll trade with you then, and make it for your advantage,â€ said Mrs. Shelby.

â€œOf course,â€ said the trader, â€œall â€™s equal with me; liâ€™ves trade â€™em up as down, so I does a good business. All I want is a livinâ€™, you know, maâ€™am; thatâ€™s all any on us wants, I, sâ€™pose.â€

Mr. and Mrs. Shelby both felt annoyed and degraded by the familiar impudence of the trader, and yet both saw the absolute necessity of putting a constraint on their feelings. The more hopelessly sordid and insensible he appeared, the greater became Mrs. Shelbyâ€™s dread of his succeeding in recapturing Eliza and her child, and of course the greater her motive for detaining him by every female artifice. She therefore graciously smiled, assented, chatted familiarly, and did all she could to make time pass imperceptibly.
At two oâ€™clock Sam and Andy brought the horses up to the posts, apparently greatly refreshed and invigorated by the scamper of the morning.

Sam was there new oiled from dinner, with an abundance of zealous and ready officiousness. As Haley approached, he was boasting, in flourishing style, to Andy, of the evident and eminent success of the operation, now that he had â€œfarly come to it.â€
â€œYour master, I sâ€™pose, donâ€™t keep no dogs,â€ said Haley, thoughtfully, as he prepared to mount.
â€œHeaps on â€™em,â€ said Sam, triumphantly; â€œtharâ€™s Brunoâ€”heâ€™s a roarer! and, besides that, â€™bout every nigger of us keeps a pup of some natur or uther.â€
â€œPoh!â€ said Haley,â€”and he said something else, too, with regard to the said dogs, at which Sam muttered,
â€œI donâ€™t see no use cussinâ€™ on â€™em, no way.â€
â€œBut your master donâ€™t keep no dogs (I pretty much know he donâ€™t) for trackinâ€™ out niggers.â€
Sam knew exactly what he meant, but he kept on a look of earnest and desperate simplicity.

â€œOur dogs all smells round considable sharp. I spect theyâ€™s the kind, though they hanâ€™t never had no practice. They â€™s far dogs, though, at most anything, if youâ€™d get â€™em started. Here, Bruno,â€ he called, whistling to the lumbering Newfoundland, who came pitching tumultuously toward them.
â€œYou go hang!â€ said Haley, getting up. â€œCome, tumble up now.â€

Sam tumbled up accordingly, dexterously contriving to tickle Andy as he did so, which occasioned Andy to split out into a laugh, greatly to Haleyâ€™s indignation, who made a cut at him with his riding-whip.
â€œI â€™s â€™stonished at yer, Andy,â€ said Sam, with awful gravity. â€œThis yerâ€™s a seris bisness, Andy. Yer mustnâ€™t be a makinâ€™ game. This yer anâ€™t no way to help Masâ€™r.â€

â€œI shall take the straight road to the river,â€ said Haley, decidedly, after they had come to the boundaries of the estate. â€œI know the way of all of â€™em,â€”they makes tracks for the underground.â€
â€œSartin,â€ said Sam, â€œdatâ€™s de idee. Masâ€™r Haley hits de thing right in de middle. Now, derâ€™s two roads to de river,â€”de dirt road and der pike,â€”which Masâ€™r mean to take?â€
Andy looked up innocently at Sam, surprised at hearing this new geographical fact, but instantly confirmed what he said, by a vehement reiteration.
â€œCause,â€ said Sam, â€œIâ€™d rather be â€™clined to â€™magine that Lizy â€™d take de dirt road, beinâ€™ itâ€™s the least travelled.â€
Haley, notwithstanding that he was a very old bird, and naturally inclined to be suspicious of chaff, was rather brought up by this view of the case.
â€œIf yer warnâ€™t both on yer such cussed liars, now!â€ he said, contemplatively as he pondered a moment.

The pensive, reflective tone in which this was spoken appeared to amuse Andy prodigiously, and he drew a little behind, and shook so as apparently to run a great risk of failing off his horse, while Samâ€™s face was immovably composed into the most doleful gravity.

â€œCourse,â€ said Sam, â€œMasâ€™r can do as heâ€™d ruther, go de straight road, if Masâ€™r thinks best,â€”itâ€™s all one to us. Now, when I study â€™pon it, I think de straight road de best, deridedly.â€
â€œShe would naturally go a lonesome way,â€ said Haley, thinking aloud, and not minding Samâ€™s remark.

â€œDar anâ€™t no sayinâ€™,â€ said Sam; â€œgals is pecular; they never does nothinâ€™ ye thinks they will; mose genâ€™lly the contrary. Gals is natâ€™lly made contrary; and so, if you thinks theyâ€™ve gone one road, it is sartin youâ€™d better go tâ€™ other, and then youâ€™ll be sure to find â€™em. Now, my private â€™pinion is, Lizy took der road; so I think weâ€™d better take de straight one.â€

This profound generic view of the female sex did not seem to dispose Haley particularly to the straight road, and he announced decidedly that he should go the other, and asked Sam when they should come to it.

â€œA little piece ahead,â€ said Sam, giving a wink to Andy with the eye which was on Andyâ€™s side of the head; and he added, gravely, â€œbut Iâ€™ve studded on de matter, and Iâ€™m quite clar we ought not to go dat ar way. I nebber been over it no way. Itâ€™s despit lonesome, and we might lose our way,â€”whar weâ€™d come to, de Lord only knows.â€
â€œNevertheless,â€ said Haley, â€œI shall go that way.â€
â€œNow I think on â€™t, I think I hearn â€™em tell that dat ar road was all fenced up and down by der creek, and thar, anâ€™t it, Andy?â€
Andy wasnâ€™t certain; heâ€™d only â€œhearn tellâ€ about that road, but never been over it. In short, he was strictly noncommittal.

Haley, accustomed to strike the balance of probabilities between lies of greater or lesser magnitude, thought that it lay in favor of the dirt road aforesaid. The mention of the thing he thought he perceived was involuntary on Samâ€™s part at first, and his confused attempts to dissuade him he set down to a desperate lying on second thoughts, as being unwilling to implicate Liza.
When, therefore, Sam indicated the road, Haley plunged briskly into it, followed by Sam and Andy.

Now, the road, in fact, was an old one, that had formerly been a thoroughfare to the river, but abandoned for many years after the laying of the new pike. It was open for about an hourâ€™s ride, and after that it was cut across by various farms and fences. Sam knew this fact perfectly well,â€”indeed, the road had been so long closed up, that Andy had never heard of it. He therefore rode along with an air of dutiful submission, only groaning and vociferating occasionally that â€™t was â€œdespâ€™t rough, and bad for Jerryâ€™s foot.â€
â€œNow, I jest give yer warning,â€ said Haley, â€œI know yer; yer wonâ€™t get me to turn off this road, with all yer fussinâ€™â€”so you shet up!â€
â€œMasâ€™r will go his own way!â€ said Sam, with rueful submission, at the same time winking most portentously to Andy, whose delight was now very near the explosive point.

Sam was in wonderful spirits,â€”professed to keep a very brisk lookout,â€”at one time exclaiming that he saw â€œa galâ€™s bonnetâ€ on the top of some distant eminence, or calling to Andy â€œif that thar wasnâ€™t â€™Lizyâ€™ down in the hollow;â€ always making these exclamations in some rough or craggy part of the road, where the sudden quickening of speed was a special inconvenience to all parties concerned, and thus keeping Haley in a state of constant commotion.

After riding about an hour in this way, the whole party made a precipitate and tumultuous descent into a barn-yard belonging to a large farming establishment. Not a soul was in sight, all the hands being employed in the fields; but, as the barn stood conspicuously and plainly square across the road, it was evident that their journey in that direction had reached a decided finale.
â€œWanâ€™t dat ar what I telled Masâ€™r?â€ said Sam, with an air of injured innocence. â€œHow does strange gentleman spect to know more about a country dan de natives born and raised?â€
â€œYou rascal!â€ said Haley, â€œyou knew all about this.â€
â€œDidnâ€™t I tell yer I knowd, and yer wouldnâ€™t believe me? I telled Masâ€™r â€™t was all shet up, and fenced up, and I didnâ€™t spect we could get through,â€”Andy heard me.â€

It was all too true to be disputed, and the unlucky man had to pocket his wrath with the best grace he was able, and all three faced to the right about, and took up their line of march for the highway.

In consequence of all the various delays, it was about three-quarters of an hour after Eliza had laid her child to sleep in the village tavern that the party came riding into the same place. Eliza was standing by the window, looking out in another direction, when Samâ€™s quick eye caught a glimpse of her. Haley and Andy were two yards behind. At this crisis, Sam contrived to have his hat blown off, and uttered a loud and characteristic ejaculation, which startled her at once; she drew suddenly back; the whole train swept by the window, round to the front door.

A thousand lives seemed to be concentrated in that one moment to Eliza. Her room opened by a side door to the river. She caught her child, and sprang down the steps towards it. The trader caught a full glimpse of her just as she was disappearing down the bank; and throwing himself from his horse, and calling loudly on Sam and Andy, he was after her like a hound after a deer. In that dizzy moment her feet to her scarce seemed to touch the ground, and a moment brought her to the waterâ€™s edge. Right on behind they came; and, nerved with strength such as God gives only to the desperate, with one wild cry and flying leap, she vaulted sheer over the turbid current by the shore, on to the raft of ice beyond. It was a desperate leapâ€”impossible to anything but madness and despair; and Haley, Sam, and Andy, instinctively cried out, and lifted up their hands, as she did it.

The huge green fragment of ice on which she alighted pitched and creaked as her weight came on it, but she staid there not a moment. With wild cries and desperate energy she leaped to another and still another cake; stumblingâ€”leapingâ€”slippingâ€”springing upwards again! Her shoes are goneâ€”her stockings cut from her feetâ€”while blood marked every step; but she saw nothing, felt nothing, till dimly, as in a dream, she saw the Ohio side, and a man helping her up the bank.
â€œYer a brave gal, now, whoever ye ar!â€ said the man, with an oath.
Eliza recognized the voice and face for a man who owned a farm not far from her old home.
â€œO, Mr. Symmes!â€”save meâ€”do save meâ€”do hide me!â€ said Elia.
â€œWhy, whatâ€™s this?â€ said the man. â€œWhy, if â€™tanâ€™t Shelbyâ€™s gal!â€
â€œMy child!â€”this boy!â€”heâ€™d sold him! There is his Masâ€™r,â€ said she, pointing to the Kentucky shore. â€œO, Mr. Symmes, youâ€™ve got a little boy!â€
â€œSo I have,â€ said the man, as he roughly, but kindly, drew her up the steep bank. â€œBesides, youâ€™re a right brave gal. I like grit, wherever I see it.â€
When they had gained the top of the bank, the man paused.

â€œIâ€™d be glad to do something for ye,â€ said he; â€œbut then thereâ€™s nowhar I could take ye. The best I can do is to tell ye to go thar,â€ said he, pointing to a large white house which stood by itself, off the main street of the village. â€œGo thar; theyâ€™re kind folks. Tharâ€™s no kind oâ€™ danger but theyâ€™ll help you,â€”theyâ€™re up to all that sort oâ€™ thing.â€
â€œThe Lord bless you!â€ said Eliza, earnestly.
â€œNo â€™casion, no â€™casion in the world,â€ said the man. â€œWhat Iâ€™ve doneâ€™s of no â€™count.â€
â€œAnd, oh, surely, sir, you wonâ€™t tell any one!â€

â€œGo to thunder, gal! What do you take a feller for? In course not,â€ said the man. â€œCome, now, go along like a likely, sensible gal, as you are. Youâ€™ve arnt your liberty, and you shall have it, for all me.â€
The woman folded her child to her bosom, and walked firmly and swiftly away. The man stood and looked after her.

â€œShelby, now, mebbe wonâ€™t think this yer the most neighborly thing in the world; but whatâ€™s a feller to do? If he catches one of my gals in the same fix, heâ€™s welcome to pay back. Somehow I never could see no kind oâ€™ critter a strivinâ€™ and pantinâ€™, and trying to clar theirselves, with the dogs arter â€™em and go agin â€™em. Besides, I donâ€™t see no kind of â€™casion for me to be hunter and catcher for other folks, neither.â€

So spoke this poor, heathenish Kentuckian, who had not been instructed in his constitutional relations, and consequently was betrayed into acting in a sort of Christianized manner, which, if he had been better situated and more enlightened, he would not have been left to do.
Haley had stood a perfectly amazed spectator of the scene, till Eliza had disappeared up the bank, when he turned a blank, inquiring look on Sam and Andy.
â€œThat ar was a tolable fair stroke of business,â€ said Sam.
â€œThe gal â€™s got seven devils in her, I believe!â€ said Haley. â€œHow like a wildcat she jumped!â€
â€œWal, now,â€ said Sam, scratching his head, â€œI hope Masâ€™râ€™ll â€™scuse us trying dat ar road. Donâ€™t think I feel spry enough for dat ar, no way!â€ and Sam gave a hoarse chuckle.
â€œYou laugh!â€ said the trader, with a growl.

â€œLord bless you, Masâ€™r, I couldnâ€™t help it now,â€ said Sam, giving way to the long pent-up delight of his soul. â€œShe looked so curiâ€™s, a leapinâ€™ and springinâ€™â€”ice a crackinâ€™â€”and only to hear her,â€”plump! ker chunk! ker splash! Spring! Lord! how she goes it!â€ and Sam and Andy laughed till the tears rolled down their cheeks.
â€œIâ€™ll make ye laugh tâ€™ other side yer mouths!â€ said the trader, laying about their heads with his riding-whip.
Both ducked, and ran shouting up the bank, and were on their horses before he was up.

â€œGood-evening, Masâ€™r!â€ said Sam, with much gravity. â€œI berry much spect Missis be anxious â€™bout Jerry. Masâ€™r Haley wonâ€™t want us no longer. Missis wouldnâ€™t hear of our ridinâ€™ the critters over Lizyâ€™s bridge tonight;â€ and, with a facetious poke into Andyâ€™s ribs, he started off, followed by the latter, at full speed,â€”their shouts of laughter coming faintly on the wind.

div.head:
Chapter VIII
Elizaâ€™s Escape
div.p: Eliza made her desperate retreat across the river just in the dusk of twilight. The gray mist of evening, rising slowly from the river, enveloped her as she disappeared up the bank, and the swollen current and floundering masses of ice presented a hopeless barrier between her and her pursuer. Haley therefore slowly and discontentedly returned to the little tavern, to ponder further what was to be done. The woman opened to him the door of a little parlor, covered with a rag carpet, where stood a table with a very shining black oil-cloth, sundry lank, high-backed wood chairs, with some plaster images in resplendent colors on the mantel-shelf, above a very dimly-smoking grate; a long hard-wood settle extended its uneasy length by the chimney, and here Haley sat him down to meditate on the instability of human hopes and happiness in general.

â€œWhat did I want with the little cuss, now,â€ he said to himself, â€œthat I should have got myself treed like a coon, as I am, this yer way?â€ and Haley relieved himself by repeating over a not very select litany of imprecations on himself, which, though there was the best possible reason to consider them as true, we shall, as a matter of taste, omit.
He was startled by the loud and dissonant voice of a man who was apparently dismounting at the door. He hurried to the window.
â€œBy the land! if this yer anâ€™t the nearest, now, to what Iâ€™ve heard folks call Providence,â€ said Haley. â€œI do bâ€™lieve that arâ€™s Tom Loker.â€

Haley hastened out. Standing by the bar, in the corner of the room, was a brawny, muscular man, full six feet in height, and broad in proportion. He was dressed in a coat of buffalo-skin, made with the hair outward, which gave him a shaggy and fierce appearance, perfectly in keeping with the whole air of his physiognomy. In the head and face every organ and lineament expressive of brutal and unhesitating violence was in a state of the highest possible development. Indeed, could our readers fancy a bull-dog come unto manâ€™s estate, and walking about in a hat and coat, they would have no unapt idea of the general style and effect of his physique. He was accompanied by a travelling companion, in many respects an exact contrast to himself. He was short and slender, lithe and catlike in his motions, and had a peering, mousing expression about his keen black eyes, with which every feature of his face seemed sharpened into sympathy; his thin, long nose, ran out as if it was eager to bore into the nature of things in general; his sleek, thin, black hair was stuck eagerly forward, and all his motions and evolutions expressed a dry, cautious acuteness. The great man poured out a big tumbler half full of raw spirits, and gulped it down without a word. The little man stood tiptoe, and putting his head first to one side and then the other, and snuffing considerately in the directions of the various bottles, ordered at last a mint julep, in a thin and quivering voice, and with an air of great circumspection. When poured out, he took it and looked at it with a sharp, complacent air, like a man who thinks he has done about the right thing, and hit the nail on the head, and proceeded to dispose of it in short and well-advised sips.
â€œWal, now, whoâ€™d a thought this yer luck â€™ad come to me? Why, Loker, how are ye?â€ said Haley, coming forward, and extending his hand to the big man.
â€œThe devil!â€ was the civil reply. â€œWhat brought you here, Haley?â€

The mousing man, who bore the name of Marks, instantly stopped his sipping, and, poking his head forward, looked shrewdly on the new acquaintance, as a cat sometimes looks at a moving dry leaf, or some other possible object of pursuit.
â€œI say, Tom, this yerâ€™s the luckiest thing in the world. Iâ€™m in a devil of a hobble, and you must help me out.â€
â€œUgh? aw! like enough!â€ grunted his complacent acquaintance. â€œA body may be pretty sure of that, when youâ€™re glad to see â€™em; something to be made off of â€™em. Whatâ€™s the blow now?â€
â€œYouâ€™ve got a friend here?â€ said Haley, looking doubtfully at Marks; â€œpartner, perhaps?â€
â€œYes, I have. Here, Marks! hereâ€™s that ar feller that I was in with in Natchez.â€
â€œShall be pleased with his acquaintance,â€ said Marks, thrusting out a long, thin hand, like a ravenâ€™s claw. â€œMr. Haley, I believe?â€

â€œThe same, sir,â€ said Haley. â€œAnd now, gentlemen, seeinâ€™ as weâ€™ve met so happily, I think Iâ€™ll stand up to a small matter of a treat in this here parlor. So, now, old coon,â€ said he to the man at the bar, â€œget us hot water, and sugar, and cigars, and plenty of the real stuff and weâ€™ll have a blow-out.â€

Behold, then, the candles lighted, the fire stimulated to the burning point in the grate, and our three worthies seated round a table, well spread with all the accessories to good fellowship enumerated before.

Haley began a pathetic recital of his peculiar troubles. Loker shut up his mouth, and listened to him with gruff and surly attention. Marks, who was anxiously and with much fidgeting compounding a tumbler of punch to his own peculiar taste, occasionally looked up from his employment, and, poking his sharp nose and chin almost into Haleyâ€™s face, gave the most earnest heed to the whole narrative. The conclusion of it appeared to amuse him extremely, for he shook his shoulders and sides in silence, and perked up his thin lips with an air of great internal enjoyment.
â€œSo, then, yeâ€™r fairly sewed up, anâ€™t ye?â€ he said; â€œhe! he! he! Itâ€™s neatly done, too.â€
â€œThis yer young-un business makes lots of trouble in the trade,â€ said Haley, dolefully.

â€œIf we could get a breed of gals that didnâ€™t care, now, for their young uns,â€ said Marks; â€œtell ye, I think â€™t would be â€™bout the greatest modâ€™rn improvement I knows on,â€â€”and Marks patronized his joke by a quiet introductory sniggle.

â€œJes so,â€ said Haley; â€œI never couldnâ€™t see into it; young uns is heaps of trouble to â€™em; one would think, now, theyâ€™d be glad to get clar on â€™em; but they arnâ€™t. And the more trouble a young un is, and the more good for nothing, as a genâ€™l thing, the tighter they sticks to â€™em.â€

â€œWal, Mr. Haley,â€ said Marks, â€œâ€˜est pass the hot water. Yes, sir, you say â€™est what I feel and allâ€™us have. Now, I bought a gal once, when I was in the trade,â€”a tight, likely wench she was, too, and quite considerable smart,â€”and she had a young un that was misâ€™able sickly; it had a crooked back, or something or other; and I jest gin â€™t away to a man that thought heâ€™d take his chance raising on â€™t, being it didnâ€™t cost nothinâ€™;â€”never thought, yer know, of the galâ€™s takinâ€™ on about it,â€”but, Lord, yer oughter seen how she went on. Why, reâ€™lly, she did seem to me to valley the child more â€™cause â€t was sickly and cross, and plagued her; and she warnâ€™t making bâ€™lieve, neither,â€”cried about it, she did, and lopped round, as if sheâ€™d lost every friend she had. It reâ€™lly was droll to think on â€™t. Lord, there ainâ€™t no end to womenâ€™s notions.â€

â€œWal, jest so with me,â€ said Haley. â€œLast summer, down on Red River, I got a gal traded off on me, with a likely lookinâ€™ child enough, and his eyes looked as bright as yourn; but, come to look, I found him stone blind. Factâ€”he was stone blind. Wal, ye see, I thought there warnâ€™t no harm in my jest passing him along, and not sayinâ€™ nothinâ€™; and Iâ€™d got him nicely swapped off for a keg oâ€™ whiskey; but come to get him away from the gal, she was jest like a tiger. So â€™t was before we started, and I hadnâ€™t got my gang chained up; so what should she do but ups on a cotton-bale, like a cat, ketches a knife from one of the deck hands, and, I tell ye, she made all fly for a minit, till she saw â€™t wanâ€™t no use; and she jest turns round, and pitches head first, young un and all, into the river,â€”went down plump, and never ris.â€
â€œBah!â€ said Tom Loker, who had listened to these stories with ill-repressed disgust,â€”â€œshifâ€™less, both on ye! my gals donâ€™t cut up no such shines, I tell ye!â€
â€œIndeed! how do you help it?â€ said Marks, briskly.

â€œHelp it? why, I buys a gal, and if sheâ€™s got a young un to be sold, I jest walks up and puts my fist to her face, and says, â€˜Look here, now, if you give me one word out of your head, Iâ€™ll smash yer face in. I wonâ€™t hear one wordâ€”not the beginning of a word.â€™ I says to â€™em, â€˜This yer young unâ€™s mine, and not yourn, and youâ€™ve no kind oâ€™ business with it. Iâ€™m going to sell it, first chance; mind, you donâ€™t cut up none oâ€™ yer shines about it, or Iâ€™ll make ye wish yeâ€™d never been born.â€™ I tell ye, they sees it anâ€™t no play, when I gets hold. I makes â€™em as whist as fishes; and if one on â€™em begins and gives a yelp, why,â€”â€ and Mr. Loker brought down his fist with a thump that fully explained the hiatus.

â€œThat arâ€™s what ye may call emphasis,â€ said Marks, poking Haley in the side, and going into another small giggle. â€œAnâ€™t Tom peculiar? he! he! I say, Tom, I sâ€™pect you make â€™em understand, for all niggersâ€™ heads is woolly. They donâ€™t never have no doubt oâ€™ your meaning, Tom. If you anâ€™t the devil, Tom, you â€™s his twin brother, Iâ€™ll say that for ye!â€
Tom received the compliment with becoming modesty, and began to look as affable as was consistent, as John Bunyan says, â€œwith his doggish nature.â€

Haley, who had been imbibing very freely of the staple of the evening, began to feel a sensible elevation and enlargement of his moral faculties,â€”a phenomenon not unusual with gentlemen of a serious and reflective turn, under similar circumstances.

â€œWal, now, Tom,â€ he said, â€œye reâ€™lly is too bad, as I alâ€™ays have told ye; ye know, Tom, you and I used to talk over these yer matters down in Natchez, and I used to prove to ye that we made full as much, and was as well off for this yer world, by treatinâ€™ on â€™em well, besides keepinâ€™ a better chance for cominâ€™ in the kingdom at last, when wust comes to wust, and thar anâ€™t nothing else left to get, ye know.â€
â€œBoh!â€ said Tom, â€œdonâ€™t I know?â€”donâ€™t make me too sick with any yer stuff,â€”my stomach is a leetle riled now;â€ and Tom drank half a glass of raw brandy.

â€œI say,â€ said Haley, and leaning back in his chair and gesturing impressively, â€œIâ€™ll say this now, I alâ€™ays meant to drive my trade so as to make money on â€™t fust and foremost, as much as any man; but, then, trade anâ€™t everything, and money anâ€™t everything, â€™cause we â€™s all got souls. I donâ€™t care, now, who hears me say it,â€”and I think a cussed sight on it,â€”so I may as well come out with it. I bâ€™lieve in religion, and one of these days, when Iâ€™ve got matters tight and snug, I calculates to tend to my soul and them ar matters; and so whatâ€™s the use of doinâ€™ any more wickedness than â€™s reâ€™lly necessary?â€”it donâ€™t seem to me itâ€™s â€™t all prudent.â€

â€œTend to yer soul!â€ repeated Tom, contemptuously; â€œtake a bright lookout to find a soul in you,â€”save yourself any care on that score. If the devil sifts you through a hair sieve, he wonâ€™t find one.â€
â€œWhy, Tom, youâ€™re cross,â€ said Haley; â€œwhy canâ€™t ye take it pleasant, now, when a fellerâ€™s talking for your good?â€

â€œStop that ar jaw oâ€™ yourn, there,â€ said Tom, gruffly. â€œI can stand most any talk oâ€™ yourn but your pious talk,â€”that kills me right up. After all, whatâ€™s the odds between me and you? â€™Tanâ€™t that you care one bit more, or have a bit more feelinâ€™â€”itâ€™s clean, sheer, dog meanness, wanting to cheat the devil and save your own skin; donâ€™t I see through it? And your â€˜gettinâ€™ religion,â€™ as you call it, arter all, is too pâ€™isin mean for any crittur;â€”run up a bill with the devil all your life, and then sneak out when pay time comes! Bob!â€

â€œCome, come, gentlemen, I say; this isnâ€™t business,â€ said Marks. â€œThereâ€™s different ways, you know, of looking at all subjects. Mr. Haley is a very nice man, no doubt, and has his own conscience; and, Tom, you have your ways, and very good ones, too, Tom; but quarrelling, you know, wonâ€™t answer no kind of purpose. Letâ€™s go to business. Now, Mr. Haley, what is it?â€”you want us to undertake to catch this yer gal?â€
â€œThe galâ€™s no matter of mine,â€”sheâ€™s Shelbyâ€™s; itâ€™s only the boy. I was a fool for buying the monkey!â€
â€œYouâ€™re generally a fool!â€ said Tom, gruffly.

â€œCome, now, Loker, none of your huffs,â€ said Marks, licking his lips; â€œyou see, Mr. Haley â€™s a puttinâ€™ us in a way of a good job, I reckon; just hold stillâ€”these yer arrangements is my forte. This yer gal, Mr. Haley, how is she? what is she?â€
â€œWal! white and handsomeâ€”well brought up. Iâ€™d a gin Shelby eight hundred or a thousand, and then made well on her.â€

â€œWhite and handsomeâ€”well brought up!â€ said Marks, his sharp eyes, nose and mouth, all alive with enterprise. â€œLook here, now, Loker, a beautiful opening. Weâ€™ll do a business here on our own account;â€”we does the catchinâ€™; the boy, of course, goes to Mr. Haley,â€”we takes the gal to Orleans to speculate on. Anâ€™t it beautiful?â€
Tom, whose great heavy mouth had stood ajar during this communication, now suddenly snapped it together, as a big dog closes on a piece of meat, and seemed to be digesting the idea at his leisure.

â€œYe see,â€ said Marks to Haley, stirring his punch as he did so, â€œye see, we has justices convenient at all pâ€™ints along shore, that does up any little jobs in our line quite reasonable. Tom, he does the knockinâ€™ down and that ar; and I come in all dressed upâ€”shining bootsâ€”everything first chop, when the swearinâ€™ â€™s to be done. You oughter see, now,â€ said Marks, in a glow of professional pride, â€œhow I can tone it off. One day, Iâ€™m Mr. Twickem, from New Orleans; â€™nother day, Iâ€™m just come from my plantation on Pearl River, where I works seven hundred niggers; then, again, I come out a distant relation of Henry Clay, or some old cock in Kentuck. Talents is different, you know. Now, Tomâ€™s roarer when thereâ€™s any thumping or fighting to be done; but at lying he anâ€™t good, Tom anâ€™t,â€”ye see it donâ€™t come natural to him; but, Lord, if tharâ€™s a feller in the country that can swear to anything and everything, and put in all the circumstances and flourishes with a long face, and carry â€™t through better â€™n I can, why, Iâ€™d like to see him, thatâ€™s all! I bâ€™lieve my heart, I could get along and snake through, even if justices were more particular than they is. Sometimes I rather wish they was more particular; â€™t would be a heap more relishinâ€™ if they was,â€”more fun, yer know.â€

Tom Loker, who, as we have made it appear, was a man of slow thoughts and movements, here interrupted Marks by bringing his heavy fist down on the table, so as to make all ring again, â€œItâ€™ll do!â€ he said.
â€œLord bless ye, Tom, ye neednâ€™t break all the glasses!â€ said Marks; â€œsave your fist for time oâ€™ need.â€
â€œBut, gentlemen, anâ€™t I to come in for a share of the profits?â€ said Haley.
â€œAnâ€™t it enough we catch the boy for ye?â€ said Loker. â€œWhat do ye want?â€
â€œWal,â€ said Haley, â€œif I gives you the job, itâ€™s worth something,â€”say ten per cent. on the profits, expenses paid.â€

â€œNow,â€ said Loker, with a tremendous oath, and striking the table with his heavy fist, â€œdonâ€™t I know you, Dan Haley? Donâ€™t you think to come it over me! Suppose Marks and I have taken up the catchinâ€™ trade, jest to â€™commodate gentlemen like you, and get nothinâ€™ for ourselves?â€”Not by a long chalk! weâ€™ll have the gal out and out, and you keep quiet, or, ye see, weâ€™ll have both,â€”whatâ€™s to hinder? Hanâ€™t you showâ€™d us the game? Itâ€™s as free to us as you, I hope. If you or Shelby wants to chase us, look where the partridges was last year; if you find them or us, youâ€™re quite welcome.â€
â€œO, wal, certainly, jest let it go at that,â€ said Haley, alarmed; â€œyou catch the boy for the job;â€”you allers did trade far with me, Tom, and was up to yer word.â€

â€œYe know that,â€ said Tom; â€œI donâ€™t pretend none of your snivelling ways, but I wonâ€™t lie in my â€™counts with the devil himself. What I ses Iâ€™ll do, I will do,â€”you know that, Dan Haley.â€
â€œJes so, jes so,â€”I said so, Tom,â€ said Haley; â€œand if youâ€™d only promise to have the boy for me in a week, at any point youâ€™ll name, thatâ€™s all I want.â€

â€œBut it anâ€™t all I want, by a long jump,â€ said Tom. â€œYe donâ€™t think I did business with you, down in Natchez, for nothing, Haley; Iâ€™ve learned to hold an eel, when I catch him. Youâ€™ve got to fork over fifty dollars, flat down, or this child donâ€™t start a peg. I know yer.â€
â€œWhy, when you have a job in hand that may bring a clean profit of somewhere about a thousand or sixteen hundred, why, Tom, youâ€™re onreasonable,â€ said Haley.

â€œYes, and hasnâ€™t we business booked for five weeks to come,â€”all we can do? And suppose we leaves all, and goes to bush-whacking round arter yer young uns, and finally doesnâ€™t catch the gal,â€”and gals allers is the devil to catch,â€”whatâ€™s then? would you pay us a centâ€”would you? I think I see you a doinâ€™ itâ€”ugh! No, no; flap down your fifty. If we get the job, and it pays, Iâ€™ll hand it back; if we donâ€™t, itâ€™s for our trouble,â€”thatâ€™s far, anâ€™t it, Marks?â€

â€œCertainly, certainly,â€ said Marks, with a conciliatory tone; â€œitâ€™s only a retaining fee, you see,â€”he! he! he!â€”we lawyers, you know. Wal, we must all keep good-natured,â€”keep easy, yer know. Tomâ€™ll have the boy for yer, anywhere yeâ€™ll name; wonâ€™t ye, Tom?â€
â€œIf I find the young un, Iâ€™ll bring him on to Cincinnati, and leave him at Granny Belcherâ€™s, on the landing,â€ said Loker.

Marks had got from his pocket a greasy pocket-book, and taking a long paper from thence, he sat down, and fixing his keen black eyes on it, began mumbling over its contents: â€œBarnesâ€”Shelby Countyâ€”boy Jim, three hundred dollars for him, dead or alive.
â€œEdwardsâ€”Dick and Lucyâ€”man and wife, six hundred dollars; wench Polly and two childrenâ€”six hundred for her or her head.

â€œIâ€™m jest a runninâ€™ over our business, to see if we can take up this yer handily. Loker,â€ he said, after a pause, â€œwe must set Adams and Springer on the track of these yer; theyâ€™ve been booked some time.â€
â€œTheyâ€™ll charge too much,â€ said Tom.

â€œIâ€™ll manage that ar; they â€™s young in the business, and must spect to work cheap,â€ said Marks, as he continued to read. â€œTherâ€™s three on â€™em easy cases, â€™cause all youâ€™ve got to do is to shoot â€™em, or swear they is shot; they couldnâ€™t, of course, charge much for that. Them other cases,â€ he said, folding the paper, â€œwill bear puttinâ€™ off a spell. So now letâ€™s come to the particulars. Now, Mr. Haley, you saw this yer gal when she landed?â€
â€œTo be sure,â€”plain as I see you.â€
â€œAnd a man helpinâ€™ on her up the bank?â€ said Loker.
â€œTo be sure, I did.â€
â€œMost likely,â€ said Marks, â€œsheâ€™s took in somewhere; but where, â€™s a question. Tom, what do you say?â€
â€œWe must cross the river tonight, no mistake,â€ said Tom.
