â€œBut thereâ€™s no boat about,â€ said Marks. â€œThe ice is running awfully, Tom; anâ€™t it dangerous?â€
â€œDonâ€™no nothing â€™bout that,â€”only itâ€™s got to be done,â€ said Tom, decidedly.
â€œDear me,â€ said Marks, fidgeting, â€œitâ€™ll beâ€”I say,â€ he said, walking to the window, â€œitâ€™s dark as a wolfâ€™s mouth, and, Tomâ€”â€

â€œThe long and short is, youâ€™re scared, Marks; but I canâ€™t help that,â€”youâ€™ve got to go. Suppose you want to lie by a day or two, till the gal â€™s been carried on the underground line up to Sandusky or so, before you start.â€
â€œO, no; I anâ€™t a grain afraid,â€ said Marks, â€œonlyâ€”â€
â€œOnly what?â€ said Tom.
â€œWell, about the boat. Yer see there anâ€™t any boat.â€
â€œI heard the woman say there was one coming along this evening, and that a man was going to cross over in it. Neck or nothing, we must go with him,â€ said Tom.
â€œI sâ€™pose youâ€™ve got good dogs,â€ said Haley.
â€œFirst rate,â€ said Marks. â€œBut whatâ€™s the use? you hanâ€™t got nothinâ€™ oâ€™ hers to smell on.â€
â€œYes, I have,â€ said Haley, triumphantly. â€œHereâ€™s her shawl she left on the bed in her hurry; she left her bonnet, too.â€
â€œThat arâ€™s lucky,â€ said Loker; â€œfork over.â€
â€œThough the dogs might damage the gal, if they come on her unawars,â€ said Haley.
â€œThat arâ€™s a consideration,â€ said Marks. â€œOur dogs tore a feller half to pieces, once, down in Mobile, â€™fore we could get â€™em off.â€
â€œWell, ye see, for this sort thatâ€™s to be sold for their looks, that ar wonâ€™t answer, ye see,â€ said Haley.

â€œI do see,â€ said Marks. â€œBesides, if sheâ€™s got took in, â€™tanâ€™t no go, neither. Dogs is no â€™count in these yer up states where these critters gets carried; of course, ye canâ€™t get on their track. They only does down in plantations, where niggers, when they runs, has to do their own running, and donâ€™t get no help.â€
â€œWell,â€ said Loker, who had just stepped out to the bar to make some inquiries, â€œthey say the manâ€™s come with the boat; so, Marksâ€”â€

That worthy cast a rueful look at the comfortable quarters he was leaving, but slowly rose to obey. After exchanging a few words of further arrangement, Haley, with visible reluctance, handed over the fifty dollars to Tom, and the worthy trio separated for the night.

If any of our refined and Christian readers object to the society into which this scene introduces them, let us beg them to begin and conquer their prejudices in time. The catching business, we beg to remind them, is rising to the dignity of a lawful and patriotic profession. If all the broad land between the Mississippi and the Pacific becomes one great market for bodies and souls, and human property retains the locomotive tendencies of this nineteenth century, the trader and catcher may yet be among our aristocracy.
While this scene was going on at the tavern, Sam and Andy, in a state of high felicitation, pursued their way home.

Sam was in the highest possible feather, and expressed his exultation by all sorts of supernatural howls and ejaculations, by divers odd motions and contortions of his whole system. Sometimes he would sit backward, with his face to the horseâ€™s tail and sides, and then, with a whoop and a somerset, come right side up in his place again, and, drawing on a grave face, begin to lecture Andy in high-sounding tones for laughing and playing the fool. Anon, slapping his sides with his arms, he would burst forth in peals of laughter, that made the old woods ring as they passed. With all these evolutions, he contrived to keep the horses up to the top of their speed, until, between ten and eleven, their heels resounded on the gravel at the end of the balcony. Mrs. Shelby flew to the railings.
â€œIs that you, Sam? Where are they?â€
â€œMasâ€™r Haley â€™s a-restinâ€™ at the tavern; heâ€™s drefful fatigued, Missis.â€
â€œAnd Eliza, Sam?â€
â€œWal, sheâ€™s clar â€™cross Jordan. As a body may say, in the land oâ€™ Canaan.â€
â€œWhy, Sam, what do you mean?â€ said Mrs. Shelby, breathless, and almost faint, as the possible meaning of these words came over her.
â€œWal, Missis, de Lord he persarves his own. Lizyâ€™s done gone over the river into â€™Hio, as â€™markably as if de Lord took her over in a charrit of fire and two hosses.â€
Samâ€™s vein of piety was always uncommonly fervent in his mistressâ€™ presence; and he made great capital of scriptural figures and images.

â€œCome up here, Sam,â€ said Mr. Shelby, who had followed on to the verandah, â€œand tell your mistress what she wants. Come, come, Emily,â€ said he, passing his arm round her, â€œyou are cold and all in a shiver; you allow yourself to feel too much.â€
â€œFeel too much! Am not I a woman,â€”a mother? Are we not both responsible to God for this poor girl? My God! lay not this sin to our charge.â€
â€œWhat sin, Emily? You see yourself that we have only done what we were obliged to.â€
â€œThereâ€™s an awful feeling of guilt about it, though,â€ said Mrs. Shelby. â€œI canâ€™t reason it away.â€

â€œHere, Andy, you nigger, be alive!â€ called Sam, under the verandah; â€œtake these yer hosses to der barn; donâ€™t ye hear Masâ€™r a callinâ€™?â€ and Sam soon appeared, palm-leaf in hand, at the parlor door.
â€œNow, Sam, tell us distinctly how the matter was,â€ said Mr. Shelby. â€œWhere is Eliza, if you know?â€

â€œWal, Masâ€™r, I saw her, with my own eyes, a crossinâ€™ on the floatinâ€™ ice. She crossed most â€™markably; it wasnâ€™t no less nor a miracle; and I saw a man help her up the â€™Hio side, and then she was lost in the dusk.â€
â€œSam, I think this rather apocryphal,â€”this miracle. Crossing on floating ice isnâ€™t so easily done,â€ said Mr. Shelby.

â€œEasy! couldnâ€™t nobody a done it, without de Lord. Why, now,â€ said Sam, â€œâ€˜t was jist dis yer way. Masâ€™r Haley, and me, and Andy, we comes up to de little tavern by the river, and I rides a leetle ahead,â€”(Iâ€™s so zealous to be a cotchinâ€™ Lizy, that I couldnâ€™t hold in, no way),â€”and when I comes by the tavern winder, sure enough there she was, right in plain sight, and dey digginâ€™ on behind. Wal, I loses off my hat, and sings out nuff to raise the dead. Course Lizy she hars, and she dodges back, when Masâ€™r Haley he goes past the door; and then, I tell ye, she clared out de side door; she went down de river bank;â€”Masâ€™r Haley he seed her, and yelled out, and him, and me, and Andy, we took arter. Down she come to the river, and thar was the current running ten feet wide by the shore, and over tâ€™ other side ice a sawinâ€™ and a jiggling up and down, kinder as â€™t were a great island. We come right behind her, and I thought my soul heâ€™d got her sure enough,â€”when she gin sich a screech as I never hearn, and thar she was, clar over tâ€™ other side of the current, on the ice, and then on she went, a screeching and a jumpinâ€™,â€”the ice went crack! câ€™wallop! cracking! chunk! and she a boundinâ€™ like a buck! Lord, the spring that ar galâ€™s got in her anâ€™t common, Iâ€™m oâ€™ â€™pinion.â€
Mrs. Shelby sat perfectly silent, pale with excitement, while Sam told his story.
â€œGod be praised, she isnâ€™t dead!â€ she said; â€œbut where is the poor child now?â€

â€œDe Lord will pervide,â€ said Sam, rolling up his eyes piously. â€œAs Iâ€™ve been a sayinâ€™, dis yer â€™s a providence and no mistake, as Missis has allers been a instructinâ€™ on us. Tharâ€™s allers instruments ris up to do de Lordâ€™s will. Now, if â€™t hadnâ€™t been for me today, sheâ€™d a been took a dozen times. Warnâ€™t it I started off de hosses, dis yer morninâ€™ and kept â€™em chasinâ€™ till nigh dinner time? And didnâ€™t I car Masâ€™r Haley night five miles out of de road, dis evening, or else heâ€™d a come up with Lizy as easy as a dog arter a coon. These yer â€™s all providences.â€

â€œThey are a kind of providences that youâ€™ll have to be pretty sparing of, Master Sam. I allow no such practices with gentlemen on my place,â€ said Mr. Shelby, with as much sternness as he could command, under the circumstances.

Now, there is no more use in making believe be angry with a negro than with a child; both instinctively see the true state of the case, through all attempts to affect the contrary; and Sam was in no wise disheartened by this rebuke, though he assumed an air of doleful gravity, and stood with the corners of his mouth lowered in most penitential style.

â€œMasâ€™r quite right,â€”quite; it was ugly on me,â€”thereâ€™s no disputinâ€™ that ar; and of course Masâ€™r and Missis wouldnâ€™t encourage no such works. Iâ€™m sensible of dat ar; but a poor nigger like me â€™s â€™mazinâ€™ tempted to act ugly sometimes, when fellers will cut up such shines as dat ar Masâ€™r Haley; he anâ€™t no genâ€™lâ€™man no way; anybodyâ€™s been raised as Iâ€™ve been canâ€™t help a seeinâ€™ dat ar.â€

â€œWell, Sam,â€ said Mrs. Shelby, â€œas you appear to have a proper sense of your errors, you may go now and tell Aunt Chloe she may get you some of that cold ham that was left of dinner today. You and Andy must be hungry.â€
â€œMissis is a heap too good for us,â€ said Sam, making his bow with alacrity, and departing.

It will be perceived, as has been before intimated, that Master Sam had a native talent that might, undoubtedly, have raised him to eminence in political life,â€”a talent of making capital out of everything that turned up, to be invested for his own especial praise and glory; and having done up his piety and humility, as he trusted, to the satisfaction of the parlor, he clapped his palm-leaf on his head, with a sort of rakish, free-and-easy air, and proceeded to the dominions of Aunt Chloe, with the intention of flourishing largely in the kitchen.
â€œIâ€™ll speechify these yer niggers,â€ said Sam to himself, â€œnow Iâ€™ve got a chance. Lord, Iâ€™ll reel it off to make â€™em stare!â€

It must be observed that one of Samâ€™s especial delights had been to ride in attendance on his master to all kinds of political gatherings, where, roosted on some rail fence, or perched aloft in some tree, he would sit watching the orators, with the greatest apparent gusto, and then, descending among the various brethren of his own color, assembled on the same errand, he would edify and delight them with the most ludicrous burlesques and imitations, all delivered with the most imperturbable earnestness and solemnity; and though the auditors immediately about him were generally of his own color, it not infrequently happened that they were fringed pretty deeply with those of a fairer complexion, who listened, laughing and winking, to Samâ€™s great self-congratulation. In fact, Sam considered oratory as his vocation, and never let slip an opportunity of magnifying his office.

Now, between Sam and Aunt Chloe there had existed, from ancient times, a sort of chronic feud, or rather a decided coolness; but, as Sam was meditating something in the provision department, as the necessary and obvious foundation of his operations, he determined, on the present occasion, to be eminently conciliatory; for he well knew that although â€œMissisâ€™ ordersâ€ would undoubtedly be followed to the letter, yet he should gain a considerable deal by enlisting the spirit also. He therefore appeared before Aunt Chloe with a touchingly subdued, resigned expression, like one who has suffered immeasurable hardships in behalf of a persecuted fellow-creature,â€”enlarged upon the fact that Missis had directed him to come to Aunt Chloe for whatever might be wanting to make up the balance in his solids and fluids,â€”and thus unequivocally acknowledged her right and supremacy in the cooking department, and all thereto pertaining.

The thing took accordingly. No poor, simple, virtuous body was ever cajoled by the attentions of an electioneering politician with more ease than Aunt Chloe was won over by Master Samâ€™s suavities; and if he had been the prodigal son himself, he could not have been overwhelmed with more maternal bountifulness; and he soon found himself seated, happy and glorious, over a large tin pan, containing a sort of olla podrida of all that had appeared on the table for two or three days past. Savory morsels of ham, golden blocks of corn-cake, fragments of pie of every conceivable mathematical figure, chicken wings, gizzards, and drumsticks, all appeared in picturesque confusion; and Sam, as monarch of all he surveyed, sat with his palm-leaf cocked rejoicingly to one side, and patronizing Andy at his right hand.

The kitchen was full of all his compeers, who had hurried and crowded in, from the various cabins, to hear the termination of the dayâ€™s exploits. Now was Samâ€™s hour of glory. The story of the day was rehearsed, with all kinds of ornament and varnishing which might be necessary to heighten its effect; for Sam, like some of our fashionable dilettanti, never allowed a story to lose any of its gilding by passing through his hands. Roars of laughter attended the narration, and were taken up and prolonged by all the smaller fry, who were lying, in any quantity, about on the floor, or perched in every corner. In the height of the uproar and laughter, Sam, however, preserved an immovable gravity, only from time to time rolling his eyes up, and giving his auditors divers inexpressibly droll glances, without departing from the sententious elevation of his oratory.

â€œYer see, fellow-countrymen,â€ said Sam, elevating a turkeyâ€™s leg, with energy, â€œyer see, now what dis yer chile â€™s up ter, for fendinâ€™ yer all,â€”yes, all on yer. For him as tries to get one oâ€™ our people is as good as tryinâ€™ to get all; yer see the principle â€™s de same,â€”dat arâ€™s clar. And any one oâ€™ these yer drivers that comes smelling round arter any our people, why, heâ€™s got me in his way; Iâ€™m the feller heâ€™s got to set in with,â€”Iâ€™m the feller for yer all to come to, bredren,â€”Iâ€™ll stand up for yer rights,â€”Iâ€™ll fend â€™em to the last breath!â€
â€œWhy, but Sam, yer telled me, only this morninâ€™, that youâ€™d help this yer Masâ€™r to cotch Lizy; seems to me yer talk donâ€™t hang together,â€ said Andy.

â€œI tell you now, Andy,â€ said Sam, with awful superiority, â€œdonâ€™t yer be a talkinâ€™ â€™bout what yer donâ€™t know nothinâ€™ on; boys like you, Andy, means well, but they canâ€™t be spected to collusitate the great principles of action.â€
Andy looked rebuked, particularly by the hard word collusitate, which most of the youngerly members of the company seemed to consider as a settler in the case, while Sam proceeded.

â€œDat ar was conscience, Andy; when I thought of gwine arter Lizy, I railly spected Masâ€™r was sot dat way. When I found Missis was sot the contrar, dat ar was conscience more yet,â€”cause fellers allers gets more by stickinâ€™ to Missisâ€™ side,â€”so yer see I â€™s persistent either way, and sticks up to conscience, and holds on to principles. Yes, principles,â€ said Sam, giving an enthusiastic toss to a chickenâ€™s neck,â€”â€œwhatâ€™s principles good for, if we isnâ€™t persistent, I wanter know? Thar, Andy, you may have dat ar bone,â€”tanâ€™t picked quite clean.â€
Samâ€™s audience hanging on his words with open mouth, he could not but proceed.

â€œDis yer matter â€™bout persistence, feller-niggers,â€ said Sam, with the air of one entering into an abstruse subject, â€œdis yer â€™sistency â€™s a thing what anâ€™t seed into very clar, by most anybody. Now, yer see, when a feller stands up for a thing one day and night, de contrar de next, folks ses (and natâ€™rally enough dey ses), why he anâ€™t persistent,â€”hand me dat ar bit oâ€™ corn-cake, Andy. But letâ€™s look inter it. I hope the genâ€™lmen and der fair sex will scuse my usinâ€™ an orâ€™nary sort oâ€™ â€™parison. Here! Iâ€™m a trying to get top oâ€™ der hay. Wal, I puts up my larder dis yer side; â€™tanâ€™t no go;â€”den, cause I donâ€™t try dere no more, but puts my larder right de contrar side, anâ€™t I persistent? Iâ€™m persistent in wantinâ€™ to get up which ary side my larder is; donâ€™t you see, all on yer?â€

â€œItâ€™s the only thing ye ever was persistent in, Lord knows!â€ muttered Aunt Chloe, who was getting rather restive; the merriment of the evening being to her somewhat after the Scripture comparison,â€”like â€œvinegar upon nitre.â€

â€œYes, indeed!â€ said Sam, rising, full of supper and glory, for a closing effort. â€œYes, my feller-citizens and ladies of de other sex in general, I has principles,â€”Iâ€™m proud to â€™oon â€™em,â€”they â€™s perquisite to dese yer times, and ter all times. I has principles, and I sticks to â€™em like forty,â€”jest anything that I thinks is principle, I goes in to â€™t;â€”I wouldnâ€™t mind if dey burnt me â€™live,â€”Iâ€™d walk right up to de stake, I would, and say, here I comes to shed my last blood fur my principles, fur my country, fur de genâ€™l interests of society.â€

â€œWell,â€ said Aunt Chloe, â€œone oâ€™ yer principles will have to be to get to bed some time tonight, and not be a keepinâ€™ everybody up till morninâ€™; now, every one of you young uns that donâ€™t want to be cracked, had better be scase, mighty sudden.â€
â€œNiggers! all on yer,â€ said Sam, waving his palm-leaf with benignity, â€œI give yer my blessinâ€™; go to bed now, and be good boys.â€
And, with this pathetic benediction, the assembly dispersed.

div.head:
Chapter IX
In Which It Appears That a Senator Is But a Man
div.p: The light of the cheerful fire shone on the rug and carpet of a cosey parlor, and glittered on the sides of the tea-cups and well-brightened tea-pot, as Senator Bird was drawing off his boots, preparatory to inserting his feet in a pair of new handsome slippers, which his wife had been working for him while away on his senatorial tour. Mrs. Bird, looking the very picture of delight, was superintending the arrangements of the table, ever and anon mingling admonitory remarks to a number of frolicsome juveniles, who were effervescing in all those modes of untold gambol and mischief that have astonished mothers ever since the flood.

â€œTom, let the door-knob alone,â€”thereâ€™s a man! Mary! Mary! donâ€™t pull the catâ€™s tail,â€”poor pussy! Jim, you mustnâ€™t climb on that table,â€”no, no!â€”You donâ€™t know, my dear, what a surprise it is to us all, to see you here tonight!â€ said she, at last, when she found a space to say something to her husband.
â€œYes, yes, I thought Iâ€™d just make a run down, spend the night, and have a little comfort at home. Iâ€™m tired to death, and my head aches!â€
Mrs. Bird cast a glance at a camphor-bottle, which stood in the half-open closet, and appeared to meditate an approach to it, but her husband interposed.
â€œNo, no, Mary, no doctoring! a cup of your good hot tea, and some of our good home living, is what I want. Itâ€™s a tiresome business, this legislating!â€
And the senator smiled, as if he rather liked the idea of considering himself a sacrifice to his country.
â€œWell,â€ said his wife, after the business of the tea-table was getting rather slack, â€œand what have they been doing in the Senate?â€

Now, it was a very unusual thing for gentle little Mrs. Bird ever to trouble her head with what was going on in the house of the state, very wisely considering that she had enough to do to mind her own. Mr. Bird, therefore, opened his eyes in surprise, and said,
â€œNot very much of importance.â€

â€œWell; but is it true that they have been passing a law forbidding people to give meat and drink to those poor colored folks that come along? I heard they were talking of some such law, but I didnâ€™t think any Christian legislature would pass it!â€
â€œWhy, Mary, you are getting to be a politician, all at once.â€
â€œNo, nonsense! I wouldnâ€™t give a fig for all your politics, generally, but I think this is something downright cruel and unchristian. I hope, my dear, no such law has been passed.â€

â€œThere has been a law passed forbidding people to help off the slaves that come over from Kentucky, my dear; so much of that thing has been done by these reckless Abolitionists, that our brethren in Kentucky are very strongly excited, and it seems necessary, and no more than Christian and kind, that something should be done by our state to quiet the excitement.â€

â€œAnd what is the law? It donâ€™t forbid us to shelter those poor creatures a night, does it, and to give â€™em something comfortable to eat, and a few old clothes, and send them quietly about their business?â€
â€œWhy, yes, my dear; that would be aiding and abetting, you know.â€

Mrs. Bird was a timid, blushing little woman, of about four feet in height, and with mild blue eyes, and a peach-blow complexion, and the gentlest, sweetest voice in the world;â€”as for courage, a moderate-sized cock-turkey had been known to put her to rout at the very first gobble, and a stout house-dog, of moderate capacity, would bring her into subjection merely by a show of his teeth. Her husband and children were her entire world, and in these she ruled more by entreaty and persuasion than by command or argument. There was only one thing that was capable of arousing her, and that provocation came in on the side of her unusually gentle and sympathetic nature;â€”anything in the shape of cruelty would throw her into a passion, which was the more alarming and inexplicable in proportion to the general softness of her nature. Generally the most indulgent and easy to be entreated of all mothers, still her boys had a very reverent remembrance of a most vehement chastisement she once bestowed on them, because she found them leagued with several graceless boys of the neighborhood, stoning a defenceless kitten.

â€œIâ€™ll tell you what,â€ Master Bill used to say, â€œI was scared that time. Mother came at me so that I thought she was crazy, and I was whipped and tumbled off to bed, without any supper, before I could get over wondering what had come about; and, after that, I heard mother crying outside the door, which made me feel worse than all the rest. Iâ€™ll tell you what,â€ heâ€™d say, â€œwe boys never stoned another kitten!â€

On the present occasion, Mrs. Bird rose quickly, with very red cheeks, which quite improved her general appearance, and walked up to her husband, with quite a resolute air, and said, in a determined tone,
â€œNow, John, I want to know if you think such a law as that is right and Christian?â€
â€œYou wonâ€™t shoot me, now, Mary, if I say I do!â€
â€œI never could have thought it of you, John; you didnâ€™t vote for it?â€
â€œEven so, my fair politician.â€

â€œYou ought to be ashamed, John! Poor, homeless, houseless creatures! Itâ€™s a shameful, wicked, abominable law, and Iâ€™ll break it, for one, the first time I get a chance; and I hope I shall have a chance, I do! Things have got to a pretty pass, if a woman canâ€™t give a warm supper and a bed to poor, starving creatures, just because they are slaves, and have been abused and oppressed all their lives, poor things!â€

â€œBut, Mary, just listen to me. Your feelings are all quite right, dear, and interesting, and I love you for them; but, then, dear, we mustnâ€™t suffer our feelings to run away with our judgment; you must consider itâ€™s a matter of private feeling,â€”there are great public interests involved,â€”there is such a state of public agitation rising, that we must put aside our private feelings.â€

â€œNow, John, I donâ€™t know anything about politics, but I can read my Bible; and there I see that I must feed the hungry, clothe the naked, and comfort the desolate; and that Bible I mean to follow.â€
â€œBut in cases where your doing so would involve a great public evilâ€”â€
â€œObeying God never brings on public evils. I know it canâ€™t. Itâ€™s always safest, all round, to do as He bids us.
â€œNow, listen to me, Mary, and I can state to you a very clear argument, to showâ€”â€

â€œO, nonsense, John! you can talk all night, but you wouldnâ€™t do it. I put it to you, John,â€”would you now turn away a poor, shivering, hungry creature from your door, because he was a runaway? Would you, now?â€

Now, if the truth must be told, our senator had the misfortune to be a man who had a particularly humane and accessible nature, and turning away anybody that was in trouble never had been his forte; and what was worse for him in this particular pinch of the argument was, that his wife knew it, and, of course was making an assault on rather an indefensible point. So he had recourse to the usual means of gaining time for such cases made and provided; he said â€œahem,â€ and coughed several times, took out his pocket-handkerchief, and began to wipe his glasses. Mrs. Bird, seeing the defenceless condition of the enemyâ€™s territory, had no more conscience than to push her advantage.

â€œI should like to see you doing that, Johnâ€”I really should! Turning a woman out of doors in a snowstorm, for instance; or may be youâ€™d take her up and put her in jail, wouldnâ€™t you? You would make a great hand at that!â€
â€œOf course, it would be a very painful duty,â€ began Mr. Bird, in a moderate tone.

â€œDuty, John! donâ€™t use that word! You know it isnâ€™t a dutyâ€”it canâ€™t be a duty! If folks want to keep their slaves from running away, let â€™em treat â€™em well,â€”thatâ€™s my doctrine. If I had slaves (as I hope I never shall have), Iâ€™d risk their wanting to run away from me, or you either, John. I tell you folks donâ€™t run away when they are happy; and when they do run, poor creatures! they suffer enough with cold and hunger and fear, without everybodyâ€™s turning against them; and, law or no law, I never will, so help me God!â€
â€œMary! Mary! My dear, let me reason with you.â€

â€œI hate reasoning, John,â€”especially reasoning on such subjects. Thereâ€™s a way you political folks have of coming round and round a plain right thing; and you donâ€™t believe in it yourselves, when it comes to practice. I know you well enough, John. You donâ€™t believe itâ€™s right any more than I do; and you wouldnâ€™t do it any sooner than I.â€

At this critical juncture, old Cudjoe, the black man-of-all-work, put his head in at the door, and wished â€œMissis would come into the kitchen;â€ and our senator, tolerably relieved, looked after his little wife with a whimsical mixture of amusement and vexation, and, seating himself in the arm-chair, began to read the papers.
After a moment, his wifeâ€™s voice was heard at the door, in a quick, earnest tone,â€”â€œJohn! John! I do wish youâ€™d come here, a moment.â€

He laid down his paper, and went into the kitchen, and started, quite amazed at the sight that presented itself:â€”A young and slender woman, with garments torn and frozen, with one shoe gone, and the stocking torn away from the cut and bleeding foot, was laid back in a deadly swoon upon two chairs. There was the impress of the despised race on her face, yet none could help feeling its mournful and pathetic beauty, while its stony sharpness, its cold, fixed, deathly aspect, struck a solemn chill over him. He drew his breath short, and stood in silence. His wife, and their only colored domestic, old Aunt Dinah, were busily engaged in restorative measures; while old Cudjoe had got the boy on his knee, and was busy pulling off his shoes and stockings, and chafing his little cold feet.

â€œSure, now, if she anâ€™t a sight to behold!â€ said old Dinah, compassionately; â€œâ€˜pears like â€™t was the heat that made her faint. She was tolâ€™able peart when she cum in, and asked if she couldnâ€™t warm herself here a spell; and I was just a-askinâ€™ her where she cum from, and she fainted right down. Never done much hard work, guess, by the looks of her hands.â€

â€œPoor creature!â€ said Mrs. Bird, compassionately, as the woman slowly unclosed her large, dark eyes, and looked vacantly at her. Suddenly an expression of agony crossed her face, and she sprang up, saying, â€œO, my Harry! Have they got him?â€
The boy, at this, jumped from Cudjoeâ€™s knee, and running to her side put up his arms. â€œO, heâ€™s here! heâ€™s here!â€ she exclaimed.
â€œO, maâ€™am!â€ said she, wildly, to Mrs. Bird, â€œdo protect us! donâ€™t let them get him!â€
â€œNobody shall hurt you here, poor woman,â€ said Mrs. Bird, encouragingly. â€œYou are safe; donâ€™t be afraid.â€
â€œGod bless you!â€ said the woman, covering her face and sobbing; while the little boy, seeing her crying, tried to get into her lap.

With many gentle and womanly offices, which none knew better how to render than Mrs. Bird, the poor woman was, in time, rendered more calm. A temporary bed was provided for her on the settle, near the fire; and, after a short time, she fell into a heavy slumber, with the child, who seemed no less weary, soundly sleeping on her arm; for the mother resisted, with nervous anxiety, the kindest attempts to take him from her; and, even in sleep, her arm encircled him with an unrelaxing clasp, as if she could not even then be beguiled of her vigilant hold.

Mr. and Mrs. Bird had gone back to the parlor, where, strange as it may appear, no reference was made, on either side, to the preceding conversation; but Mrs. Bird busied herself with her knitting-work, and Mr. Bird pretended to be reading the paper.
â€œI wonder who and what she is!â€ said Mr. Bird, at last, as he laid it down.
â€œWhen she wakes up and feels a little rested, we will see,â€ said Mrs. Bird.
â€œI say, wife!â€ said Mr. Bird after musing in silence over his newspaper.
â€œWell, dear!â€
â€œShe couldnâ€™t wear one of your gowns, could she, by any letting down, or such matter? She seems to be rather larger than you are.â€
A quite perceptible smile glimmered on Mrs. Birdâ€™s face, as she answered, â€œWeâ€™ll see.â€
Another pause, and Mr. Bird again broke out,
â€œI say, wife!â€
â€œWell! What now?â€
â€œWhy, thereâ€™s that old bombazin cloak, that you keep on purpose to put over me when I take my afternoonâ€™s nap; you might as well give her that,â€”she needs clothes.â€
At this instant, Dinah looked in to say that the woman was awake, and wanted to see Missis.
Mr. and Mrs. Bird went into the kitchen, followed by the two eldest boys, the smaller fry having, by this time, been safely disposed of in bed.
The woman was now sitting up on the settle, by the fire. She was looking steadily into the blaze, with a calm, heart-broken expression, very different from her former agitated wildness.
â€œDid you want me?â€ said Mrs. Bird, in gentle tones. â€œI hope you feel better now, poor woman!â€
A long-drawn, shivering sigh was the only answer; but she lifted her dark eyes, and fixed them on her with such a forlorn and imploring expression, that the tears came into the little womanâ€™s eyes.
â€œYou neednâ€™t be afraid of anything; we are friends here, poor woman! Tell me where you came from, and what you want,â€ said she.
â€œI came from Kentucky,â€ said the woman.
â€œWhen?â€ said Mr. Bird, taking up the interogatory.
â€œTonight.â€
â€œHow did you come?â€
â€œI crossed on the ice.â€
â€œCrossed on the ice!â€ said every one present.
â€œYes,â€ said the woman, slowly, â€œI did. God helping me, I crossed on the ice; for they were behind meâ€”right behindâ€”and there was no other way!â€
â€œLaw, Missis,â€ said Cudjoe, â€œthe ice is all in broken-up blocks, a swinging and a tetering up and down in the water!â€

â€œI know it wasâ€”I know it!â€ said she, wildly; â€œbut I did it! I wouldnâ€™t have thought I could,â€”I didnâ€™t think I should get over, but I didnâ€™t care! I could but die, if I didnâ€™t. The Lord helped me; nobody knows how much the Lord can help â€™em, till they try,â€ said the woman, with a flashing eye.
â€œWere you a slave?â€ said Mr. Bird.
â€œYes, sir; I belonged to a man in Kentucky.â€
â€œWas he unkind to you?â€
â€œNo, sir; he was a good master.â€
â€œAnd was your mistress unkind to you?â€
â€œNo, sirâ€”no! my mistress was always good to me.â€
â€œWhat could induce you to leave a good home, then, and run away, and go through such dangers?â€
The woman looked up at Mrs. Bird, with a keen, scrutinizing glance, and it did not escape her that she was dressed in deep mourning.
â€œMaâ€™am,â€ she said, suddenly, â€œhave you ever lost a child?â€
The question was unexpected, and it was thrust on a new wound; for it was only a month since a darling child of the family had been laid in the grave.
Mr. Bird turned around and walked to the window, and Mrs. Bird burst into tears; but, recovering her voice, she said,
â€œWhy do you ask that? I have lost a little one.â€

â€œThen you will feel for me. I have lost two, one after another,â€”left â€™em buried there when I came away; and I had only this one left. I never slept a night without him; he was all I had. He was my comfort and pride, day and night; and, maâ€™am, they were going to take him away from me,â€”to sell him,â€”sell him down south, maâ€™am, to go all alone,â€”a baby that had never been away from his mother in his life! I couldnâ€™t stand it, maâ€™am. I knew I never should be good for anything, if they did; and when I knew the papers the papers were signed, and he was sold, I took him and came off in the night; and they chased me,â€”the man that bought him, and some of Masâ€™râ€™s folks,â€”and they were coming down right behind me, and I heard â€™em. I jumped right on to the ice; and how I got across, I donâ€™t know,â€”but, first I knew, a man was helping me up the bank.â€
The woman did not sob nor weep. She had gone to a place where tears are dry; but every one around her was, in some way characteristic of themselves, showing signs of hearty sympathy.

The two little boys, after a desperate rummaging in their pockets, in search of those pocket-handkerchiefs which mothers know are never to be found there, had thrown themselves disconsolately into the skirts of their motherâ€™s gown, where they were sobbing, and wiping their eyes and noses, to their heartsâ€™ content;â€”Mrs. Bird had her face fairly hidden in her pocket-handkerchief; and old Dinah, with tears streaming down her black, honest face, was ejaculating, â€œLord have mercy on us!â€ with all the fervor of a camp-meeting;â€”while old Cudjoe, rubbing his eyes very hard with his cuffs, and making a most uncommon variety of wry faces, occasionally responded in the same key, with great fervor. Our senator was a statesman, and of course could not be expected to cry, like other mortals; and so he turned his back to the company, and looked out of the window, and seemed particularly busy in clearing his throat and wiping his spectacle-glasses, occasionally blowing his nose in a manner that was calculated to excite suspicion, had any one been in a state to observe critically.
â€œHow came you to tell me you had a kind master?â€ he suddenly exclaimed, gulping down very resolutely some kind of rising in his throat, and turning suddenly round upon the woman.

â€œBecause he was a kind master; Iâ€™ll say that of him, any way;â€”and my mistress was kind; but they couldnâ€™t help themselves. They were owing money; and there was some way, I canâ€™t tell how, that a man had a hold on them, and they were obliged to give him his will. I listened, and heard him telling mistress that, and she begging and pleading for me,â€”and he told her he couldnâ€™t help himself, and that the papers were all drawn;â€”and then it was I took him and left my home, and came away. I knew â€™t was no use of my trying to live, if they did it; for â€™t â€™pears like this child is all I have.â€
â€œHave you no husband?â€

â€œYes, but he belongs to another man. His master is real hard to him, and wonâ€™t let him come to see me, hardly ever; and heâ€™s grown harder and harder upon us, and he threatens to sell him down south;â€”itâ€™s like Iâ€™ll never see him again!â€

The quiet tone in which the woman pronounced these words might have led a superficial observer to think that she was entirely apathetic; but there was a calm, settled depth of anguish in her large, dark eye, that spoke of something far otherwise.
â€œAnd where do you mean to go, my poor woman?â€ said Mrs. Bird.
â€œTo Canada, if I only knew where that was. Is it very far off, is Canada?â€ said she, looking up, with a simple, confiding air, to Mrs. Birdâ€™s face.
â€œPoor thing!â€ said Mrs. Bird, involuntarily.
â€œIs â€™t a very great way off, think?â€ said the woman, earnestly.

â€œMuch further than you think, poor child!â€ said Mrs. Bird; â€œbut we will try to think what can be done for you. Here, Dinah, make her up a bed in your own room, close by the kitchen, and Iâ€™ll think what to do for her in the morning. Meanwhile, never fear, poor woman; put your trust in God; he will protect you.â€

Mrs. Bird and her husband reentered the parlor. She sat down in her little rocking-chair before the fire, swaying thoughtfully to and fro. Mr. Bird strode up and down the room, grumbling to himself, â€œPish! pshaw! confounded awkward business!â€ At length, striding up to his wife, he said,

â€œI say, wife, sheâ€™ll have to get away from here, this very night. That fellow will be down on the scent bright and early tomorrow morning: if â€™t was only the woman, she could lie quiet till it was over; but that little chap canâ€™t be kept still by a troop of horse and foot, Iâ€™ll warrant me; heâ€™ll bring it all out, popping his head out of some window or door. A pretty kettle of fish it would be for me, too, to be caught with them both here, just now! No; theyâ€™ll have to be got off tonight.â€
â€œTonight! How is it possible?â€”where to?â€

â€œWell, I know pretty well where to,â€ said the senator, beginning to put on his boots, with a reflective air; and, stopping when his leg was half in, he embraced his knee with both hands, and seemed to go off in deep meditation.

â€œItâ€™s a confounded awkward, ugly business,â€ said he, at last, beginning to tug at his boot-straps again, â€œand thatâ€™s a fact!â€ After one boot was fairly on, the senator sat with the other in his hand, profoundly studying the figure of the carpet. â€œIt will have to be done, though, for aught I see,â€”hang it all!â€ and he drew the other boot anxiously on, and looked out of the window.

Now, little Mrs. Bird was a discreet woman,â€”a woman who never in her life said, â€œI told you so!â€ and, on the present occasion, though pretty well aware of the shape her husbandâ€™s meditations were taking, she very prudently forbore to meddle with them, only sat very quietly in her chair, and looked quite ready to hear her liege lordâ€™s intentions, when he should think proper to utter them.

â€œYou see,â€ he said, â€œthereâ€™s my old client, Van Trompe, has come over from Kentucky, and set all his slaves free; and he has bought a place seven miles up the creek, here, back in the woods, where nobody goes, unless they go on purpose; and itâ€™s a place that isnâ€™t found in a hurry. There sheâ€™d be safe enough; but the plague of the thing is, nobody could drive a carriage there tonight, but me.â€
â€œWhy not? Cudjoe is an excellent driver.â€

â€œAy, ay, but here it is. The creek has to be crossed twice; and the second crossing is quite dangerous, unless one knows it as I do. I have crossed it a hundred times on horseback, and know exactly the turns to take. And so, you see, thereâ€™s no help for it. Cudjoe must put in the horses, as quietly as may be, about twelve oâ€™clock, and Iâ€™ll take her over; and then, to give color to the matter, he must carry me on to the next tavern to take the stage for Columbus, that comes by about three or four, and so it will look as if I had had the carriage only for that. I shall get into business bright and early in the morning. But Iâ€™m thinking I shall feel rather cheap there, after all thatâ€™s been said and done; but, hang it, I canâ€™t help it!â€

â€œYour heart is better than your head, in this case, John,â€ said the wife, laying her little white hand on his. â€œCould I ever have loved you, had I not known you better than you know yourself?â€ And the little woman looked so handsome, with the tears sparkling in her eyes, that the senator thought he must be a decidedly clever fellow, to get such a pretty creature into such a passionate admiration of him; and so, what could he do but walk off soberly, to see about the carriage. At the door, however, he stopped a moment, and then coming back, he said, with some hesitation.
â€œMary, I donâ€™t know how youâ€™d feel about it, but thereâ€™s that drawer full of thingsâ€”ofâ€”ofâ€”poor little Henryâ€™s.â€ So saying, he turned quickly on his heel, and shut the door after him.

His wife opened the little bed-room door adjoining her room and, taking the candle, set it down on the top of a bureau there; then from a small recess she took a key, and put it thoughtfully in the lock of a drawer, and made a sudden pause, while two boys, who, boy like, had followed close on her heels, stood looking, with silent, significant glances, at their mother. And oh! mother that reads this, has there never been in your house a drawer, or a closet, the opening of which has been to you like the opening again of a little grave? Ah! happy mother that you are, if it has not been so.

Mrs. Bird slowly opened the drawer. There were little coats of many a form and pattern, piles of aprons, and rows of small stockings; and even a pair of little shoes, worn and rubbed at the toes, were peeping from the folds of a paper. There was a toy horse and wagon, a top, a ball,â€”memorials gathered with many a tear and many a heart-break! She sat down by the drawer, and, leaning her head on her hands over it, wept till the tears fell through her fingers into the drawer; then suddenly raising her head, she began, with nervous haste, selecting the plainest and most substantial articles, and gathering them into a bundle.
â€œMamma,â€ said one of the boys, gently touching her arm, â€œyou going to give away those things?â€

â€œMy dear boys,â€ she said, softly and earnestly, â€œif our dear, loving little Henry looks down from heaven, he would be glad to have us do this. I could not find it in my heart to give them away to any common personâ€”to anybody that was happy; but I give them to a mother more heart-broken and sorrowful than I am; and I hope God will send his blessings with them!â€

There are in this world blessed souls, whose sorrows all spring up into joys for others; whose earthly hopes, laid in the grave with many tears, are the seed from which spring healing flowers and balm for the desolate and the distressed. Among such was the delicate woman who sits there by the lamp, dropping slow tears, while she prepares the memorials of her own lost one for the outcast wanderer.

After a while, Mrs. Bird opened a wardrobe, and, taking from thence a plain, serviceable dress or two, she sat down busily to her work-table, and, with needle, scissors, and thimble, at hand, quietly commenced the â€œletting downâ€ process which her husband had recommended, and continued busily at it till the old clock in the corner struck twelve, and she heard the low rattling of wheels at the door.
â€œMary,â€ said her husband, coming in, with his overcoat in his hand, â€œyou must wake her up now; we must be off.â€

Mrs. Bird hastily deposited the various articles she had collected in a small plain trunk, and locking it, desired her husband to see it in the carriage, and then proceeded to call the woman. Soon, arrayed in a cloak, bonnet, and shawl, that had belonged to her benefactress, she appeared at the door with her child in her arms. Mr. Bird hurried her into the carriage, and Mrs. Bird pressed on after her to the carriage steps. Eliza leaned out of the carriage, and put out her hand,â€”a hand as soft and beautiful as was given in return. She fixed her large, dark eyes, full of earnest meaning, on Mrs. Birdâ€™s face, and seemed going to speak. Her lips moved,â€”she tried once or twice, but there was no sound,â€”and pointing upward, with a look never to be forgotten, she fell back in the seat, and covered her face. The door was shut, and the carriage drove on.

What a situation, now, for a patriotic senator, that had been all the week before spurring up the legislature of his native state to pass more stringent resolutions against escaping fugitives, their harborers and abettors!

Our good senator in his native state had not been exceeded by any of his brethren at Washington, in the sort of eloquence which has won for them immortal renown! How sublimely he had sat with his hands in his pockets, and scouted all sentimental weakness of those who would put the welfare of a few miserable fugitives before great state interests!

He was as bold as a lion about it, and â€œmightily convincedâ€ not only himself, but everybody that heard him;â€”but then his idea of a fugitive was only an idea of the letters that spell the word,â€”or at the most, the image of a little newspaper picture of a man with a stick and bundle with â€œRan away from the subscriberâ€ under it. The magic of the real presence of distress,â€”the imploring human eye, the frail, trembling human hand, the despairing appeal of helpless agony,â€”these he had never tried. He had never thought that a fugitive might be a hapless mother, a defenceless child,â€”like that one which was now wearing his lost boyâ€™s little well-known cap; and so, as our poor senator was not stone or steel,â€”as he was a man, and a downright noble-hearted one, too,â€”he was, as everybody must see, in a sad case for his patriotism. And you need not exult over him, good brother of the Southern States; for we have some inklings that many of you, under similar circumstances, would not do much better. We have reason to know, in Kentucky, as in Mississippi, are noble and generous hearts, to whom never was tale of suffering told in vain. Ah, good brother! is it fair for you to expect of us services which your own brave, honorable heart would not allow you to render, were you in our place?

Be that as it may, if our good senator was a political sinner, he was in a fair way to expiate it by his nightâ€™s penance. There had been a long continuous period of rainy weather, and the soft, rich earth of Ohio, as every one knows, is admirably suited to the manufacture of mudâ€”and the road was an Ohio railroad of the good old times.
â€œAnd pray, what sort of a road may that be?â€ says some eastern traveller, who has been accustomed to connect no ideas with a railroad, but those of smoothness or speed.

Know, then, innocent eastern friend, that in benighted regions of the west, where the mud is of unfathomable and sublime depth, roads are made of round rough logs, arranged transversely side by side, and coated over in their pristine freshness with earth, turf, and whatsoever may come to hand, and then the rejoicing native calleth it a road, and straightway essayeth to ride thereupon. In process of time, the rains wash off all the turf and grass aforesaid, move the logs hither and thither, in picturesque positions, up, down and crosswise, with divers chasms and ruts of black mud intervening.

Over such a road as this our senator went stumbling along, making moral reflections as continuously as under the circumstances could be expected,â€”the carriage proceeding along much as follows,â€”bump! bump! bump! slush! down in the mud!â€”the senator, woman and child, reversing their positions so suddenly as to come, without any very accurate adjustment, against the windows of the down-hill side. Carriage sticks fast, while Cudjoe on the outside is heard making a great muster among the horses. After various ineffectual pullings and twitchings, just as the senator is losing all patience, the carriage suddenly rights itself with a bounce,â€”two front wheels go down into another abyss, and senator, woman, and child, all tumble promiscuously on to the front seat,â€”senatorâ€™s hat is jammed over his eyes and nose quite unceremoniously, and he considers himself fairly extinguished;â€”child cries, and Cudjoe on the outside delivers animated addresses to the horses, who are kicking, and floundering, and straining under repeated cracks of the whip. Carriage springs up, with another bounce,â€”down go the hind wheels,â€”senator, woman, and child, fly over on to the back seat, his elbows encountering her bonnet, and both her feet being jammed into his hat, which flies off in the concussion. After a few moments the â€œsloughâ€ is passed, and the horses stop, panting;â€”the senator finds his hat, the woman straightens her bonnet and hushes her child, and they brace themselves for what is yet to come.

For a while only the continuous bump! bump! intermingled, just by way of variety, with divers side plunges and compound shakes; and they begin to flatter themselves that they are not so badly off, after all. At last, with a square plunge, which puts all on to their feet and then down into their seats with incredible quickness, the carriage stops,â€”and, after much outside commotion, Cudjoe appears at the door.
â€œPlease, sir, itâ€™s powerful bad spot, thisâ€™ yer. I donâ€™t know how weâ€™s to get clar out. Iâ€™m a thinkinâ€™ weâ€™ll have to be a gettinâ€™ rails.â€

The senator despairingly steps out, picking gingerly for some firm foothold; down goes one foot an immeasurable depth,â€”he tries to pull it up, loses his balance, and tumbles over into the mud, and is fished out, in a very despairing condition, by Cudjoe.

But we forbear, out of sympathy to our readersâ€™ bones. Western travellers, who have beguiled the midnight hour in the interesting process of pulling down rail fences, to pry their carriages out of mud holes, will have a respectful and mournful sympathy with our unfortunate hero. We beg them to drop a silent tear, and pass on.
It was full late in the night when the carriage emerged, dripping and bespattered, out of the creek, and stood at the door of a large farmhouse.

It took no inconsiderable perseverance to arouse the inmates; but at last the respectable proprietor appeared, and undid the door. He was a great, tall, bristling Orson of a fellow, full six feet and some inches in his stockings, and arrayed in a red flannel hunting-shirt. A very heavy mat of sandy hair, in a decidedly tousled condition, and a beard of some daysâ€™ growth, gave the worthy man an appearance, to say the least, not particularly prepossessing. He stood for a few minutes holding the candle aloft, and blinking on our travellers with a dismal and mystified expression that was truly ludicrous. It cost some effort of our senator to induce him to comprehend the case fully; and while he is doing his best at that, we shall give him a little introduction to our readers.

Honest old John Van Trompe was once quite a considerable land-owner and slave-owner in the State of Kentucky. Having â€œnothing of the bear about him but the skin,â€ and being gifted by nature with a great, honest, just heart, quite equal to his gigantic frame, he had been for some years witnessing with repressed uneasiness the workings of a system equally bad for oppressor and oppressed. At last, one day, Johnâ€™s great heart had swelled altogether too big to wear his bonds any longer; so he just took his pocket-book out of his desk, and went over into Ohio, and bought a quarter of a township of good, rich land, made out free papers for all his people,â€”men, women, and children,â€”packed them up in wagons, and sent them off to settle down; and then honest John turned his face up the creek, and sat quietly down on a snug, retired farm, to enjoy his conscience and his reflections.
â€œAre you the man that will shelter a poor woman and child from slave-catchers?â€ said the senator, explicitly.
â€œI rather think I am,â€ said honest John, with some considerable emphasis.
â€œI thought so,â€ said the senator.

â€œIf thereâ€™s anybody comes,â€ said the good man, stretching his tall, muscular form upward, â€œwhy here Iâ€™m ready for him: and Iâ€™ve got seven sons, each six foot high, and theyâ€™ll be ready for â€™em. Give our respects to â€™em,â€ said John; â€œtell â€™em itâ€™s no matter how soon they call,â€”make no kinder difference to us,â€ said John, running his fingers through the shock of hair that thatched his head, and bursting out into a great laugh.

Weary, jaded, and spiritless, Eliza dragged herself up to the door, with her child lying in a heavy sleep on her arm. The rough man held the candle to her face, and uttering a kind of compassionate grunt, opened the door of a small bed-room adjoining to the large kitchen where they were standing, and motioned her to go in. He took down a candle, and lighting it, set it upon the table, and then addressed himself to Eliza.

â€œNow, I say, gal, you neednâ€™t be a bit afeard, let who will come here. Iâ€™m up to all that sort oâ€™ thing,â€ said he, pointing to two or three goodly rifles over the mantel-piece; â€œand most people that know me know that â€™t wouldnâ€™t be healthy to try to get anybody out oâ€™ my house when Iâ€™m agin it. So now you jist go to sleep now, as quiet as if yer mother was a rockinâ€™ ye,â€ said he, as he shut the door.

â€œWhy, this is an uncommon handsome un,â€ he said to the senator. â€œAh, well; handsome uns has the greatest cause to run, sometimes, if they has any kind oâ€™ feelin, such as decent women should. I know all about that.â€
The senator, in a few words, briefly explained Elizaâ€™s history.

â€œO! ou! aw! now, I want to know?â€ said the good man, pitifully; â€œsho! now sho! Thatâ€™s natur now, poor crittur! hunted down now like a deer,â€”hunted down, jest for havinâ€™ natural feelinâ€™s, and doinâ€™ what no kind oâ€™ mother could help a doinâ€™! I tell ye what, these yer things make me come the nighest to swearinâ€™, now, oâ€™ most anything,â€ said honest John, as he wiped his eyes with the back of a great, freckled, yellow hand. â€œI tell yer what, stranger, it was years and years before Iâ€™d jine the church, â€™cause the ministers round in our parts used to preach that the Bible went in for these ere cuttings up,â€”and I couldnâ€™t be up to â€™em with their Greek and Hebrew, and so I took up agin â€™em, Bible and all. I never jined the church till I found a minister that was up to â€™em all in Greek and all that, and he said right the contrary; and then I took right hold, and jined the church,â€”I did now, fact,â€ said John, who had been all this time uncorking some very frisky bottled cider, which at this juncture he presented.
â€œYeâ€™d better jest put up here, now, till daylight,â€ said he, heartily, â€œand Iâ€™ll call up the old woman, and have a bed got ready for you in no time.â€
â€œThank you, my good friend,â€ said the senator, â€œI must be along, to take the night stage for Columbus.â€
â€œAh! well, then, if you must, Iâ€™ll go a piece with you, and show you a cross road that will take you there better than the road you came on. That roadâ€™s mighty bad.â€

John equipped himself, and, with a lantern in hand, was soon seen guiding the senatorâ€™s carriage towards a road that ran down in a hollow, back of his dwelling. When they parted, the senator put into his hand a ten-dollar bill.
â€œItâ€™s for her,â€ he said, briefly.
â€œAy, ay,â€ said John, with equal conciseness.
They shook hands, and parted.

div.head:
Chapter X
The Property Is Carried Off
div.p: The February morning looked gray and drizzling through the window of Uncle Tomâ€™s cabin. It looked on downcast faces, the images of mournful hearts. The little table stood out before the fire, covered with an ironing-cloth; a coarse but clean shirt or two, fresh from the iron, hung on the back of a chair by the fire, and Aunt Chloe had another spread out before her on the table. Carefully she rubbed and ironed every fold and every hem, with the most scrupulous exactness, every now and then raising her hand to her face to wipe off the tears that were coursing down her cheeks.
Tom sat by, with his Testament open on his knee, and his head leaning upon his hand;â€”but neither spoke. It was yet early, and the children lay all asleep together in their little rude trundle-bed.
Tom, who had, to the full, the gentle, domestic heart, which woe for them! has been a peculiar characteristic of his unhappy race, got up and walked silently to look at his children.
â€œItâ€™s the last time,â€ he said.

Aunt Chloe did not answer, only rubbed away over and over on the coarse shirt, already as smooth as hands could make it; and finally setting her iron suddenly down with a despairing plunge, she sat down to the table, and â€œlifted up her voice and wept.â€

â€œSâ€™pose we must be resigned; but oh Lord! how ken I? If I knowâ€™d anything whar you â€™s goinâ€™, or how theyâ€™d sarve you! Missis says sheâ€™ll try and â€™deem ye, in a year or two; but Lor! nobody never comes up that goes down thar! They kills â€™em! Iâ€™ve hearn â€™em tell how dey works â€™em up on dem ar plantations.â€
â€œThereâ€™ll be the same God there, Chloe, that there is here.â€
â€œWell,â€ said Aunt Chloe, â€œsâ€™pose dere will; but de Lord lets drefful things happen, sometimes. I donâ€™t seem to get no comfort dat way.â€

â€œIâ€™m in the Lordâ€™s hands,â€ said Tom; â€œnothinâ€™ can go no furder than he lets it;â€”and tharâ€™s one thing I can thank him for. Itâ€™s me thatâ€™s sold and going down, and not you nur the chilâ€™en. Here youâ€™re safe;â€”what comes will come only on me; and the Lord, heâ€™ll help me,â€”I know he will.â€
Ah, brave, manly heart,â€”smothering thine own sorrow, to comfort thy beloved ones! Tom spoke with a thick utterance, and with a bitter choking in his throat,â€”but he spoke brave and strong.
â€œLetâ€™s think on our marcies!â€ he added, tremulously, as if he was quite sure he needed to think on them very hard indeed.

â€œMarcies!â€ said Aunt Chloe; â€œdonâ€™t see no marcy in â€™t! â€™tanâ€™t right! tanâ€™t right it should be so! Masâ€™r never ought ter left it so that ye could be took for his debts. Yeâ€™ve arnt him all he gets for ye, twice over. He owed ye yer freedom, and ought ter gin â€™t to yer years ago. Mebbe he canâ€™t help himself now, but I feel itâ€™s wrong. Nothing canâ€™t beat that ar out oâ€™ me. Sich a faithful crittur as yeâ€™ve been,â€”and allers sot his business â€™fore yer own every way,â€”and reckoned on him more than yer own wife and chilâ€™en! Them as sells heartâ€™s love and heartâ€™s blood, to get out thar scrapes, de Lordâ€™ll be up to â€™em!â€

â€œChloe! now, if ye love me, ye wonâ€™t talk so, when perhaps jest the last time weâ€™ll ever have together! And Iâ€™ll tell ye, Chloe, it goes agin me to hear one word agin Masâ€™r. Wanâ€™t he put in my arms a baby?â€”itâ€™s natur I should think a heap of him. And he couldnâ€™t be spected to think so much of poor Tom. Masâ€™rs is used to havinâ€™ all these yer things done for â€™em, and natâ€™lly they donâ€™t think so much on â€™t. They canâ€™t be spected to, no way. Set him â€™longside of other Masâ€™rsâ€”whoâ€™s had the treatment and livinâ€™ Iâ€™ve had? And he never would have let this yer come on me, if he could have seed it aforehand. I know he wouldnâ€™t.â€

â€œWal, any way, tharâ€™s wrong about it somewhar,â€ said Aunt Chloe, in whom a stubborn sense of justice was a predominant trait; â€œI canâ€™t jest make out whar â€™t is, but tharâ€™s wrong somewhar, Iâ€™m clar oâ€™ that.â€
â€œYer ought ter look up to the Lord aboveâ€”heâ€™s above allâ€”thar donâ€™t a sparrow fall without him.â€

â€œIt donâ€™t seem to comfort me, but I spect it orter,â€ said Aunt Chloe. â€œBut darâ€™s no use talkinâ€™; Iâ€™ll jes wet up de corn-cake, and get ye one good breakfast, â€™cause nobody knows when youâ€™ll get another.â€

In order to appreciate the sufferings of the negroes sold south, it must be remembered that all the instinctive affections of that race are peculiarly strong. Their local attachments are very abiding. They are not naturally daring and enterprising, but home-loving and affectionate. Add to this all the terrors with which ignorance invests the unknown, and add to this, again, that selling to the south is set before the negro from childhood as the last severity of punishment. The threat that terrifies more than whipping or torture of any kind is the threat of being sent down river. We have ourselves heard this feeling expressed by them, and seen the unaffected horror with which they will sit in their gossipping hours, and tell frightful stories of that â€œdown river,â€ which to them is

â€œThat undiscovered country, from whose bourn
No traveller returns.â€ [1]
[1] A slightly inaccurate quotation from Hamlet, Act III, scene I, lines 369-370.

A missionary figure among the fugitives in Canada told us that many of the fugitives confessed themselves to have escaped from comparatively kind masters, and that they were induced to brave the perils of escape, in almost every case, by the desperate horror with which they regarded being sold south,â€”a doom which was hanging either over themselves or their husbands, their wives or children. This nerves the African, naturally patient, timid and unenterprising, with heroic courage, and leads him to suffer hunger, cold, pain, the perils of the wilderness, and the more dread penalties of recapture.

The simple morning meal now smoked on the table, for Mrs. Shelby had excused Aunt Chloeâ€™s attendance at the great house that morning. The poor soul had expended all her little energies on this farewell feast,â€”had killed and dressed her choicest chicken, and prepared her corn-cake with scrupulous exactness, just to her husbandâ€™s taste, and brought out certain mysterious jars on the mantel-piece, some preserves that were never produced except on extreme occasions.
â€œLor, Pete,â€ said Mose, triumphantly, â€œhanâ€™t we got a buster of a breakfast!â€ at the same time catching at a fragment of the chicken.
Aunt Chloe gave him a sudden box on the ear. â€œThar now! crowing over the last breakfast yer poor daddyâ€™s gwine to have to home!â€
â€œO, Chloe!â€ said Tom, gently.
â€œWal, I canâ€™t help it,â€ said Aunt Chloe, hiding her face in her apron; â€œI â€™s so tossed about it, it makes me act ugly.â€
The boys stood quite still, looking first at their father and then at their mother, while the baby, climbing up her clothes, began an imperious, commanding cry.

â€œThar!â€ said Aunt Chloe, wiping her eyes and taking up the baby; â€œnow Iâ€™s done, I hope,â€”now do eat something. This yerâ€™s my nicest chicken. Thar, boys, ye shall have some, poor critturs! Yer mammyâ€™s been cross to yer.â€
The boys needed no second invitation, and went in with great zeal for the eatables; and it was well they did so, as otherwise there would have been very little performed to any purpose by the party.

â€œNow,â€ said Aunt Chloe, bustling about after breakfast, â€œI must put up yer clothes. Jest like as not, heâ€™ll take â€™em all away. I know thar waysâ€”mean as dirt, they is! Wal, now, yer flannels for rhumatis is in this corner; so be careful, â€™cause there wonâ€™t nobody make ye no more. Then hereâ€™s yer old shirts, and these yer is new ones. I toed off these yer stockings last night, and put de ball in â€™em to mend with. But Lor! whoâ€™ll ever mend for ye?â€ and Aunt Chloe, again overcome, laid her head on the box side, and sobbed. â€œTo think on â€™t! no crittur to do for ye, sick or well! I donâ€™t railly think I ought ter be good now!â€

The boys, having eaten everything there was on the breakfast-table, began now to take some thought of the case; and, seeing their mother crying, and their father looking very sad, began to whimper and put their hands to their eyes. Uncle Tom had the baby on his knee, and was letting her enjoy herself to the utmost extent, scratching his face and pulling his hair, and occasionally breaking out into clamorous explosions of delight, evidently arising out of her own internal reflections.

â€œAy, crow away, poor crittur!â€ said Aunt Chloe; â€œyeâ€™ll have to come to it, too! yeâ€™ll live to see yer husband sold, or mebbe be sold yerself; and these yer boys, theyâ€™s to be sold, I sâ€™pose, too, jest like as not, when dey gets good for somethinâ€™; anâ€™t no use in niggers havinâ€™ nothinâ€™!â€
Here one of the boys called out, â€œTharâ€™s Missis a-cominâ€™ in!â€
â€œShe canâ€™t do no good; whatâ€™s she coming for?â€ said Aunt Chloe.
Mrs. Shelby entered. Aunt Chloe set a chair for her in a manner decidedly gruff and crusty. She did not seem to notice either the action or the manner. She looked pale and anxious.
â€œTom,â€ she said, â€œI come toâ€”â€ and stopping suddenly, and regarding the silent group, she sat down in the chair, and, covering her face with her handkerchief, began to sob.

â€œLor, now, Missis, donâ€™tâ€”donâ€™t!â€ said Aunt Chloe, bursting out in her turn; and for a few moments they all wept in company. And in those tears they all shed together, the high and the lowly, melted away all the heart-burnings and anger of the oppressed. O, ye who visit the distressed, do ye know that everything your money can buy, given with a cold, averted face, is not worth one honest tear shed in real sympathy?

â€œMy good fellow,â€ said Mrs. Shelby, â€œI canâ€™t give you anything to do you any good. If I give you money, it will only be taken from you. But I tell you solemnly, and before God, that I will keep trace of you, and bring you back as soon as I can command the money;â€”and, till then, trust in God!â€

Here the boys called out that Masâ€™r Haley was coming, and then an unceremonious kick pushed open the door. Haley stood there in very ill humor, having ridden hard the night before, and being not at all pacified by his ill success in recapturing his prey.
â€œCome,â€ said he, â€œye nigger, yeâ€™r ready? Servant, maâ€™am!â€ said he, taking off his hat, as he saw Mrs. Shelby.
Aunt Chloe shut and corded the box, and, getting up, looked gruffly on the trader, her tears seeming suddenly turned to sparks of fire.

Tom rose up meekly, to follow his new master, and raised up his heavy box on his shoulder. His wife took the baby in her arms to go with him to the wagon, and the children, still crying, trailed on behind.

Mrs. Shelby, walking up to the trader, detained him for a few moments, talking with him in an earnest manner; and while she was thus talking, the whole family party proceeded to a wagon, that stood ready harnessed at the door. A crowd of all the old and young hands on the place stood gathered around it, to bid farewell to their old associate. Tom had been looked up to, both as a head servant and a Christian teacher, by all the place, and there was much honest sympathy and grief about him, particularly among the women.
â€œWhy, Chloe, you bar it better â€™n we do!â€ said one of the women, who had been weeping freely, noticing the gloomy calmness with which Aunt Chloe stood by the wagon.
â€œIâ€™s done my tears!â€ she said, looking grimly at the trader, who was coming up. â€œI does not feel to cry â€™fore dat ar old limb, no how!â€
â€œGet in!â€ said Haley to Tom, as he strode through the crowd of servants, who looked at him with lowering brows.
Tom got in, and Haley, drawing out from under the wagon seat a heavy pair of shackles, made them fast around each ankle.
A smothered groan of indignation ran through the whole circle, and Mrs. Shelby spoke from the verandah,â€”â€œMr. Haley, I assure you that precaution is entirely unnecessary.â€
â€œDonâ€™ know, maâ€™am; Iâ€™ve lost one five hundred dollars from this yer place, and I canâ€™t afford to run no more risks.â€

â€œWhat else could she spect on him?â€ said Aunt Chloe, indignantly, while the two boys, who now seemed to comprehend at once their fatherâ€™s destiny, clung to her gown, sobbing and groaning vehemently.
â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ said Tom, â€œthat Masâ€™r George happened to be away.â€

George had gone to spend two or three days with a companion on a neighboring estate, and having departed early in the morning, before Tomâ€™s misfortune had been made public, had left without hearing of it.
â€œGive my love to Masâ€™r George,â€ he said, earnestly.
Haley whipped up the horse, and, with a steady, mournful look, fixed to the last on the old place, Tom was whirled away.

Mr. Shelby at this time was not at home. He had sold Tom under the spur of a driving necessity, to get out of the power of a man whom he dreaded,â€”and his first feeling, after the consummation of the bargain, had been that of relief. But his wifeâ€™s expostulations awoke his half-slumbering regrets; and Tomâ€™s manly disinterestedness increased the unpleasantness of his feelings. It was in vain that he said to himself that he had a right to do it,â€”that everybody did it,â€”and that some did it without even the excuse of necessity;â€”he could not satisfy his own feelings; and that he might not witness the unpleasant scenes of the consummation, he had gone on a short business tour up the country, hoping that all would be over before he returned.

Tom and Haley rattled on along the dusty road, whirling past every old familiar spot, until the bounds of the estate were fairly passed, and they found themselves out on the open pike. After they had ridden about a mile, Haley suddenly drew up at the door of a blacksmithâ€™s shop, when, taking out with him a pair of handcuffs, he stepped into the shop, to have a little alteration in them.
â€œThese yer â€™s a little too small for his build,â€ said Haley, showing the fetters, and pointing out to Tom.
â€œLor! now, if thar anâ€™t Shelbyâ€™s Tom. He hanâ€™t sold him, now?â€ said the smith.
â€œYes, he has,â€ said Haley.
â€œNow, ye donâ€™t! well, reely,â€ said the smith, â€œwhoâ€™d a thought it! Why, ye neednâ€™t go to fetterinâ€™ him up this yer way. Heâ€™s the faithfullest, best critturâ€”â€

â€œYes, yes,â€ said Haley; â€œbut your good fellers are just the critturs to want ter run off. Them stupid ones, as doesnâ€™t care whar they go, and shifless, drunken ones, as donâ€™t care for nothinâ€™, theyâ€™ll stick by, and like as not be rather pleased to be toted round; but these yer prime fellers, they hates it like sin. No way but to fetter â€™em; got legs,â€”theyâ€™ll use â€™em,â€”no mistake.â€
â€œWell,â€ said the smith, feeling among his tools, â€œthem plantations down thar, stranger, anâ€™t jest the place a Kentuck nigger wants to go to; they dies thar tolâ€™able fast, donâ€™t they?â€
â€œWal, yes, tolâ€™able fast, ther dying is; what with the â€™climating and one thing and another, they dies so as to keep the market up pretty brisk,â€ said Haley.
â€œWal, now, a feller canâ€™t help thinkinâ€™ itâ€™s a mighty pity to have a nice, quiet, likely feller, as good un as Tom is, go down to be fairly ground up on one of them ar sugar plantations.â€

â€œWal, heâ€™s got a faâ€™r chance. I promised to do well by him. Iâ€™ll get him in house-servant in some good old family, and then, if he stands the fever and â€™climating, heâ€™ll have a berth good as any nigger ought ter ask for.â€
â€œHe leaves his wife and chilâ€™en up here, sâ€™pose?â€
â€œYes; but heâ€™ll get another thar. Lord, tharâ€™s women enough everywhar,â€ said Haley.

Tom was sitting very mournfully on the outside of the shop while this conversation was going on. Suddenly he heard the quick, short click of a horseâ€™s hoof behind him; and, before he could fairly awake from his surprise, young Master George sprang into the wagon, threw his arms tumultuously round his neck, and was sobbing and scolding with energy.

â€œI declare, itâ€™s real mean! I donâ€™t care what they say, any of â€™em! Itâ€™s a nasty, mean shame! If I was a man, they shouldnâ€™t do it,â€”they should not, so!â€ said George, with a kind of subdued howl.

â€œO! Masâ€™r George! this does me good!â€ said Tom. â€œI couldnâ€™t bar to go off without seeinâ€™ ye! It does me real good, ye canâ€™t tell!â€ Here Tom made some movement of his feet, and Georgeâ€™s eye fell on the fetters.
â€œWhat a shame!â€ he exclaimed, lifting his hands. â€œIâ€™ll knock that old fellow downâ€”I will!â€
â€œNo you wonâ€™t, Masâ€™r George; and you must not talk so loud. It wonâ€™t help me any, to anger him.â€

â€œWell, I wonâ€™t, then, for your sake; but only to think of itâ€”isnâ€™t it a shame? They never sent for me, nor sent me any word, and, if it hadnâ€™t been for Tom Lincon, I shouldnâ€™t have heard it. I tell you, I blew â€™em up well, all of â€™em, at home!â€
â€œThat ar wasnâ€™t right, Iâ€™m â€™feard, Masâ€™r George.â€
â€œCanâ€™t help it! I say itâ€™s a shame! Look here, Uncle Tom,â€ said he, turning his back to the shop, and speaking in a mysterious tone, â€œIâ€™ve brought you my dollar!â€
â€œO! I couldnâ€™t think oâ€™ takinâ€™ on â€™t, Masâ€™r George, no ways in the world!â€ said Tom, quite moved.

â€œBut you shall take it!â€ said George; â€œlook hereâ€”I told Aunt Chloe Iâ€™d do it, and she advised me just to make a hole in it, and put a string through, so you could hang it round your neck, and keep it out of sight; else this mean scamp would take it away. I tell ye, Tom, I want to blow him up! it would do me good!â€
â€œNo, donâ€™t Masâ€™r George, for it wonâ€™t do me any good.â€

â€œWell, I wonâ€™t, for your sake,â€ said George, busily tying his dollar round Tomâ€™s neck; â€œbut there, now, button your coat tight over it, and keep it, and remember, every time you see it, that Iâ€™ll come down after you, and bring you back. Aunt Chloe and I have been talking about it. I told her not to fear; Iâ€™ll see to it, and Iâ€™ll tease fatherâ€™s life out, if he donâ€™t do it.â€
â€œO! Masâ€™r George, ye mustnâ€™t talk so â€™bout yer father!â€
â€œLor, Uncle Tom, I donâ€™t mean anything bad.â€

â€œAnd now, Masâ€™r George,â€ said Tom, â€œye must be a good boy; â€™member how many hearts is sot on ye. Alâ€™ays keep close to yer mother. Donâ€™t be gettinâ€™ into any of them foolish ways boys has of gettinâ€™ too big to mind their mothers. Tell ye what, Masâ€™r George, the Lord gives good many things twice over; but he donâ€™t give ye a mother but once. Yeâ€™ll never see sich another woman, Masâ€™r George, if ye live to be a hundred years old. So, now, you hold on to her, and grow up, and be a comfort to her, tharâ€™s my own good boy,â€”you will now, wonâ€™t ye?â€
â€œYes, I will, Uncle Tom,â€ said George seriously.

â€œAnd be careful of yer speaking, Masâ€™r George. Young boys, when they comes to your age, is wilful, sometimesâ€”it is natur they should be. But real gentlemen, such as I hopes youâ€™ll be, never lets fall on words that isnâ€™t â€™spectful to thar parents. Ye anâ€™t â€™fended, Masâ€™r George?â€
â€œNo, indeed, Uncle Tom; you always did give me good advice.â€

â€œIâ€™s older, ye know,â€ said Tom, stroking the boyâ€™s fine, curly head with his large, strong hand, but speaking in a voice as tender as a womanâ€™s, â€œand I sees all thatâ€™s bound up in you. O, Masâ€™r George, you has everything,â€”lâ€™arninâ€™, privileges, readinâ€™, writinâ€™,â€”and youâ€™ll grow up to be a great, learned, good man and all the people on the place and your mother and fatherâ€™ll be so proud on ye! Be a good Masâ€™r, like yer father; and be a Christian, like yer mother. â€™Member yer Creator in the days oâ€™ yer youth, Masâ€™r George.â€

â€œIâ€™ll be real good, Uncle Tom, I tell you,â€ said George. â€œIâ€™m going to be a first-rater; and donâ€™t you be discouraged. Iâ€™ll have you back to the place, yet. As I told Aunt Chloe this morning, Iâ€™ll build our house all over, and you shall have a room for a parlor with a carpet on it, when Iâ€™m a man. O, youâ€™ll have good times yet!â€
Haley now came to the door, with the handcuffs in his hands.
â€œLook here, now, Mister,â€ said George, with an air of great superiority, as he got out, â€œI shall let father and mother know how you treat Uncle Tom!â€
â€œYouâ€™re welcome,â€ said the trader.
â€œI should think youâ€™d be ashamed to spend all your life buying men and women, and chaining them, like cattle! I should think youâ€™d feel mean!â€ said George.
â€œSo long as your grand folks wants to buy men and women, Iâ€™m as good as they is,â€ said Haley; â€œâ€˜tanâ€™t any meaner sellinâ€™ on â€™em, that â€™t is buyinâ€™!â€

â€œIâ€™ll never do either, when Iâ€™m a man,â€ said George; â€œIâ€™m ashamed, this day, that Iâ€™m a Kentuckian. I always was proud of it before;â€ and George sat very straight on his horse, and looked round with an air, as if he expected the state would be impressed with his opinion.
â€œWell, good-by, Uncle Tom; keep a stiff upper lip,â€ said George.

â€œGood-by, Masâ€™r George,â€ said Tom, looking fondly and admiringly at him. â€œGod Almighty bless you! Ah! Kentucky hanâ€™t got many like you!â€ he said, in the fulness of his heart, as the frank, boyish face was lost to his view. Away he went, and Tom looked, till the clatter of his horseâ€™s heels died away, the last sound or sight of his home. But over his heart there seemed to be a warm spot, where those young hands had placed that precious dollar. Tom put up his hand, and held it close to his heart.

â€œNow, I tell ye what, Tom,â€ said Haley, as he came up to the wagon, and threw in the handcuffs, â€œI mean to start faâ€™r with ye, as I genâ€™ally do with my niggers; and Iâ€™ll tell ye now, to begin with, you treat me faâ€™r, and Iâ€™ll treat you faâ€™r; I anâ€™t never hard on my niggers. Calculates to do the best for â€™em I can. Now, ye see, youâ€™d better jest settle down comfortable, and not be tryinâ€™ no tricks; because niggerâ€™s tricks of all sorts Iâ€™m up to, and itâ€™s no use. If niggers is quiet, and donâ€™t try to get off, they has good times with me; and if they donâ€™t, why, itâ€™s thar fault, and not mine.â€

Tom assured Haley that he had no present intentions of running off. In fact, the exhortation seemed rather a superfluous one to a man with a great pair of iron fetters on his feet. But Mr. Haley had got in the habit of commencing his relations with his stock with little exhortations of this nature, calculated, as he deemed, to inspire cheerfulness and confidence, and prevent the necessity of any unpleasant scenes.
And here, for the present, we take our leave of Tom, to pursue the fortunes of other characters in our story.

div.head:
Chapter XI
In Which Property Gets into an Improper State of Mind
div.p: It was late in a drizzly afternoon that a traveler alighted at the door of a small country hotel, in the village of Nâ€”â€”, in Kentucky. In the barroom he found assembled quite a miscellaneous company, whom stress of weather had driven to harbor, and the place presented the usual scenery of such reunions. Great, tall, raw-boned Kentuckians, attired in hunting-shirts, and trailing their loose joints over a vast extent of territory, with the easy lounge peculiar to the race,â€”rifles stacked away in the corner, shot-pouches, game-bags, hunting-dogs, and little negroes, all rolled together in the corners,â€”were the characteristic features in the picture. At each end of the fireplace sat a long-legged gentleman, with his chair tipped back, his hat on his head, and the heels of his muddy boots reposing sublimely on the mantel-piece,â€”a position, we will inform our readers, decidedly favorable to the turn of reflection incident to western taverns, where travellers exhibit a decided preference for this particular mode of elevating their understandings.

Mine host, who stood behind the bar, like most of his country men, was great of stature, good-natured and loose-jointed, with an enormous shock of hair on his head, and a great tall hat on the top of that.

In fact, everybody in the room bore on his head this characteristic emblem of manâ€™s sovereignty; whether it were felt hat, palm-leaf, greasy beaver, or fine new chapeau, there it reposed with true republican independence. In truth, it appeared to be the characteristic mark of every individual.
