Indolent and childish, unsystematic and improvident, it was not to be expected that servants trained under her care should not be so likewise; and she had very justly described to Miss Ophelia the state of confusion she would find in the family, though she had not ascribed it to the proper cause.

The first morning of her regency, Miss Ophelia was up at four oâ€™clock; and having attended to all the adjustments of her own chamber, as she had done ever since she came there, to the great amazement of the chambermaid, she prepared for a vigorous onslaught on the cupboards and closets of the establishment of which she had the keys.

The store-room, the linen-presses, the china-closet, the kitchen and cellar, that day, all went under an awful review. Hidden things of darkness were brought to light to an extent that alarmed all the principalities and powers of kitchen and chamber, and caused many wonderings and murmurings about â€œdese yer northern ladiesâ€ from the domestic cabinet.

Old Dinah, the head cook, and principal of all rule and authority in the kitchen department, was filled with wrath at what she considered an invasion of privilege. No feudal baron in Magna Charta times could have more thoroughly resented some incursion of the crown.

Dinah was a character in her own way, and it would be injustice to her memory not to give the reader a little idea of her. She was a native and essential cook, as much as Aunt Chloe,â€”cooking being an indigenous talent of the African race; but Chloe was a trained and methodical one, who moved in an orderly domestic harness, while Dinah was a self-taught genius, and, like geniuses in general, was positive, opinionated and erratic, to the last degree.

Like a certain class of modern philosophers, Dinah perfectly scorned logic and reason in every shape, and always took refuge in intuitive certainty; and here she was perfectly impregnable. No possible amount of talent, or authority, or explanation, could ever make her believe that any other way was better than her own, or that the course she had pursued in the smallest matter could be in the least modified. This had been a conceded point with her old mistress, Marieâ€™s mother; and â€œMiss Marie,â€ as Dinah always called her young mistress, even after her marriage, found it easier to submit than contend; and so Dinah had ruled supreme. This was the easier, in that she was perfect mistress of that diplomatic art which unites the utmost subservience of manner with the utmost inflexibility as to measure.

Dinah was mistress of the whole art and mystery of excuse-making, in all its branches. Indeed, it was an axiom with her that the cook can do no wrong; and a cook in a Southern kitchen finds abundance of heads and shoulders on which to lay off every sin and frailty, so as to maintain her own immaculateness entire. If any part of the dinner was a failure, there were fifty indisputably good reasons for it; and it was the fault undeniably of fifty other people, whom Dinah berated with unsparing zeal.

But it was very seldom that there was any failure in Dinahâ€™s last results. Though her mode of doing everything was peculiarly meandering and circuitous, and without any sort of calculation as to time and place,â€”though her kitchen generally looked as if it had been arranged by a hurricane blowing through it, and she had about as many places for each cooking utensil as there were days in the year,â€”yet, if one would have patience to wait her own good time, up would come her dinner in perfect order, and in a style of preparation with which an epicure could find no fault.

It was now the season of incipient preparation for dinner. Dinah, who required large intervals of reflection and repose, and was studious of ease in all her arrangements, was seated on the kitchen floor, smoking a short, stumpy pipe, to which she was much addicted, and which she always kindled up, as a sort of censer, whenever she felt the need of an inspiration in her arrangements. It was Dinahâ€™s mode of invoking the domestic Muses.

Seated around her were various members of that rising race with which a Southern household abounds, engaged in shelling peas, peeling potatoes, picking pin-feathers out of fowls, and other preparatory arrangements,â€”Dinah every once in a while interrupting her meditations to give a poke, or a rap on the head, to some of the young operators, with the pudding-stick that lay by her side. In fact, Dinah ruled over the woolly heads of the younger members with a rod of iron, and seemed to consider them born for no earthly purpose but to â€œsave her steps,â€ as she phrased it. It was the spirit of the system under which she had grown up, and she carried it out to its full extent.

Miss Ophelia, after passing on her reformatory tour through all the other parts of the establishment, now entered the kitchen. Dinah had heard, from various sources, what was going on, and resolved to stand on defensive and conservative ground,â€”mentally determined to oppose and ignore every new measure, without any actual observable contest.

The kitchen was a large brick-floored apartment, with a great old-fashioned fireplace stretching along one side of it,â€”an arrangement which St. Clare had vainly tried to persuade Dinah to exchange for the convenience of a modern cook-stove. Not she. No Puseyite, [1] or conservative of any school, was ever more inflexibly attached to time-honored inconveniences than Dinah.
[1] Edward Bouverie Pusey (1800-1882), champion of the orthodoxy of revealed religion, defender of the Oxford movement, and Regius professor of Hebrew and Canon of Christ Church, Oxford.

When St. Clare had first returned from the north, impressed with the system and order of his uncleâ€™s kitchen arrangements, he had largely provided his own with an array of cupboards, drawers, and various apparatus, to induce systematic regulation, under the sanguine illusion that it would be of any possible assistance to Dinah in her arrangements. He might as well have provided them for a squirrel or a magpie. The more drawers and closets there were, the more hiding-holes could Dinah make for the accommodation of old rags, hair-combs, old shoes, ribbons, cast-off artificial flowers, and other articles of vertu, wherein her soul delighted.

When Miss Ophelia entered the kitchen Dinah did not rise, but smoked on in sublime tranquillity, regarding her movements obliquely out of the corner of her eye, but apparently intent only on the operations around her.
Miss Ophelia commenced opening a set of drawers.
â€œWhat is this drawer for, Dinah?â€ she said.

â€œItâ€™s handy for most anything, Missis,â€ said Dinah. So it appeared to be. From the variety it contained, Miss Ophelia pulled out first a fine damask table-cloth stained with blood, having evidently been used to envelop some raw meat.
â€œWhatâ€™s this, Dinah? You donâ€™t wrap up meat in your mistressâ€™ best table-cloths?â€
â€œO Lor, Missis, no; the towels was all a missinâ€™â€”so I jest did it. I laid out to wash that a,â€”thatâ€™s why I put it thar.â€

â€œShifâ€™less!â€ said Miss Ophelia to herself, proceeding to tumble over the drawer, where she found a nutmeg-grater and two or three nutmegs, a Methodist hymn-book, a couple of soiled Madras handkerchiefs, some yarn and knitting-work, a paper of tobacco and a pipe, a few crackers, one or two gilded china-saucers with some pomade in them, one or two thin old shoes, a piece of flannel carefully pinned up enclosing some small white onions, several damask table-napkins, some coarse crash towels, some twine and darning-needles, and several broken papers, from which sundry sweet herbs were sifting into the drawer.
â€œWhere do you keep your nutmegs, Dinah?â€ said Miss Ophelia, with the air of one who prayed for patience.
â€œMost anywhar, Missis; thereâ€™s some in that cracked tea-cup, up there, and thereâ€™s some over in that ar cupboard.â€
â€œHere are some in the grater,â€ said Miss Ophelia, holding them up.

â€œLaws, yes, I put â€™em there this morning,â€”I likes to keep my things handy,â€ said Dinah. â€œYou, Jake! what are you stopping for! Youâ€™ll cotch it! Be still, thar!â€ she added, with a dive of her stick at the criminal.
â€œWhatâ€™s this?â€ said Miss Ophelia, holding up the saucer of pomade.
â€œLaws, itâ€™s my har grease;â€”I put it thar to have it handy.â€
â€œDo you use your mistressâ€™ best saucers for that?â€
â€œLaw! it was cause I was driv, and in sich a hurry;â€”I was gwine to change it this very day.â€
â€œHere are two damask table-napkins.â€
â€œThem table-napkins I put thar, to get â€™em washed out, some day.â€
â€œDonâ€™t you have some place here on purpose for things to be washed?â€
â€œWell, Masâ€™r St. Clare got dat ar chest, he said, for dat; but I likes to mix up biscuit and hev my things on it some days, and then it anâ€™t handy a liftinâ€™ up the lid.â€
â€œWhy donâ€™t you mix your biscuits on the pastry-table, there?â€
â€œLaw, Missis, it gets sot so full of dishes, and one thing and another, der anâ€™t no room, nowayâ€”â€
â€œBut you should wash your dishes, and clear them away.â€

â€œWash my dishes!â€ said Dinah, in a high key, as her wrath began to rise over her habitual respect of manner; â€œwhat does ladies know â€™bout work, I want to know? When â€™d Masâ€™r ever get his dinner, if I vas to spend all my time a washinâ€™ and a puttinâ€™ up dishes? Miss Marie never telled me so, nohow.â€
â€œWell, here are these onions.â€

â€œLaws, yes!â€ said Dinah; â€œthar is whar I put â€™em, now. I couldnâ€™t â€™member. Them â€™s particular onions I was a savinâ€™ for dis yer very stew. Iâ€™d forgot they was in dat ar old flannel.â€
Miss Ophelia lifted out the sifting papers of sweet herbs.
â€œI wish Missis wouldnâ€™t touch dem ar. I likes to keep my things where I knows whar to go to â€™em,â€ said Dinah, rather decidedly.
â€œBut you donâ€™t want these holes in the papers.â€
â€œThem â€™s handy for siftinâ€™ on â€™t out,â€ said Dinah.
â€œBut you see it spills all over the drawer.â€

â€œLaws, yes! if Missis will go a tumblinâ€™ things all up so, it will. Missis has spilt lots dat ar way,â€ said Dinah, coming uneasily to the drawers. â€œIf Missis only will go up stars till my clarinâ€™ up time comes, Iâ€™ll have everything right; but I canâ€™t do nothinâ€™ when ladies is round, a henderinâ€™. You, Sam, donâ€™t you gib the baby dat ar sugar-bowl! Iâ€™ll crack ye over, if ye donâ€™t mind!â€
â€œIâ€™m going through the kitchen, and going to put everything in order, once, Dinah; and then Iâ€™ll expect you to keep it so.â€

â€œLor, now! Miss Phelia; dat ar anâ€™t no way for ladies to do. I never did see ladies doinâ€™ no sich; my old Missis nor Miss Marie never did, and I donâ€™t see no kinder need on â€™t;â€ and Dinah stalked indignantly about, while Miss Ophelia piled and sorted dishes, emptied dozens of scattering bowls of sugar into one receptacle, sorted napkins, table-cloths, and towels, for washing; washing, wiping, and arranging with her own hands, and with a speed and alacrity which perfectly amazed Dinah.

â€œLor now! if dat ar de way dem northern ladies do, dey anâ€™t ladies, nohow,â€ she said to some of her satellites, when at a safe hearing distance. â€œI has things as straight as anybody, when my clarinâ€™ up times comes; but I donâ€™t want ladies round, a henderinâ€™, and getting my things all where I canâ€™t find â€™em.â€

To do Dinah justice, she had, at irregular periods, paroxyms of reformation and arrangement, which she called â€œclarinâ€™ up times,â€ when she would begin with great zeal, and turn every drawer and closet wrong side outward, on to the floor or tables, and make the ordinary confusion seven-fold more confounded. Then she would light her pipe, and leisurely go over her arrangements, looking things over, and discoursing upon them; making all the young fry scour most vigorously on the tin things, and keeping up for several hours a most energetic state of confusion, which she would explain to the satisfaction of all inquirers, by the remark that she was a â€œclarinâ€™ up.â€ â€œShe couldnâ€™t hev things a gwine on so as they had been, and she was gwine to make these yer young ones keep better order;â€ for Dinah herself, somehow, indulged the illusion that she, herself, was the soul of order, and it was only the young uns, and the everybody else in the house, that were the cause of anything that fell short of perfection in this respect. When all the tins were scoured, and the tables scrubbed snowy white, and everything that could offend tucked out of sight in holes and corners, Dinah would dress herself up in a smart dress, clean apron, and high, brilliant Madras turban, and tell all marauding â€œyoung unsâ€ to keep out of the kitchen, for she was gwine to have things kept nice. Indeed, these periodic seasons were often an inconvenience to the whole household; for Dinah would contract such an immoderate attachment to her scoured tin, as to insist upon it that it shouldnâ€™t be used again for any possible purpose,â€”at least, till the ardor of the â€œclarinâ€™ upâ€ period abated.

Miss Ophelia, in a few days, thoroughly reformed every department of the house to a systematic pattern; but her labors in all departments that depended on the cooperation of servants were like those of Sisyphus or the Danaides. In despair, she one day appealed to St. Clare.
â€œThere is no such thing as getting anything like a system in this family!â€
â€œTo be sure, there isnâ€™t,â€ said St. Clare.
â€œSuch shiftless management, such waste, such confusion, I never saw!â€
â€œI dare say you didnâ€™t.â€
â€œYou would not take it so coolly, if you were housekeeper.â€

â€œMy dear cousin, you may as well understand, once for all, that we masters are divided into two classes, oppressors and oppressed. We who are good-natured and hate severity make up our minds to a good deal of inconvenience. If we will keep a shambling, loose, untaught set in the community, for our convenience, why, we must take the consequence. Some rare cases I have seen, of persons, who, by a peculiar tact, can produce order and system without severity; but Iâ€™m not one of them,â€”and so I made up my mind, long ago, to let things go just as they do. I will not have the poor devils thrashed and cut to pieces, and they know it,â€”and, of course, they know the staff is in their own hands.â€
â€œBut to have no time, no place, no order,â€”all going on in this shiftless way!â€

â€œMy dear Vermont, you natives up by the North Pole set an extravagant value on time! What on earth is the use of time to a fellow who has twice as much of it as he knows what to do with? As to order and system, where there is nothing to be done but to lounge on the sofa and read, an hour sooner or later in breakfast or dinner isnâ€™t of much account. Now, thereâ€™s Dinah gets you a capital dinner,â€”soup, ragout, roast fowl, dessert, ice-creams and all,â€”and she creates it all out of chaos and old night down there, in that kitchen. I think it really sublime, the way she manages. But, Heaven bless us! if we are to go down there, and view all the smoking and squatting about, and hurryscurryation of the preparatory process, we should never eat more! My good cousin, absolve yourself from that! Itâ€™s more than a Catholic penance, and does no more good. Youâ€™ll only lose your own temper, and utterly confound Dinah. Let her go her own way.â€
â€œBut, Augustine, you donâ€™t know how I found things.â€

â€œDonâ€™t I? Donâ€™t I know that the rolling-pin is under her bed, and the nutmeg-grater in her pocket with her tobacco,â€”that there are sixty-five different sugar-bowls, one in every hole in the house,â€”that she washes dishes with a dinner-napkin one day, and with a fragment of an old petticoat the next? But the upshot is, she gets up glorious dinners, makes superb coffee; and you must judge her as warriors and statesmen are judged, by her success.â€
â€œBut the waste,â€”the expense!â€
â€œO, well! Lock everything you can, and keep the key. Give out by driblets, and never inquire for odds and ends,â€”it isnâ€™t best.â€
â€œThat troubles me, Augustine. I canâ€™t help feeling as if these servants were not strictly honest. Are you sure they can be relied on?â€
Augustine laughed immoderately at the grave and anxious face with which Miss Ophelia propounded the question.
â€œO, cousin, thatâ€™s too good,â€”honest!â€”as if thatâ€™s a thing to be expected! Honest!â€”why, of course, they arnâ€™t. Why should they be? What upon earth is to make them so?â€
â€œWhy donâ€™t you instruct?â€

â€œInstruct! O, fiddlestick! What instructing do you think I should do? I look like it! As to Marie, she has spirit enough, to be sure, to kill off a whole plantation, if Iâ€™d let her manage; but she wouldnâ€™t get the cheatery out of them.â€
â€œAre there no honest ones?â€

â€œWell, now and then one, whom Nature makes so impracticably simple, truthful and faithful, that the worst possible influence canâ€™t destroy it. But, you see, from the motherâ€™s breast the colored child feels and sees that there are none but underhand ways open to it. It can get along no other way with its parents, its mistress, its young master and missie play-fellows. Cunning and deception become necessary, inevitable habits. It isnâ€™t fair to expect anything else of him. He ought not to be punished for it. As to honesty, the slave is kept in that dependent, semi-childish state, that there is no making him realize the rights of property, or feel that his masterâ€™s goods are not his own, if he can get them. For my part, I donâ€™t see how they can be honest. Such a fellow as Tom, here, is,â€”is a moral miracle!â€
â€œAnd what becomes of their souls?â€ said Miss Ophelia.

â€œThat isnâ€™t my affair, as I know of,â€ said St. Clare; â€œI am only dealing in facts of the present life. The fact is, that the whole race are pretty generally understood to be turned over to the devil, for our benefit, in this world, however it may turn out in another!â€
â€œThis is perfectly horrible!â€ said Miss Ophelia; â€œyou ought to be ashamed of yourselves!â€

â€œI donâ€™t know as I am. We are in pretty good company, for all that,â€ said St. Clare, â€œas people in the broad road generally are. Look at the high and the low, all the world over, and itâ€™s the same story,â€”the lower class used up, body, soul and spirit, for the good of the upper. It is so in England; it is so everywhere; and yet all Christendom stands aghast, with virtuous indignation, because we do the thing in a little different shape from what they do it.â€
â€œIt isnâ€™t so in Vermont.â€

â€œAh, well, in New England, and in the free States, you have the better of us, I grant. But thereâ€™s the bell; so, Cousin, let us for a while lay aside our sectional prejudices, and come out to dinner.â€
As Miss Ophelia was in the kitchen in the latter part of the afternoon, some of the sable children called out, â€œLa, sakes! tharâ€™s Prue a coming, grunting along like she allers does.â€
A tall, bony colored woman now entered the kitchen, bearing on her head a basket of rusks and hot rolls.

Prue had a peculiar scowling expression of countenance, and a sullen, grumbling voice. She set down her basket, squatted herself down, and resting her elbows on her knees said,
â€œO Lord! I wishâ€™t I â€™s dead!â€

â€œMaybe youâ€™ll come to it, one of these yer days. Iâ€™d be glad to see you, I would; then youâ€™ll be glad of a drop, like me, to forget your misery.â€

â€œTharâ€™s some tickets in that ar old cracked jug on the top shelf,â€ said Dinah. â€œYou, Jake, climb up and get it down.â€

â€œWe buy tickets of her Masâ€™r, and she gives us bread for â€™em.â€

â€œAnd thatâ€™s what I will do,â€”I canâ€™t live no other ways,â€”drink and forget my misery.â€

â€œItâ€™s mighty likely, Missis; but I will do it,â€”yes, I will. O Lord! I wish I â€™s dead, I do,â€”I wish I â€™s dead, and out of my misery!â€ and slowly and stiffly the old creature rose, and got her basket on her head again; but before she went out, she looked at the quadroon girl, who still stood playing with her ear-drops.

â€œYe think yeâ€™re mighty fine with them ar, a frolickinâ€™ and a tossinâ€™ your head, and a lookinâ€™ down on everybody. Well, never mind,â€”you may live to be a poor, old, cut-up crittur, like me. â€œI think such low creatures ought not to be allowed to go round to genteel families,â€ said Miss Jane. â€œWhat do you think, Mr. St. Clare?â€ she said, coquettishly tossing her head at Adolph.

â€œIâ€™m certainly of your opinion, Miss Benoir,â€ said Adolph.

â€œAunt Dinahâ€™s glum, because she canâ€™t go to the ball,â€ said Rosa.
â€œDonâ€™t want none oâ€™ your light-colored balls,â€ said Dinah; â€œcuttinâ€™ round, makinâ€™ bâ€™lieve youâ€™s white folks. Arter all, youâ€™s niggers, much as I am.â€
â€œAunt Dinah greases her wool stiff, every day, to make it lie straight,â€ said Jane.

â€œWell, in the Lordâ€™s sight, anâ€™t wool as good as har, any time?â€ said Dinah. â€œIâ€™d like to have Missis say which is worth the most,â€”a couple such as you, or one like me. Get out wid ye, ye trumpery,â€”I wonâ€™t have ye round!â€

Here the conversation was interrupted in a two-fold manner. St. Clareâ€™s voice was heard at the head of the stairs, asking Adolph if he meant to stay all night with his shaving-water; and Miss Ophelia, coming out of the dining-room, said,
â€œJane and Rosa, what are you wasting your time for, here? Go in and attend to your muslins.â€

Our friend Tom, who had been in the kitchen during the conversation with the old rusk-woman, had followed her out into the street. He saw her go on, giving every once in a while a suppressed groan. At last she set her basket down on a doorstep, and began arranging the old, faded shawl which covered her shoulders.

â€œWhy should ye?â€ said the woman. â€œI donâ€™t want no help.â€

â€œI anâ€™t sick,â€ said the woman, shortly.
â€œI wish,â€ said Tom, looking at her earnestly,â€”â€œI wish I could persuade you to leave off drinking. Donâ€™t you know it will be the ruin of ye, body and soul?â€
â€œI knows Iâ€™m gwine to torment,â€ said the woman, sullenly. â€œYe donâ€™t need to tell me that ar. I â€™s ugly, I â€™s wicked,â€”I â€™s gwine straight to torment. O, Lord! I wish I â€™s thar!â€

â€œDonâ€™t know nothinâ€™ â€™bout that,â€ said the woman; â€œnobody hanâ€™t never loved me, since my old man died.â€
â€œWhere was you raised?â€ said Tom.
â€œUp in Kentuck. A man kept me to breed chilâ€™en for market, and sold â€™em as fast as they got big enough; last of all, he sold me to a speculator, and my Masâ€™r got me oâ€™ him.â€
â€œWhat set you into this bad way of drinkinâ€™?â€

â€œTo get shet oâ€™ my misery. I had one child after I come here; and I thought then Iâ€™d have one to raise, cause Masâ€™r wasnâ€™t a speculator. It was de peartest little thing! and Missis she seemed to think a heap on â€™t, at first; it never cried,â€”it was likely and fat. But Missis tuck sick, and I tended her; and I tuck the fever, and my milk all left me, and the child it pined to skin and bone, and Missis wouldnâ€™t buy milk for it. She wouldnâ€™t hear to me, when I telled her I hadnâ€™t milk. She said she knowed I could feed it on what other folks eat; and the child kinder pined, and cried, and cried, and cried, day and night, and got all gone to skin and bones, and Missis got sot agin it and she said â€™t wanâ€™t nothinâ€™ but crossness. She wished it was dead, she said; and she wouldnâ€™t let me have it oâ€™ nights, cause, she said, it kept me awake, and made me good for nothing. She made me sleep in her room; and I had to put it away off in a little kind oâ€™ garret, and thar it cried itself to death, one night. It did; and I tuck to drinkinâ€™, to keep its crying out of my ears! I did,â€”and I will drink! I will, if I do go to torment for it! Masâ€™r says I shall go to torment, and I tell him Iâ€™ve got thar now!â€

â€œO, ye poor crittur!â€ said Tom, â€œhanâ€™t nobody never telled ye how the Lord Jesus loved ye, and died for ye? Hanâ€™t they telled ye that heâ€™ll help ye, and ye can go to heaven, and have rest, at last?â€

â€œI looks like gwine to heaven,â€ said the woman; â€œanâ€™t thar where white folks is gwine? Sâ€™pose theyâ€™d have me thar? Iâ€™d rather go to torment, and get away from Masâ€™r and Missis. I had so,â€ she said, as with her usual groan, she got her basket on her head, and walked sullenly away.
Tom turned, and walked sorrowfully back to the house. In the court he met little Eva,â€”a crown of tuberoses on her head, and her eyes radiant with delight.

â€œO, Tom! here you are. Iâ€™m glad Iâ€™ve found you. Papa says you may get out the ponies, and take me in my little new carriage,â€ she said, catching his hand. â€œBut whatâ€™s the matter Tom?â€”you look sober.â€
â€œI feel bad, Miss Eva,â€ said Tom, sorrowfully. â€œBut Iâ€™ll get the horses for you.â€
â€œBut do tell me, Tom, what is the matter. I saw you talking to cross old Prue.â€

Tom, in simple, earnest phrase, told Eva the womanâ€™s history. She did not exclaim or wonder, or weep, as other children do. Her cheeks grew pale, and a deep, earnest shadow passed over her eyes. She laid both hands on her bosom, and sighed heavily.

div.head:
Chapter XIX
Miss Opheliaâ€™s Experiences and Opinions Continued
div.p: â€œTom, you neednâ€™t get me the horses. I donâ€™t want to go,â€ she said.
â€œWhy not, Miss Eva?â€
â€œThese things sink into my heart, Tom,â€ said Eva,â€”â€œthey sink into my heart,â€ she repeated, earnestly. â€œI donâ€™t want to go;â€ and she turned from Tom, and went into the house.
A few days after, another woman came, in old Prueâ€™s place, to bring the rusks; Miss Ophelia was in the kitchen.
â€œLor!â€ said Dinah, â€œwhatâ€™s got Prue?â€
â€œPrue isnâ€™t coming any more,â€ said the woman, mysteriously.
â€œWhy not?â€ said Dinah, â€œshe anâ€™t dead, is she?â€
â€œWe doesnâ€™t exactly know. Sheâ€™s down cellar,â€ said the woman, glancing at Miss Ophelia.
After Miss Ophelia had taken the rusks, Dinah followed the woman to the door.
â€œWhat has got Prue, any how?â€ she said.
The woman seemed desirous, yet reluctant, to speak, and answered, in low, mysterious tone.

â€œWell, you mustnâ€™t tell nobody, Prue, she got drunk agin,â€”and they had her down cellar,â€”and thar they left her all day,â€”and I hearn â€™em saying that the flies had got to her,â€”and sheâ€™s dead!â€
Dinah held up her hands, and, turning, saw close by her side the spirit-like form of Evangeline, her large, mystic eyes dilated with horror, and every drop of blood driven from her lips and cheeks.
â€œLor bless us! Miss Evaâ€™s gwine to faint away! What go us all, to let her har such talk? Her paâ€™ll be rail mad.â€
â€œI shanâ€™t faint, Dinah,â€ said the child, firmly; â€œand why shouldnâ€™t I hear it? It anâ€™t so much for me to hear it, as for poor Prue to suffer it.â€
â€œLor sakes! it isnâ€™t for sweet, delicate young ladies, like you,â€”these yer stories isnâ€™t; itâ€™s enough to kill â€™em!â€
Eva sighed again, and walked up stairs with a slow and melancholy step.
Miss Ophelia anxiously inquired the womanâ€™s story. Dinah gave a very garrulous version of it, to which Tom added the particulars which he had drawn from her that morning.
â€œAn abominable business,â€”perfectly horrible!â€ she exclaimed, as she entered the room where St. Clare lay reading his paper.
â€œPray, what iniquity has turned up now?â€ said he.
â€œWhat now? why, those folks have whipped Prue to death!â€ said Miss Ophelia, going on, with great strength of detail, into the story, and enlarging on its most shocking particulars.
â€œI thought it would come to that, some time,â€ said St. Clare, going on with his paper.
â€œThought so!â€”anâ€™t you going to do anything about it?â€ said Miss Ophelia. â€œHavenâ€™t you got any selectmen, or anybody, to interfere and look after such matters?â€

â€œItâ€™s commonly supposed that the property interest is a sufficient guard in these cases. If people choose to ruin their own possessions, I donâ€™t know whatâ€™s to be done. It seems the poor creature was a thief and a drunkard; and so there wonâ€™t be much hope to get up sympathy for her.â€
â€œIt is perfectly outrageous,â€”it is horrid, Augustine! It will certainly bring down vengeance upon you.â€

â€œMy dear cousin, I didnâ€™t do it, and I canâ€™t help it; I would, if I could. If low-minded, brutal people will act like themselves, what am I to do? they have absolute control; they are irresponsible despots. There would be no use in interfering; there is no law that amounts to anything practically, for such a case. The best we can do is to shut our eyes and ears, and let it alone. Itâ€™s the only resource left us.â€
â€œHow can you shut your eyes and ears? How can you let such things alone?â€

â€œMy dear child, what do you expect? Here is a whole class,â€”debased, uneducated, indolent, provoking,â€”put, without any sort of terms or conditions, entirely into the hands of such people as the majority in our world are; people who have neither consideration nor self-control, who havenâ€™t even an enlightened regard to their own interest,â€”for thatâ€™s the case with the largest half of mankind. Of course, in a community so organized, what can a man of honorable and humane feelings do, but shut his eyes all he can, and harden his heart? I canâ€™t buy every poor wretch I see. I canâ€™t turn knight-errant, and undertake to redress every individual case of wrong in such a city as this. The most I can do is to try and keep out of the way of it.â€
St. Clareâ€™s fine countenance was for a moment overcast; he said,

â€œCome, cousin, donâ€™t stand there looking like one of the Fates; youâ€™ve only seen a peep through the curtain,â€”a specimen of what is going on, the world over, in some shape or other. If we are to be prying and spying into all the dismals of life, we should have no heart to anything. â€™T is like looking too close into the details of Dinahâ€™s kitchen;â€ and St. Clare lay back on the sofa, and busied himself with his paper.

Miss Ophelia sat down, and pulled out her knitting-work, and sat there grim with indignation. She knit and knit, but while she mused the fire burned; at last she broke outâ€”â€œI tell you, Augustine, I canâ€™t get over things so, if you can. Itâ€™s a perfect abomination for you to defend such a system,â€”thatâ€™s my mind!â€
â€œWhat now?â€ said St. Clare, looking up. â€œAt it again, hey?â€
â€œI say itâ€™s perfectly abominable for you to defend such a system!â€ said Miss Ophelia, with increasing warmth.
â€œI defend it, my dear lady? Who ever said I did defend it?â€ said St. Clare.
â€œOf course, you defend it,â€”you all do,â€”all you Southerners. What do you have slaves for, if you donâ€™t?â€
â€œAre you such a sweet innocent as to suppose nobody in this world ever does what they donâ€™t think is right? Donâ€™t you, or didnâ€™t you ever, do anything that you did not think quite right?â€
â€œIf I do, I repent of it, I hope,â€ said Miss Ophelia, rattling her needles with energy.
â€œSo do I,â€ said St. Clare, peeling his orange; â€œIâ€™m repenting of it all the time.â€
â€œWhat do you keep on doing it for?â€
â€œDidnâ€™t you ever keep on doing wrong, after youâ€™d repented, my good cousin?â€
â€œWell, only when Iâ€™ve been very much tempted,â€ said Miss Ophelia.
â€œWell, Iâ€™m very much tempted,â€ said St. Clare; â€œthatâ€™s just my difficulty.â€
â€œBut I always resolve I wonâ€™t and I try to break off.â€
â€œWell, I have been resolving I wonâ€™t, off and on, these ten years,â€ said St. Clare; â€œbut I havenâ€™t, some how, got clear. Have you got clear of all your sins, cousin?â€

â€œCousin Augustine,â€ said Miss Ophelia, seriously, and laying down her knitting-work, â€œI suppose I deserve that you should reprove my short-comings. I know all you say is true enough; nobody else feels them more than I do; but it does seem to me, after all, there is some difference between me and you. It seems to me I would cut off my right hand sooner than keep on, from day to day, doing what I thought was wrong. But, then, my conduct is so inconsistent with my profession, I donâ€™t wonder you reprove me.â€

â€œO, now, cousin,â€ said Augustine, sitting down on the floor, and laying his head back in her lap, â€œdonâ€™t take on so awfully serious! You know what a good-for-nothing, saucy boy I always was. I love to poke you up,â€”thatâ€™s all,â€”just to see you get earnest. I do think you are desperately, distressingly good; it tires me to death to think of it.â€
â€œBut this is a serious subject, my boy, Auguste,â€ said Miss Ophelia, laying her hand on his forehead.

â€œDismally so,â€ said he; â€œand Iâ€”well, I never want to talk seriously in hot weather. What with mosquitos and all, a fellow canâ€™t get himself up to any very sublime moral flights; and I believe,â€ said St. Clare, suddenly rousing himself up, â€œthereâ€™s a theory, now! I understand now why northern nations are always more virtuous than southern ones,â€”I see into that whole subject.â€
â€œO, Augustine, you are a sad rattle-brain!â€

â€œAm I? Well, so I am, I suppose; but for once I will be serious, now; but you must hand me that basket of oranges;â€”you see, youâ€™ll have to â€˜stay me with flagons and comfort me with apples,â€™ if Iâ€™m going to make this effort. Now,â€ said Augustine, drawing the basket up, â€œIâ€™ll begin: When, in the course of human events, it becomes necessary for a fellow to hold two or three dozen of his fellow-worms in captivity, a decent regard to the opinions of society requiresâ€”â€
â€œI donâ€™t see that you are growing more serious,â€ said Miss Ophelia.

â€œWait,â€”Iâ€™m coming on,â€”youâ€™ll hear. The short of the matter is, cousin,â€ said he, his handsome face suddenly settling into an earnest and serious expression, â€œon this abstract question of slavery there can, as I think, be but one opinion. Planters, who have money to make by it,â€”clergymen, who have planters to please,â€”politicians, who want to rule by it,â€”may warp and bend language and ethics to a degree that shall astonish the world at their ingenuity; they can press nature and the Bible, and nobody knows what else, into the service; but, after all, neither they nor the world believe in it one particle the more. It comes from the devil, thatâ€™s the short of it;â€”and, to my mind, itâ€™s a pretty respectable specimen of what he can do in his own line.â€
Miss Ophelia stopped her knitting, and looked surprised, and St. Clare, apparently enjoying her astonishment, went on.

â€œYou seem to wonder; but if you will get me fairly at it, Iâ€™ll make a clean breast of it. This cursed business, accursed of God and man, what is it? Strip it of all its ornament, run it down to the root and nucleus of the whole, and what is it? Why, because my brother Quashy is ignorant and weak, and I am intelligent and strong,â€”because I know how, and can do it,â€”therefore, I may steal all he has, keep it, and give him only such and so much as suits my fancy. Whatever is too hard, too dirty, too disagreeable, for me, I may set Quashy to doing. Because I donâ€™t like work, Quashy shall work. Because the sun burns me, Quashy shall stay in the sun. Quashy shall earn the money, and I will spend it. Quashy shall lie down in every puddle, that I may walk over dry-shod. Quashy shall do my will, and not his, all the days of his mortal life, and have such chance of getting to heaven, at last, as I find convenient. This I take to be about what slavery is. I defy anybody on earth to read our slave-code, as it stands in our law-books, and make anything else of it. Talk of the abuses of slavery! Humbug! The thing itself is the essence of all abuse! And the only reason why the land donâ€™t sink under it, like Sodom and Gomorrah, is because it is used in a way infinitely better than it is. For pityâ€™s sake, for shameâ€™s sake, because we are men born of women, and not savage beasts, many of us do not, and dare not,â€”we would scorn to use the full power which our savage laws put into our hands. And he who goes the furthest, and does the worst, only uses within limits the power that the law gives him.â€

St. Clare had started up, and, as his manner was when excited, was walking, with hurried steps, up and down the floor. His fine face, classic as that of a Greek statue, seemed actually to burn with the fervor of his feelings. His large blue eyes flashed, and he gestured with an unconscious eagerness. Miss Ophelia had never seen him in this mood before, and she sat perfectly silent.

â€œI declare to you,â€ said he, suddenly stopping before his cousin â€œ(Itâ€™s no sort of use to talk or to feel on this subject), but I declare to you, there have been times when I have thought, if the whole country would sink, and hide all this injustice and misery from the light, I would willingly sink with it. When I have been travelling up and down on our boats, or about on my collecting tours, and reflected that every brutal, disgusting, mean, low-lived fellow I met, was allowed by our laws to become absolute despot of as many men, women and children, as he could cheat, steal, or gamble money enough to buy,â€”when I have seen such men in actual ownership of helpless children, of young girls and women,â€”I have been ready to curse my country, to curse the human race!â€
â€œAugustine! Augustine!â€ said Miss Ophelia, â€œIâ€™m sure youâ€™ve said enough. I never, in my life, heard anything like this, even at the North.â€

â€œAt the North!â€ said St. Clare, with a sudden change of expression, and resuming something of his habitual careless tone. â€œPooh! your northern folks are cold-blooded; you are cool in everything! You canâ€™t begin to curse up hill and down as we can, when we get fairly at it.â€
â€œWell, but the question is,â€ said Miss Ophelia.

â€œO, yes, to be sure, the question is,â€”and a deuce of a question it is! How came you in this state of sin and misery? Well, I shall answer in the good old words you used to teach me, Sundays. I came so by ordinary generation. My servants were my fatherâ€™s, and, what is more, my motherâ€™s; and now they are mine, they and their increase, which bids fair to be a pretty considerable item. My father, you know, came first from New England; and he was just such another man as your father,â€”a regular old Roman,â€”upright, energetic, noble-minded, with an iron will. Your father settled down in New England, to rule over rocks and stones, and to force an existence out of Nature; and mine settled in Louisiana, to rule over men and women, and force existence out of them. My mother,â€ said St. Clare, getting up and walking to a picture at the end of the room, and gazing upward with a face fervent with veneration, â€œshe was divine! Donâ€™t look at me so!â€”you know what I mean! She probably was of mortal birth; but, as far as ever I could observe, there was no trace of any human weakness or error about her; and everybody that lives to remember her, whether bond or free, servant, acquaintance, relation, all say the same. Why, cousin, that mother has been all that has stood between me and utter unbelief for years. She was a direct embodiment and personification of the New Testament,â€”a living fact, to be accounted for, and to be accounted for in no other way than by its truth. O, mother! mother!â€ said St. Clare, clasping his hands, in a sort of transport; and then suddenly checking himself, he came back, and seating himself on an ottoman, he went on:

â€œMy brother and I were twins; and they say, you know, that twins ought to resemble each other; but we were in all points a contrast. He had black, fiery eyes, coal-black hair, a strong, fine Roman profile, and a rich brown complexion. I had blue eyes, golden hair, a Greek outline, and fair complexion. He was active and observing, I dreamy and inactive. He was generous to his friends and equals, but proud, dominant, overbearing, to inferiors, and utterly unmerciful to whatever set itself up against him. Truthful we both were; he from pride and courage, I from a sort of abstract ideality. We loved each other about as boys generally do,â€”off and on, and in general;â€”he was my fatherâ€™s pet, and I my motherâ€™s.

â€œThere was a morbid sensitiveness and acuteness of feeling in me on all possible subjects, of which he and my father had no kind of understanding, and with which they could have no possible sympathy. But mother did; and so, when I had quarreled with Alfred, and father looked sternly on me, I used to go off to motherâ€™s room, and sit by her. I remember just how she used to look, with her pale cheeks, her deep, soft, serious eyes, her white dress,â€”she always wore white; and I used to think of her whenever I read in Revelations about the saints that were arrayed in fine linen, clean and white. She had a great deal of genius of one sort and another, particularly in music; and she used to sit at her organ, playing fine old majestic music of the Catholic church, and singing with a voice more like an angel than a mortal woman; and I would lay my head down on her lap, and cry, and dream, and feel,â€”oh, immeasurably!â€”things that I had no language to say!
â€œIn those days, this matter of slavery had never been canvassed as it has now; nobody dreamed of any harm in it.

â€œMy father was a born aristocrat. I think, in some preexistent state, he must have been in the higher circles of spirits, and brought all his old court pride along with him; for it was ingrain, bred in the bone, though he was originally of poor and not in any way of noble family. My brother was begotten in his image.

â€œNow, an aristocrat, you know, the world over, has no human sympathies, beyond a certain line in society. In England the line is in one place, in Burmah in another, and in America in another; but the aristocrat of all these countries never goes over it. What would be hardship and distress and injustice in his own class, is a cool matter of course in another one. My fatherâ€™s dividing line was that of color. Among his equals, never was a man more just and generous; but he considered the negro, through all possible gradations of color, as an intermediate link between man and animals, and graded all his ideas of justice or generosity on this hypothesis. I suppose, to be sure, if anybody had asked him, plump and fair, whether they had human immortal souls, he might have hemmed and hawed, and said yes. But my father was not a man much troubled with spiritualism; religious sentiment he had none, beyond a veneration for God, as decidedly the head of the upper classes.

â€œWell, my father worked some five hundred negroes; he was an inflexible, driving, punctilious business man; everything was to move by system,â€”to be sustained with unfailing accuracy and precision. Now, if you take into account that all this was to be worked out by a set of lazy, twaddling, shiftless laborers, who had grown up, all their lives, in the absence of every possible motive to learn how to do anything but â€˜shirk,â€™ as you Vermonters say, and youâ€™ll see that there might naturally be, on his plantation, a great many things that looked horrible and distressing to a sensitive child, like me.

â€œBesides all, he had an overseer,â€”great, tall, slab-sided, two-fisted renegade son of Vermontâ€”(begging your pardon),â€”who had gone through a regular apprenticeship in hardness and brutality and taken his degree to be admitted to practice. My mother never could endure him, nor I; but he obtained an entire ascendency over my father; and this man was the absolute despot of the estate.

â€œI was a little fellow then, but I had the same love that I have now for all kinds of human things,â€”a kind of passion for the study of humanity, come in what shape it would. I was found in the cabins and among the field-hands a great deal, and, of course, was a great favorite; and all sorts of complaints and grievances were breathed in my ear; and I told them to mother, and we, between us, formed a sort of committee for a redress of grievances. We hindered and repressed a great deal of cruelty, and congratulated ourselves on doing a vast deal of good, till, as often happens, my zeal overacted. Stubbs complained to my father that he couldnâ€™t manage the hands, and must resign his position. Father was a fond, indulgent husband, but a man that never flinched from anything that he thought necessary; and so he put down his foot, like a rock, between us and the field-hands. He told my mother, in language perfectly respectful and deferential, but quite explicit, that over the house-servants she should be entire mistress, but that with the field-hands he could allow no interference. He revered and respected her above all living beings; but he would have said it all the same to the virgin Mary herself, if she had come in the way of his system.

â€œI used sometimes to hear my mother reasoning cases with him,â€”endeavoring to excite his sympathies. He would listen to the most pathetic appeals with the most discouraging politeness and equanimity. â€˜It all resolves itself into this,â€™ he would say; â€˜must I part with Stubbs, or keep him? Stubbs is the soul of punctuality, honesty, and efficiency,â€”a thorough business hand, and as humane as the general run. We canâ€™t have perfection; and if I keep him, I must sustain his administration as a whole, even if there are, now and then, things that are exceptionable. All government includes some necessary hardness. General rules will bear hard on particular cases.â€™ This last maxim my father seemed to consider a settler in most alleged cases of cruelty. After he had said that, he commonly drew up his feet on the sofa, like a man that has disposed of a business, and betook himself to a nap, or the newspaper, as the case might be.

â€œThe fact is my father showed the exact sort of talent for a statesman. He could have divided Poland as easily as an orange, or trod on Ireland as quietly and systematically as any man living. At last my mother gave up, in despair. It never will be known, till the last account, what noble and sensitive natures like hers have felt, cast, utterly helpless, into what seems to them an abyss of injustice and cruelty, and which seems so to nobody about them. It has been an age of long sorrow of such natures, in such a hell-begotten sort of world as ours. What remained for her, but to train her children in her own views and sentiments? Well, after all you say about training, children will grow up substantially what they are by nature, and only that. From the cradle, Alfred was an aristocrat; and as he grew up, instinctively, all his sympathies and all his reasonings were in that line, and all motherâ€™s exhortations went to the winds. As to me, they sunk deep into me. She never contradicted, in form, anything my father said, or seemed directly to differ from him; but she impressed, burnt into my very soul, with all the force of her deep, earnest nature, an idea of the dignity and worth of the meanest human soul. I have looked in her face with solemn awe, when she would point up to the stars in the evening, and say to me, â€™See there, Auguste! the poorest, meanest soul on our place will be living, when all these stars are gone forever,â€”will live as long as God lives!â€™

â€œShe had some fine old paintings; one, in particular, of Jesus healing a blind man. They were very fine, and used to impress me strongly. â€˜See there, Auguste,â€™ she would say; â€˜the blind man was a beggar, poor and loathsome; therefore, he would not heal him afar off! He called him to him, and put his hands on him! Remember this, my boy.â€™ If I had lived to grow up under her care, she might have stimulated me to I know not what of enthusiasm. I might have been a saint, reformer, martyr,â€”but, alas! alas! I went from her when I was only thirteen, and I never saw her again!â€
St. Clare rested his head on his hands, and did not speak for some minutes. After a while, he looked up, and went on:

â€œWhat poor, mean trash this whole business of human virtue is! A mere matter, for the most part, of latitude and longitude, and geographical position, acting with natural temperament. The greater part is nothing but an accident! Your father, for example, settles in Vermont, in a town where all are, in fact, free and equal; becomes a regular church member and deacon, and in due time joins an Abolition society, and thinks us all little better than heathens. Yet he is, for all the world, in constitution and habit, a duplicate of my father. I can see it leaking out in fifty different ways,â€”just the same strong, overbearing, dominant spirit. You know very well how impossible it is to persuade some of the folks in your village that Squire Sinclair does not feel above them. The fact is, though he has fallen on democratic times, and embraced a democratic theory, he is to the heart an aristocrat, as much as my father, who ruled over five or six hundred slaves.â€
Miss Ophelia felt rather disposed to cavil at this picture, and was laying down her knitting to begin, but St. Clare stopped her.

â€œNow, I know every word you are going to say. I do not say they were alike, in fact. One fell into a condition where everything acted against the natural tendency, and the other where everything acted for it; and so one turned out a pretty wilful, stout, overbearing old democrat, and the other a wilful, stout old despot. If both had owned plantations in Louisiana, they would have been as like as two old bullets cast in the same mould.â€
â€œWhat an undutiful boy you are!â€ said Miss Ophelia.
â€œI donâ€™t mean them any disrespect,â€ said St. Clare. â€œYou know reverence is not my forte. But, to go back to my history:

â€œWhen father died, he left the whole property to us twin boys, to be divided as we should agree. There does not breathe on Godâ€™s earth a nobler-souled, more generous fellow, than Alfred, in all that concerns his equals; and we got on admirably with this property question, without a single unbrotherly word or feeling. We undertook to work the plantation together; and Alfred, whose outward life and capabilities had double the strength of mine, became an enthusiastic planter, and a wonderfully successful one.

â€œBut two yearsâ€™ trial satisfied me that I could not be a partner in that matter. To have a great gang of seven hundred, whom I could not know personally, or feel any individual interest in, bought and driven, housed, fed, worked like so many horned cattle, strained up to military precision,â€”the question of how little of lifeâ€™s commonest enjoyments would keep them in working order being a constantly recurring problem,â€”the necessity of drivers and overseers,â€”the ever-necessary whip, first, last, and only argument,â€”the whole thing was insufferably disgusting and loathsome to me; and when I thought of my motherâ€™s estimate of one poor human soul, it became even frightful!

â€œItâ€™s all nonsense to talk to me about slaves enjoying all this! To this day, I have no patience with the unutterable trash that some of your patronizing Northerners have made up, as in their zeal to apologize for our sins. We all know better. Tell me that any man living wants to work all his days, from day-dawn till dark, under the constant eye of a master, without the power of putting forth one irresponsible volition, on the same dreary, monotonous, unchanging toil, and all for two pairs of pantaloons and a pair of shoes a year, with enough food and shelter to keep him in working order! Any man who thinks that human beings can, as a general thing, be made about as comfortable that way as any other, I wish he might try it. Iâ€™d buy the dog, and work him, with a clear conscience!â€
â€œI always have supposed,â€ said Miss Ophelia, â€œthat you, all of you, approved of these things, and thought them rightâ€”according to Scripture.â€

â€œHumbug! We are not quite reduced to that yet. Alfred who is as determined a despot as ever walked, does not pretend to this kind of defence;â€”no, he stands, high and haughty, on that good old respectable ground, the right of the strongest; and he says, and I think quite sensibly, that the American planter is â€˜only doing, in another form, what the English aristocracy and capitalists are doing by the lower classes;â€™ that is, I take it, appropriating them, body and bone, soul and spirit, to their use and convenience. He defends both,â€”and I think, at least, consistently. He says that there can be no high civilization without enslavement of the masses, either nominal or real. There must, he says, be a lower class, given up to physical toil and confined to an animal nature; and a higher one thereby acquires leisure and wealth for a more expanded intelligence and improvement, and becomes the directing soul of the lower. So he reasons, because, as I said, he is born an aristocrat;â€”so I donâ€™t believe, because I was born a democrat.â€
â€œHow in the world can the two things be compared?â€ said Miss Ophelia. â€œThe English laborer is not sold, traded, parted from his family, whipped.â€

â€œHe is as much at the will of his employer as if he were sold to him. The slave-owner can whip his refractory slave to death,â€”the capitalist can starve him to death. As to family security, it is hard to say which is the worst,â€”to have oneâ€™s children sold, or see them starve to death at home.â€
â€œBut itâ€™s no kind of apology for slavery, to prove that it isnâ€™t worse than some other bad thing.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t give it for one,â€”nay, Iâ€™ll say, besides, that ours is the more bold and palpable infringement of human rights; actually buying a man up, like a horse,â€”looking at his teeth, cracking his joints, and trying his paces and then paying down for him,â€”having speculators, breeders, traders, and brokers in human bodies and souls,â€”sets the thing before the eyes of the civilized world in a more tangible form, though the thing done be, after all, in its nature, the same; that is, appropriating one set of human beings to the use and improvement of another without any regard to their own.â€
â€œI never thought of the matter in this light,â€ said Miss Ophelia.

â€œWell, Iâ€™ve travelled in England some, and Iâ€™ve looked over a good many documents as to the state of their lower classes; and I really think there is no denying Alfred, when he says that his slaves are better off than a large class of the population of England. You see, you must not infer, from what I have told you, that Alfred is what is called a hard master; for he isnâ€™t. He is despotic, and unmerciful to insubordination; he would shoot a fellow down with as little remorse as he would shoot a buck, if he opposed him. But, in general, he takes a sort of pride in having his slaves comfortably fed and accommodated.

â€œWhen I was with him, I insisted that he should do something for their instruction; and, to please me, he did get a chaplain, and used to have them catechized Sunday, though, I believe, in his heart, that he thought it would do about as much good to set a chaplain over his dogs and horses. And the fact is, that a mind stupefied and animalized by every bad influence from the hour of birth, spending the whole of every week-day in unreflecting toil, cannot be done much with by a few hours on Sunday. The teachers of Sunday-schools among the manufacturing population of England, and among plantation-hands in our country, could perhaps testify to the same result, there and here. Yet some striking exceptions there are among us, from the fact that the negro is naturally more impressible to religious sentiment than the white.â€
â€œWell,â€ said Miss Ophelia, â€œhow came you to give up your plantation life?â€

â€œWell, we jogged on together some time, till Alfred saw plainly that I was no planter. He thought it absurd, after he had reformed, and altered, and improved everywhere, to suit my notions, that I still remained unsatisfied. The fact was, it was, after all, the THING that I hatedâ€”the using these men and women, the perpetuation of all this ignorance, brutality and vice,â€”just to make money for me!

â€œBesides, I was always interfering in the details. Being myself one of the laziest of mortals, I had altogether too much fellow-feeling for the lazy; and when poor, shiftless dogs put stones at the bottom of their cotton-baskets to make them weigh heavier, or filled their sacks with dirt, with cotton at the top, it seemed so exactly like what I should do if I were they, I couldnâ€™t and wouldnâ€™t have them flogged for it. Well, of course, there was an end of plantation discipline; and Alf and I came to about the same point that I and my respected father did, years before. So he told me that I was a womanish sentimentalist, and would never do for business life; and advised me to take the bank-stock and the New Orleans family mansion, and go to writing poetry, and let him manage the plantation. So we parted, and I came here.â€
â€œBut why didnâ€™t you free your slaves?â€

â€œWell, I wasnâ€™t up to that. To hold them as tools for money-making, I could not;â€”have them to help spend money, you know, didnâ€™t look quite so ugly to me. Some of them were old house-servants, to whom I was much attached; and the younger ones were children to the old. All were well satisfied to be as they were.â€ He paused, and walked reflectively up and down the room.

â€œThere was,â€ said St. Clare, â€œa time in my life when I had plans and hopes of doing something in this world, more than to float and drift. I had vague, indistinct yearnings to be a sort of emancipator,â€”to free my native land from this spot and stain. All young men have had such fever-fits, I suppose, some time,â€”but thenâ€”â€
â€œWhy didnâ€™t you?â€ said Miss Ophelia;â€”â€œyou ought not to put your hand to the plough, and look back.â€

â€œO, well, things didnâ€™t go with me as I expected, and I got the despair of living that Solomon did. I suppose it was a necessary incident to wisdom in us both; but, some how or other, instead of being actor and regenerator in society, I became a piece of driftwood, and have been floating and eddying about, ever since. Alfred scolds me, every time we meet; and he has the better of me, I grant,â€”for he really does something; his life is a logical result of his opinions and mine is a contemptible non sequitur.â€
â€œMy dear cousin, can you be satisfied with such a way of spending your probation?â€

â€œSatisfied! Was I not just telling you I despised it? But, then, to come back to this point,â€”we were on this liberation business. I donâ€™t think my feelings about slavery are peculiar. I find many men who, in their hearts, think of it just as I do. The land groans under it; and, bad as it is for the slave, it is worse, if anything, for the master. It takes no spectacles to see that a great class of vicious, improvident, degraded people, among us, are an evil to us, as well as to themselves. The capitalist and aristocrat of England cannot feel that as we do, because they do not mingle with the class they degrade as we do. They are in our homes; they are the associates of our children, and they form their minds faster than we can; for they are a race that children always will cling to and assimilate with. If Eva, now, was not more angel than ordinary, she would be ruined. We might as well allow the small-pox to run among them, and think our children would not take it, as to let them be uninstructed and vicious, and think our children will not be affected by that. Yet our laws positively and utterly forbid any efficient general educational system, and they do it wisely, too; for, just begin and thoroughly educate one generation, and the whole thing would be blown sky high. If we did not give them liberty, they would take it.â€
â€œAnd what do you think will be the end of this?â€ said Miss Ophelia.

â€œI donâ€™t know. One thing is certain,â€”that there is a mustering among the masses, the world over; and there is a dies irÃ¦ coming on, sooner or later. The same thing is working in Europe, in England, and in this country. My mother used to tell me of a millennium that was coming, when Christ should reign, and all men should be free and happy. And she taught me, when I was a boy, to pray, â€™thy kingdom come.â€™ Sometimes I think all this sighing, and groaning, and stirring among the dry bones foretells what she used to tell me was coming. But who may abide the day of His appearing?â€
â€œAugustine, sometimes I think you are not far from the kingdom,â€ said Miss Ophelia, laying down her knitting, and looking anxiously at her cousin.

â€œThank you for your good opinion, but itâ€™s up and down with me,â€”up to heavenâ€™s gate in theory, down in earthâ€™s dust in practice. But thereâ€™s the teabell,â€”do letâ€™s go,â€”and donâ€™t say, now, I havenâ€™t had one downright serious talk, for once in my life.â€
At table, Marie alluded to the incident of Prue. â€œI suppose youâ€™ll think, cousin,â€ she said, â€œthat we are all barbarians.â€
â€œI think thatâ€™s a barbarous thing,â€ said Miss Ophelia, â€œbut I donâ€™t think you are all barbarians.â€

â€œWell, now,â€ said Marie, â€œI know itâ€™s impossible to get along with some of these creatures. They are so bad they ought not to live. I donâ€™t feel a particle of sympathy for such cases. If theyâ€™d only behave themselves, it would not happen.â€
â€œBut, mamma,â€ said Eva, â€œthe poor creature was unhappy; thatâ€™s what made her drink.â€

â€œO, fiddlestick! as if that were any excuse! Iâ€™m unhappy, very often. I presume,â€ she said, pensively, â€œthat Iâ€™ve had greater trials than ever she had. Itâ€™s just because they are so bad. Thereâ€™s some of them that you cannot break in by any kind of severity. I remember father had a man that was so lazy he would run away just to get rid of work, and lie round in the swamps, stealing and doing all sorts of horrid things. That man was caught and whipped, time and again, and it never did him any good; and the last time he crawled off, though he couldnâ€™t but just go, and died in the swamp. There was no sort of reason for it, for fatherâ€™s hands were always treated kindly.â€
â€œI broke a fellow in, once,â€ said St. Clare, â€œthat all the overseers and masters had tried their hands on in vain.â€
â€œYou!â€ said Marie; â€œwell, Iâ€™d be glad to know when you ever did anything of the sort.â€

â€œWell, he was a powerful, gigantic fellow,â€”a native-born African; and he appeared to have the rude instinct of freedom in him to an uncommon degree. He was a regular African lion. They called him Scipio. Nobody could do anything with him; and he was sold round from overseer to overseer, till at last Alfred bought him, because he thought he could manage him. Well, one day he knocked down the overseer, and was fairly off into the swamps. I was on a visit to Alfâ€™s plantation, for it was after we had dissolved partnership. Alfred was greatly exasperated; but I told him that it was his own fault, and laid him any wager that I could break the man; and finally it was agreed that, if I caught him, I should have him to experiment on. So they mustered out a party of some six or seven, with guns and dogs, for the hunt. People, you know, can get up as much enthusiasm in hunting a man as a deer, if it is only customary; in fact, I got a little excited myself, though I had only put in as a sort of mediator, in case he was caught.

â€œWell, the dogs bayed and howled, and we rode and scampered, and finally we started him. He ran and bounded like a buck, and kept us well in the rear for some time; but at last he got caught in an impenetrable thicket of cane; then he turned to bay, and I tell you he fought the dogs right gallantly. He dashed them to right and left, and actually killed three of them with only his naked fists, when a shot from a gun brought him down, and he fell, wounded and bleeding, almost at my feet. The poor fellow looked up at me with manhood and despair both in his eye. I kept back the dogs and the party, as they came pressing up, and claimed him as my prisoner. It was all I could do to keep them from shooting him, in the flush of success; but I persisted in my bargain, and Alfred sold him to me. Well, I took him in hand, and in one fortnight I had him tamed down as submissive and tractable as heart could desire.â€
â€œWhat in the world did you do to him?â€ said Marie.

â€œWell, it was quite a simple process. I took him to my own room, had a good bed made for him, dressed his wounds, and tended him myself, until he got fairly on his feet again. And, in process of time, I had free papers made out for him, and told him he might go where he liked.â€
â€œAnd did he go?â€ said Miss Ophelia.

â€œNo. The foolish fellow tore the paper in two, and absolutely refused to leave me. I never had a braver, better fellow,â€”trusty and true as steel. He embraced Christianity afterwards, and became as gentle as a child. He used to oversee my place on the lake, and did it capitally, too. I lost him the first cholera season. In fact, he laid down his life for me. For I was sick, almost to death; and when, through the panic, everybody else fled, Scipio worked for me like a giant, and actually brought me back into life again. But, poor fellow! he was taken, right after, and there was no saving him. I never felt anybodyâ€™s loss more.â€
Eva had come gradually nearer and nearer to her father, as he told the story,â€”her small lips apart, her eyes wide and earnest with absorbing interest.
As he finished, she suddenly threw her arms around his neck, burst into tears, and sobbed convulsively.

â€œEva, dear child! what is the matter?â€ said St. Clare, as the childâ€™s small frame trembled and shook with the violence of her feelings. â€œThis child,â€ he added, â€œought not to hear any of this kind of thing,â€”sheâ€™s nervous.â€
â€œNo, papa, Iâ€™m not nervous,â€ said Eva, controlling herself, suddenly, with a strength of resolution singular in such a child. â€œIâ€™m not nervous, but these things sink into my heart.â€
â€œWhat do you mean, Eva?â€
â€œI canâ€™t tell you, papa, I think a great many thoughts. Perhaps some day I shall tell you.â€
â€œWell, think away, dear,â€”only donâ€™t cry and worry your papa,â€ said St. Clare, â€œLook here,â€”see what a beautiful peach I have got for you.â€
Eva took it and smiled, though there was still a nervous twiching about the corners of her mouth.

â€œCome, look at the gold-fish,â€ said St. Clare, taking her hand and stepping on to the verandah. A few moments, and merry laughs were heard through the silken curtains, as Eva and St. Clare were pelting each other with roses, and chasing each other among the alleys of the court.

There is danger that our humble friend Tom be neglected amid the adventures of the higher born; but, if our readers will accompany us up to a little loft over the stable, they may, perhaps, learn a little of his affairs. It was a decent room, containing a bed, a chair, and a small, rough stand, where lay Tomâ€™s Bible and hymn-book; and where he sits, at present, with his slate before him, intent on something that seems to cost him a great deal of anxious thought.

The fact was, that Tomâ€™s home-yearnings had become so strong that he had begged a sheet of writing-paper of Eva, and, mustering up all his small stock of literary attainment acquired by Masâ€™r Georgeâ€™s instructions, he conceived the bold idea of writing a letter; and he was busy now, on his slate, getting out his first draft. Tom was in a good deal of trouble, for the forms of some of the letters he had forgotten entirely; and of what he did remember, he did not know exactly which to use. And while he was working, and breathing very hard, in his earnestness, Eva alighted, like a bird, on the round of his chair behind him, and peeped over his shoulder.
â€œO, Uncle Tom! what funny things you are making, there!â€
â€œIâ€™m trying to write to my poor old woman, Miss Eva, and my little chilâ€™en,â€ said Tom, drawing the back of his hand over his eyes; â€œbut, some how, Iâ€™m feard I shanâ€™t make it out.â€
â€œI wish I could help you, Tom! Iâ€™ve learnt to write some. Last year I could make all the letters, but Iâ€™m afraid Iâ€™ve forgotten.â€

So Eva put her golden head close to his, and the two commenced a grave and anxious discussion, each one equally earnest, and about equally ignorant; and, with a deal of consulting and advising over every word, the composition began, as they both felt very sanguine, to look quite like writing.

â€œYes, Uncle Tom, it really begins to look beautiful,â€ said Eva, gazing delightedly on it. â€œHow pleased your wifeâ€™ll be, and the poor little children! O, itâ€™s a shame you ever had to go away from them! I mean to ask papa to let you go back, some time.â€

â€œMissis said that she would send down money for me, as soon as they could get it together,â€ said Tom. â€œIâ€™m â€™spectin, she will. Young Masâ€™r George, he said heâ€™d come for me; and he gave me this yer dollar as a sign;â€ and Tom drew from under his clothes the precious dollar.
â€œO, heâ€™ll certainly come, then!â€ said Eva. â€œIâ€™m so glad!â€
â€œAnd I wanted to send a letter, you know, to let â€™em know whar I was, and tell poor Chloe that I was well off,â€”cause she felt so drefful, poor soul!â€
â€œI say Tom!â€ said St. Clareâ€™s voice, coming in the door at this moment.
Tom and Eva both started.
â€œWhatâ€™s here?â€ said St. Clare, coming up and looking at the slate.
â€œO, itâ€™s Tomâ€™s letter. Iâ€™m helping him to write it,â€ said Eva; â€œisnâ€™t it nice?â€
â€œI wouldnâ€™t discourage either of you,â€ said St. Clare, â€œbut I rather think, Tom, youâ€™d better get me to write your letter for you. Iâ€™ll do it, when I come home from my ride.â€
â€œItâ€™s very important he should write,â€ said Eva, â€œbecause his mistress is going to send down money to redeem him, you know, papa; he told me they told him so.â€

St. Clare thought, in his heart, that this was probably only one of those things which good-natured owners say to their servants, to alleviate their horror of being sold, without any intention of fulfilling the expectation thus excited. But he did not make any audible comment upon it,â€”only ordered Tom to get the horses out for a ride.
Tomâ€™s letter was written in due form for him that evening, and safely lodged in the post-office.

Miss Ophelia still persevered in her labors in the housekeeping line. It was universally agreed, among all the household, from Dinah down to the youngest urchin, that Miss Ophelia was decidedly â€œcuris,â€â€”a term by which a southern servant implies that his or her betters donâ€™t exactly suit them.

The higher circle in the familyâ€”to wit, Adolph, Jane and Rosaâ€”agreed that she was no lady; ladies never keep working about as she did,â€”that she had no air at all; and they were surprised that she should be any relation of the St. Clares. Even Marie declared that it was absolutely fatiguing to see Cousin Ophelia always so busy. And, in fact, Miss Opheliaâ€™s industry was so incessant as to lay some foundation for the complaint. She sewed and stitched away, from daylight till dark, with the energy of one who is pressed on by some immediate urgency; and then, when the light faded, and the work was folded away, with one turn out came the ever-ready knitting-work, and there she was again, going on as briskly as ever. It really was a labor to see her.

div.head:
Chapter XX
Topsy
div.p: One morning, while Miss Ophelia was busy in some of her domestic cares, St. Clareâ€™s voice was heard, calling her at the foot of the stairs.
â€œCome down here, Cousin, Iâ€™ve something to show you.â€
â€œWhat is it?â€ said Miss Ophelia, coming down, with her sewing in her hand.
â€œIâ€™ve made a purchase for your department,â€”see here,â€ said St. Clare; and, with the word, he pulled along a little negro girl, about eight or nine years of age.

She was one of the blackest of her race; and her round shining eyes, glittering as glass beads, moved with quick and restless glances over everything in the room. Her mouth, half open with astonishment at the wonders of the new Masâ€™râ€™s parlor, displayed a white and brilliant set of teeth. Her woolly hair was braided in sundry little tails, which stuck out in every direction. The expression of her face was an odd mixture of shrewdness and cunning, over which was oddly drawn, like a kind of veil, an expression of the most doleful gravity and solemnity. She was dressed in a single filthy, ragged garment, made of bagging; and stood with her hands demurely folded before her. Altogether, there was something odd and goblin-like about her appearance,â€”something, as Miss Ophelia afterwards said, â€œso heathenish,â€ as to inspire that good lady with utter dismay; and turning to St. Clare, she said,
â€œAugustine, what in the world have you brought that thing here for?â€

â€œFor you to educate, to be sure, and train in the way she should go. I thought she was rather a funny specimen in the Jim Crow line. Here, Topsy,â€ he added, giving a whistle, as a man would to call the attention of a dog, â€œgive us a song, now, and show us some of your dancing.â€

The black, glassy eyes glittered with a kind of wicked drollery, and the thing struck up, in a clear shrill voice, an odd negro melody, to which she kept time with her hands and feet, spinning round, clapping her hands, knocking her knees together, in a wild, fantastic sort of time, and producing in her throat all those odd guttural sounds which distinguish the native music of her race; and finally, turning a summerset or two, and giving a prolonged closing note, as odd and unearthly as that of a steam-whistle, she came suddenly down on the carpet, and stood with her hands folded, and a most sanctimonious expression of meekness and solemnity over her face, only broken by the cunning glances which she shot askance from the corners of her eyes.
Miss Ophelia stood silent, perfectly paralyzed with amazement. St. Clare, like a mischievous fellow as he was, appeared to enjoy her astonishment; and, addressing the child again, said,
â€œTopsy, this is your new mistress. Iâ€™m going to give you up to her; see now that you behave yourself.â€
â€œYes, Masâ€™r,â€ said Topsy, with sanctimonious gravity, her wicked eyes twinkling as she spoke.
â€œYouâ€™re going to be good, Topsy, you understand,â€ said St. Clare.
â€œO yes, Masâ€™r,â€ said Topsy, with another twinkle, her hands still devoutly folded.

â€œNow, Augustine, what upon earth is this for?â€ said Miss Ophelia. â€œYour house is so full of these little plagues, now, that a body canâ€™t set down their foot without treading on â€™em. I get up in the morning, and find one asleep behind the door, and see one black head poking out from under the table, one lying on the door-mat,â€”and they are mopping and mowing and grinning between all the railings, and tumbling over the kitchen floor! What on earth did you want to bring this one for?â€

â€œFor you to educateâ€”didnâ€™t I tell you? Youâ€™re always preaching about educating. I thought I would make you a present of a fresh-caught specimen, and let you try your hand on her, and bring her up in the way she should go.â€
â€œI donâ€™t want her, I am sure;â€”I have more to do with â€™em now than I want to.â€

â€œThatâ€™s you Christians, all over!â€”youâ€™ll get up a society, and get some poor missionary to spend all his days among just such heathen. But let me see one of you that would take one into your house with you, and take the labor of their conversion on yourselves! No; when it comes to that, they are dirty and disagreeable, and itâ€™s too much care, and so on.â€

â€œAugustine, you know I didnâ€™t think of it in that light,â€ said Miss Ophelia, evidently softening. â€œWell, it might be a real missionary work,â€ said she, looking rather more favorably on the child.

St. Clare had touched the right string. Miss Opheliaâ€™s conscientiousness was ever on the alert. â€œBut,â€ she added, â€œI really didnâ€™t see the need of buying this one;â€”there are enough now, in your house, to take all my time and skill.â€

â€œWell, then, Cousin,â€ said St. Clare, drawing her aside, â€œI ought to beg your pardon for my good-for-nothing speeches. You are so good, after all, that thereâ€™s no sense in them. Why, the fact is, this concern belonged to a couple of drunken creatures that keep a low restaurant that I have to pass by every day, and I was tired of hearing her screaming, and them beating and swearing at her. She looked bright and funny, too, as if something might be made of her;â€”so I bought her, and Iâ€™ll give her to you. Try, now, and give her a good orthodox New England bringing up, and see what itâ€™ll make of her. You know I havenâ€™t any gift that way; but Iâ€™d like you to try.â€

â€œWell, Iâ€™ll do what I can,â€ said Miss Ophelia; and she approached her new subject very much as a person might be supposed to approach a black spider, supposing them to have benevolent designs toward it.
â€œSheâ€™s dreadfully dirty, and half naked,â€ she said.
â€œWell, take her down stairs, and make some of them clean and clothe her up.â€
Miss Ophelia carried her to the kitchen regions.
â€œDonâ€™t see what Masâ€™r St. Clare wants of â€™nother nigger!â€ said Dinah, surveying the new arrival with no friendly air. â€œWonâ€™t have her around under my feet, I know!â€
â€œPah!â€ said Rosa and Jane, with supreme disgust; â€œlet her keep out of our way! What in the world Masâ€™r wanted another of these low niggers for, I canâ€™t see!â€

â€œYou go long! No more nigger dan you be, Miss Rosa,â€ said Dinah, who felt this last remark a reflection on herself. â€œYou seem to tink yourself white folks. You anâ€™t nerry one, black nor white, Iâ€™d like to be one or turrer.â€

Miss Ophelia saw that there was nobody in the camp that would undertake to oversee the cleansing and dressing of the new arrival; and so she was forced to do it herself, with some very ungracious and reluctant assistance from Jane.

It is not for ears polite to hear the particulars of the first toilet of a neglected, abused child. In fact, in this world, multitudes must live and die in a state that it would be too great a shock to the nerves of their fellow-mortals even to hear described. Miss Ophelia had a good, strong, practical deal of resolution; and she went through all the disgusting details with heroic thoroughness, though, it must be confessed, with no very gracious air,â€”for endurance was the utmost to which her principles could bring her. When she saw, on the back and shoulders of the child, great welts and calloused spots, ineffaceable marks of the system under which she had grown up thus far, her heart became pitiful within her.

â€œSee there!â€ said Jane, pointing to the marks, â€œdonâ€™t that show sheâ€™s a limb? Weâ€™ll have fine works with her, I reckon. I hate these nigger young uns! so disgusting! I wonder that Masâ€™r would buy her!â€

The â€œyoung unâ€ alluded to heard all these comments with the subdued and doleful air which seemed habitual to her, only scanning, with a keen and furtive glance of her flickering eyes, the ornaments which Jane wore in her ears. When arrayed at last in a suit of decent and whole clothing, her hair cropped short to her head, Miss Ophelia, with some satisfaction, said she looked more Christian-like than she did, and in her own mind began to mature some plans for her instruction.
Sitting down before her, she began to question her.
â€œHow old are you, Topsy?â€
â€œDun no, Missis,â€ said the image, with a grin that showed all her teeth.
â€œDonâ€™t know how old you are? Didnâ€™t anybody ever tell you? Who was your mother?â€
â€œNever had none!â€ said the child, with another grin.
â€œNever had any mother? What do you mean? Where were you born?â€
