â€œNever was born!â€ persisted Topsy, with another grin, that looked so goblin-like, that, if Miss Ophelia had been at all nervous, she might have fancied that she had got hold of some sooty gnome from the land of Diablerie; but Miss Ophelia was not nervous, but plain and business-like, and she said, with some sternness,
â€œYou mustnâ€™t answer me in that way, child; Iâ€™m not playing with you. Tell me where you were born, and who your father and mother were.â€

â€œNever was born,â€ reiterated the creature, more emphatically; â€œnever had no father nor mother, nor nothinâ€™. I was raised by a speculator, with lots of others. Old Aunt Sue used to take car on us.â€
The child was evidently sincere, and Jane, breaking into a short laugh, said,
â€œLaws, Missis, thereâ€™s heaps of â€™em. Speculators buys â€™em up cheap, when theyâ€™s little, and gets â€™em raised for market.â€
â€œHow long have you lived with your master and mistress?â€
â€œDun no, Missis.â€
â€œIs it a year, or more, or less?â€
â€œDun no, Missis.â€
â€œLaws, Missis, those low negroes,â€”they canâ€™t tell; they donâ€™t know anything about time,â€ said Jane; â€œthey donâ€™t know what a year is; they donâ€™t know their own ages.
â€œHave you ever heard anything about God, Topsy?â€
The child looked bewildered, but grinned as usual.
â€œDo you know who made you?â€
â€œNobody, as I knows on,â€ said the child, with a short laugh.
The idea appeared to amuse her considerably; for her eyes twinkled, and she added,
â€œI spect I growâ€™d. Donâ€™t think nobody never made me.â€
â€œDo you know how to sew?â€ said Miss Ophelia, who thought she would turn her inquiries to something more tangible.
â€œNo, Missis.â€
â€œWhat can you do?â€”what did you do for your master and mistress?â€
â€œFetch water, and wash dishes, and rub knives, and wait on folks.â€
â€œWere they good to you?â€
â€œSpect they was,â€ said the child, scanning Miss Ophelia cunningly.
Miss Ophelia rose from this encouraging colloquy; St. Clare was leaning over the back of her chair.
â€œYou find virgin soil there, Cousin; put in your own ideas,â€”you wonâ€™t find many to pull up.â€

Miss Opheliaâ€™s ideas of education, like all her other ideas, were very set and definite; and of the kind that prevailed in New England a century ago, and which are still preserved in some very retired and unsophisticated parts, where there are no railroads. As nearly as could be expressed, they could be comprised in very few words: to teach them to mind when they were spoken to; to teach them the catechism, sewing, and reading; and to whip them if they told lies. And though, of course, in the flood of light that is now poured on education, these are left far away in the rear, yet it is an undisputed fact that our grandmothers raised some tolerably fair men and women under this regime, as many of us can remember and testify. At all events, Miss Ophelia knew of nothing else to do; and, therefore, applied her mind to her heathen with the best diligence she could command.

The child was announced and considered in the family as Miss Opheliaâ€™s girl; and, as she was looked upon with no gracious eye in the kitchen, Miss Ophelia resolved to confine her sphere of operation and instruction chiefly to her own chamber. With a self-sacrifice which some of our readers will appreciate, she resolved, instead of comfortably making her own bed, sweeping and dusting her own chamber,â€”which she had hitherto done, in utter scorn of all offers of help from the chambermaid of the establishment,â€”to condemn herself to the martyrdom of instructing Topsy to perform these operations,â€”ah, woe the day! Did any of our readers ever do the same, they will appreciate the amount of her self-sacrifice.
Miss Ophelia began with Topsy by taking her into her chamber, the first morning, and solemnly commencing a course of instruction in the art and mystery of bed-making.

Behold, then, Topsy, washed and shorn of all the little braided tails wherein her heart had delighted, arrayed in a clean gown, with well-starched apron, standing reverently before Miss Ophelia, with an expression of solemnity well befitting a funeral.
â€œNow, Topsy, Iâ€™m going to show you just how my bed is to be made. I am very particular about my bed. You must learn exactly how to do it.â€
â€œYes, maâ€™am,â€ says Topsy, with a deep sigh, and a face of woful earnestness.
â€œNow, Topsy, look here;â€”this is the hem of the sheet,â€”this is the right side of the sheet, and this is the wrong;â€”will you remember?â€
â€œYes, maâ€™am,â€ says Topsy, with another sigh.
â€œWell, now, the under sheet you must bring over the bolster,â€”soâ€”and tuck it clear down under the mattress nice and smooth,â€”so,â€”do you see?â€
â€œYes, maâ€™am,â€ said Topsy, with profound attention.
â€œBut the upper sheet,â€ said Miss Ophelia, â€œmust be brought down in this way, and tucked under firm and smooth at the foot,â€”so,â€”the narrow hem at the foot.â€

â€œYes, maâ€™am,â€ said Topsy, as before;â€”but we will add, what Miss Ophelia did not see, that, during the time when the good ladyâ€™s back was turned in the zeal of her manipulations, the young disciple had contrived to snatch a pair of gloves and a ribbon, which she had adroitly slipped into her sleeves, and stood with her hands dutifully folded, as before.
â€œNow, Topsy, letâ€™s see you do this,â€ said Miss Ophelia, pulling off the clothes, and seating herself.

Topsy, with great gravity and adroitness, went through the exercise completely to Miss Opheliaâ€™s satisfaction; smoothing the sheets, patting out every wrinkle, and exhibiting, through the whole process, a gravity and seriousness with which her instructress was greatly edified. By an unlucky slip, however, a fluttering fragment of the ribbon hung out of one of her sleeves, just as she was finishing, and caught Miss Opheliaâ€™s attention. Instantly, she pounced upon it. â€œWhatâ€™s this? You naughty, wicked child,â€”youâ€™ve been stealing this!â€
The ribbon was pulled out of Topsyâ€™s own sleeve, yet was she not in the least disconcerted; she only looked at it with an air of the most surprised and unconscious innocence.
â€œLaws! why, that arâ€™s Miss Feelyâ€™s ribbon, anâ€™t it? How could it a got caught in my sleeve?
â€œTopsy, you naughty girl, donâ€™t you tell me a lie,â€”you stole that ribbon!â€
â€œMissis, I declar for â€™t, I didnâ€™t;â€”never seed it till dis yer blessed minnit.â€
â€œTopsy,â€ said Miss Ophelia, â€œdonâ€™t you know itâ€™s wicked to tell lies?â€
â€œI never tell no lies, Miss Feely,â€ said Topsy, with virtuous gravity; â€œitâ€™s jist the truth Iâ€™ve been a tellin now, and anâ€™t nothin else.â€
â€œTopsy, I shall have to whip you, if you tell lies so.â€

â€œLaws, Missis, if youâ€™s to whip all day, couldnâ€™t say no other way,â€ said Topsy, beginning to blubber. â€œI never seed dat ar,â€”it must a got caught in my sleeve. Miss Feeley must have left it on the bed, and it got caught in the clothes, and so got in my sleeve.â€
Miss Ophelia was so indignant at the barefaced lie, that she caught the child and shook her.
â€œDonâ€™t you tell me that again!â€
The shake brought the glove on to the floor, from the other sleeve.
â€œThere, you!â€ said Miss Ophelia, â€œwill you tell me now, you didnâ€™t steal the ribbon?â€
Topsy now confessed to the gloves, but still persisted in denying the ribbon.
â€œNow, Topsy,â€ said Miss Ophelia, â€œif youâ€™ll confess all about it, I wonâ€™t whip you this time.â€ Thus adjured, Topsy confessed to the ribbon and gloves, with woful protestations of penitence.

â€œWell, now, tell me. I know you must have taken other things since you have been in the house, for I let you run about all day yesterday. Now, tell me if you took anything, and I shanâ€™t whip you.â€
â€œLaws, Missis! I took Miss Evaâ€™s red thing she wars on her neck.â€
â€œYou did, you naughty child!â€”Well, what else?â€
â€œI took Rosaâ€™s yer-rings,â€”them red ones.â€
â€œGo bring them to me this minute, both of â€™em.â€
â€œLaws, Missis! I canâ€™t,â€”they â€™s burnt up!â€
â€œBurnt up!â€”what a story! Go get â€™em, or Iâ€™ll whip you.â€
Topsy, with loud protestations, and tears, and groans, declared that she could not. â€œThey â€™s burnt up,â€”they was.â€
â€œWhat did you burn â€™em for?â€ said Miss Ophelia.
â€œCause I â€™s wicked,â€”I is. I â€™s mighty wicked, any how. I canâ€™t help it.â€
Just at this moment, Eva came innocently into the room, with the identical coral necklace on her neck.
â€œWhy, Eva, where did you get your necklace?â€ said Miss Ophelia.
â€œGet it? Why, Iâ€™ve had it on all day,â€ said Eva.
â€œDid you have it on yesterday?â€
â€œYes; and what is funny, Aunty, I had it on all night. I forgot to take it off when I went to bed.â€

Miss Ophelia looked perfectly bewildered; the more so, as Rosa, at that instant, came into the room, with a basket of newly-ironed linen poised on her head, and the coral ear-drops shaking in her ears!
â€œIâ€™m sure I canâ€™t tell anything what to do with such a child!â€ she said, in despair. â€œWhat in the world did you tell me you took those things for, Topsy?â€
â€œWhy, Missis said I must â€™fess; and I couldnâ€™t think of nothinâ€™ else to â€™fess,â€ said Topsy, rubbing her eyes.
â€œBut, of course, I didnâ€™t want you to confess things you didnâ€™t do,â€ said Miss Ophelia; â€œthatâ€™s telling a lie, just as much as the other.â€
â€œLaws, now, is it?â€ said Topsy, with an air of innocent wonder.

â€œLa, there anâ€™t any such thing as truth in that limb,â€ said Rosa, looking indignantly at Topsy. â€œIf I was Masâ€™r St. Clare, Iâ€™d whip her till the blood run. I would,â€”Iâ€™d let her catch it!â€
â€œNo, no Rosa,â€ said Eva, with an air of command, which the child could assume at times; â€œyou mustnâ€™t talk so, Rosa. I canâ€™t bear to hear it.â€
â€œLa sakes! Miss Eva, you â€™s so good, you donâ€™t know nothing how to get along with niggers. Thereâ€™s no way but to cut â€™em well up, I tell ye.â€
â€œRosa!â€ said Eva, â€œhush! Donâ€™t you say another word of that sort!â€ and the eye of the child flashed, and her cheek deepened its color.
Rosa was cowed in a moment.
â€œMiss Eva has got the St. Clare blood in her, thatâ€™s plain. She can speak, for all the world, just like her papa,â€ she said, as she passed out of the room.
Eva stood looking at Topsy.

There stood the two children representatives of the two extremes of society. The fair, high-bred child, with her golden head, her deep eyes, her spiritual, noble brow, and prince-like movements; and her black, keen, subtle, cringing, yet acute neighbor. They stood the representatives of their races. The Saxon, born of ages of cultivation, command, education, physical and moral eminence; the Afric, born of ages of oppression, submission, ignorance, toil and vice!

Something, perhaps, of such thoughts struggled through Evaâ€™s mind. But a childâ€™s thoughts are rather dim, undefined instincts; and in Evaâ€™s noble nature many such were yearning and working, for which she had no power of utterance. When Miss Ophelia expatiated on Topsyâ€™s naughty, wicked conduct, the child looked perplexed and sorrowful, but said, sweetly.
â€œPoor Topsy, why need you steal? Youâ€™re going to be taken good care of now. Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™d rather give you anything of mine, than have you steal it.â€

It was the first word of kindness the child had ever heard in her life; and the sweet tone and manner struck strangely on the wild, rude heart, and a sparkle of something like a tear shone in the keen, round, glittering eye; but it was followed by the short laugh and habitual grin. No! the ear that has never heard anything but abuse is strangely incredulous of anything so heavenly as kindness; and Topsy only thought Evaâ€™s speech something funny and inexplicable,â€”she did not believe it.

But what was to be done with Topsy? Miss Ophelia found the case a puzzler; her rules for bringing up didnâ€™t seem to apply. She thought she would take time to think of it; and, by the way of gaining time, and in hopes of some indefinite moral virtues supposed to be inherent in dark closets, Miss Ophelia shut Topsy up in one till she had arranged her ideas further on the subject.
â€œI donâ€™t see,â€ said Miss Ophelia to St. Clare, â€œhow Iâ€™m going to manage that child, without whipping her.â€
â€œWell, whip her, then, to your heartâ€™s content; Iâ€™ll give you full power to do what you like.â€
â€œChildren always have to be whipped,â€ said Miss Ophelia; â€œI never heard of bringing them up without.â€

â€œO, well, certainly,â€ said St. Clare; â€œdo as you think best. Only Iâ€™ll make one suggestion: Iâ€™ve seen this child whipped with a poker, knocked down with the shovel or tongs, whichever came handiest, &c.; and, seeing that she is used to that style of operation, I think your whippings will have to be pretty energetic, to make much impression.â€
â€œWhat is to be done with her, then?â€ said Miss Ophelia.

â€œYou have started a serious question,â€ said St. Clare; â€œI wish youâ€™d answer it. What is to be done with a human being that can be governed only by the lash,â€”that fails,â€”itâ€™s a very common state of things down here!â€
â€œIâ€™m sure I donâ€™t know; I never saw such a child as this.â€
â€œSuch children are very common among us, and such men and women, too. How are they to be governed?â€ said St. Clare.
â€œIâ€™m sure itâ€™s more than I can say,â€ said Miss Ophelia.

â€œOr I either,â€ said St. Clare. â€œThe horrid cruelties and outrages that once and a while find their way into the papers,â€”such cases as Prueâ€™s, for example,â€”what do they come from? In many cases, it is a gradual hardening process on both sides,â€”the owner growing more and more cruel, as the servant more and more callous. Whipping and abuse are like laudanum; you have to double the dose as the sensibilities decline. I saw this very early when I became an owner; and I resolved never to begin, because I did not know when I should stop,â€”and I resolved, at least, to protect my own moral nature. The consequence is, that my servants act like spoiled children; but I think that better than for us both to be brutalized together. You have talked a great deal about our responsibilities in educating, Cousin. I really wanted you to try with one child, who is a specimen of thousands among us.â€
â€œIt is your system makes such children,â€ said Miss Ophelia.
â€œI know it; but they are made,â€”they exist,â€”and what is to be done with them?â€

â€œWell, I canâ€™t say I thank you for the experiment. But, then, as it appears to be a duty, I shall persevere and try, and do the best I can,â€ said Miss Ophelia; and Miss Ophelia, after this, did labor, with a commendable degree of zeal and energy, on her new subject. She instituted regular hours and employments for her, and undertook to teach her to read and sew.

In the former art, the child was quick enough. She learned her letters as if by magic, and was very soon able to read plain reading; but the sewing was a more difficult matter. The creature was as lithe as a cat, and as active as a monkey, and the confinement of sewing was her abomination; so she broke her needles, threw them slyly out of the window, or down in chinks of the walls; she tangled, broke, and dirtied her thread, or, with a sly movement, would throw a spool away altogether. Her motions were almost as quick as those of a practised conjurer, and her command of her face quite as great; and though Miss Ophelia could not help feeling that so many accidents could not possibly happen in succession, yet she could not, without a watchfulness which would leave her no time for anything else, detect her.

Topsy was soon a noted character in the establishment. Her talent for every species of drollery, grimace, and mimicry,â€”for dancing, tumbling, climbing, singing, whistling, imitating every sound that hit her fancy,â€”seemed inexhaustible. In her play-hours, she invariably had every child in the establishment at her heels, open-mouthed with admiration and wonder,â€”not excepting Miss Eva, who appeared to be fascinated by her wild diablerie, as a dove is sometimes charmed by a glittering serpent. Miss Ophelia was uneasy that Eva should fancy Topsyâ€™s society so much, and implored St. Clare to forbid it.
â€œPoh! let the child alone,â€ said St. Clare. â€œTopsy will do her good.â€
â€œBut so depraved a child,â€”are you not afraid she will teach her some mischief?â€
â€œShe canâ€™t teach her mischief; she might teach it to some children, but evil rolls off Evaâ€™s mind like dew off a cabbage-leaf,â€”not a drop sinks in.â€
â€œDonâ€™t be too sure,â€ said Miss Ophelia. â€œI know Iâ€™d never let a child of mine play with Topsy.â€
â€œWell, your children neednâ€™t,â€ said St. Clare, â€œbut mine may; if Eva could have been spoiled, it would have been done years ago.â€

Topsy was at first despised and contemned by the upper servants. They soon found reason to alter their opinion. It was very soon discovered that whoever cast an indignity on Topsy was sure to meet with some inconvenient accident shortly after;â€”either a pair of ear-rings or some cherished trinket would be missing, or an article of dress would be suddenly found utterly ruined, or the person would stumble accidently into a pail of hot water, or a libation of dirty slop would unaccountably deluge them from above when in full gala dress;-and on all these occasions, when investigation was made, there was nobody found to stand sponsor for the indignity. Topsy was cited, and had up before all the domestic judicatories, time and again; but always sustained her examinations with most edifying innocence and gravity of appearance. Nobody in the world ever doubted who did the things; but not a scrap of any direct evidence could be found to establish the suppositions, and Miss Ophelia was too just to feel at liberty to proceed to any length without it.

The mischiefs done were always so nicely timed, also, as further to shelter the aggressor. Thus, the times for revenge on Rosa and Jane, the two chamber maids, were always chosen in those seasons when (as not unfrequently happened) they were in disgrace with their mistress, when any complaint from them would of course meet with no sympathy. In short, Topsy soon made the household understand the propriety of letting her alone; and she was let alone, accordingly.

Topsy was smart and energetic in all manual operations, learning everything that was taught her with surprising quickness. With a few lessons, she had learned to do the proprieties of Miss Opheliaâ€™s chamber in a way with which even that particular lady could find no fault. Mortal hands could not lay spread smoother, adjust pillows more accurately, sweep and dust and arrange more perfectly, than Topsy, when she chose,â€”but she didnâ€™t very often choose. If Miss Ophelia, after three or four days of careful patient supervision, was so sanguine as to suppose that Topsy had at last fallen into her way, could do without over-looking, and so go off and busy herself about something else, Topsy would hold a perfect carnival of confusion, for some one or two hours. Instead of making the bed, she would amuse herself with pulling off the pillowcases, butting her woolly head among the pillows, till it would sometimes be grotesquely ornamented with feathers sticking out in various directions; she would climb the posts, and hang head downward from the tops; flourish the sheets and spreads all over the apartment; dress the bolster up in Miss Opheliaâ€™s night-clothes, and enact various performances with that,â€”singing and whistling, and making grimaces at herself in the looking-glass; in short, as Miss Ophelia phrased it, â€œraising Cainâ€ generally.

On one occasion, Miss Ophelia found Topsy with her very best scarlet India Canton crape shawl wound round her head for a turban, going on with her rehearsals before the glass in great style,â€”Miss Ophelia having, with carelessness most unheard-of in her, left the key for once in her drawer.
â€œTopsy!â€ she would say, when at the end of all patience, â€œwhat does make you act so?â€
â€œDunno, Missis,â€”I spects cause I â€™s so wicked!â€
â€œI donâ€™t know anything what I shall do with you, Topsy.â€
â€œLaw, Missis, you must whip me; my old Missis allers whipped me. I anâ€™t used to workinâ€™ unless I gets whipped.â€
â€œWhy, Topsy, I donâ€™t want to whip you. You can do well, if youâ€™ve a mind to; what is the reason you wonâ€™t?â€
â€œLaws, Missis, I â€™s used to whippinâ€™; I spects itâ€™s good for me.â€

Miss Ophelia tried the recipe, and Topsy invariably made a terrible commotion, screaming, groaning and imploring, though half an hour afterwards, when roosted on some projection of the balcony, and surrounded by a flock of admiring â€œyoung uns,â€ she would express the utmost contempt of the whole affair.
â€œLaw, Miss Feely whip!â€”wouldnâ€™t kill a skeeter, her whippins. Oughter see how old Masâ€™r made the flesh fly; old Masâ€™r knowâ€™d how!â€
Topsy always made great capital of her own sins and enormities, evidently considering them as something peculiarly distinguishing.

â€œLaw, you niggers,â€ she would say to some of her auditors, â€œdoes you know you â€™s all sinners? Well, you isâ€”everybody is. White folks is sinners too,â€”Miss Feely says so; but I spects niggers is the biggest ones; but lor! ye anâ€™t any on ye up to me. I â€™s so awful wicked there canâ€™t nobody do nothinâ€™ with me. I used to keep old Missis a swarinâ€™ at me half de time. I spects I â€™s the wickedest critter in the world;â€ and Topsy would cut a summerset, and come up brisk and shining on to a higher perch, and evidently plume herself on the distinction.
Miss Ophelia busied herself very earnestly on Sundays, teaching Topsy the catechism. Topsy had an uncommon verbal memory, and committed with a fluency that greatly encouraged her instructress.
â€œWhat good do you expect it is going to do her?â€ said St. Clare.
â€œWhy, it always has done children good. Itâ€™s what children always have to learn, you know,â€ said Miss Ophelia.
â€œUnderstand it or not,â€ said St. Clare.
â€œO, children never understand it at the time; but, after they are grown up, itâ€™ll come to them.â€
â€œMine hasnâ€™t come to me yet,â€ said St. Clare, â€œthough Iâ€™ll bear testimony that you put it into me pretty thoroughly when I was a boy.â€â€™
â€œAh, you were always good at learning, Augustine. I used to have great hopes of you,â€ said Miss Ophelia.
â€œWell, havenâ€™t you now?â€ said St. Clare.
â€œI wish you were as good as you were when you were a boy, Augustine.â€
â€œSo do I, thatâ€™s a fact, Cousin,â€ said St. Clare. â€œWell, go ahead and catechize Topsy; may be youâ€™ll make out something yet.â€
Topsy, who had stood like a black statue during this discussion, with hands decently folded, now, at a signal from Miss Ophelia, went on:
â€œOur first parents, being left to the freedom of their own will, fell from the state wherein they were created.â€
Topsyâ€™s eyes twinkled, and she looked inquiringly.
â€œWhat is it, Topsy?â€ said Miss Ophelia.
â€œPlease, Missis, was dat ar state Kintuck?â€
â€œWhat state, Topsy?â€
â€œDat state dey fell out of. I used to hear Masâ€™r tell how we came down from Kintuck.â€
St. Clare laughed.
â€œYouâ€™ll have to give her a meaning, or sheâ€™ll make one,â€ said he. â€œThere seems to be a theory of emigration suggested there.â€
â€œO! Augustine, be still,â€ said Miss Ophelia; â€œhow can I do anything, if you will be laughing?â€

â€œWell, I wonâ€™t disturb the exercises again, on my honor;â€ and St. Clare took his paper into the parlor, and sat down, till Topsy had finished her recitations. They were all very well, only that now and then she would oddly transpose some important words, and persist in the mistake, in spite of every effort to the contrary; and St. Clare, after all his promises of goodness, took a wicked pleasure in these mistakes, calling Topsy to him whenever he had a mind to amuse himself, and getting her to repeat the offending passages, in spite of Miss Opheliaâ€™s remonstrances.
â€œHow do you think I can do anything with the child, if you will go on so, Augustine?â€ she would say.
â€œWell, it is too bad,â€”I wonâ€™t again; but I do like to hear the droll little image stumble over those big words!â€
â€œBut you confirm her in the wrong way.â€
â€œWhatâ€™s the odds? One word is as good as another to her.â€
â€œYou wanted me to bring her up right; and you ought to remember she is a reasonable creature, and be careful of your influence over her.â€
â€œO, dismal! so I ought; but, as Topsy herself says, â€™I â€™s so wicked!â€™â€

In very much this way Topsyâ€™s training proceeded, for a year or two,â€”Miss Ophelia worrying herself, from day to day, with her, as a kind of chronic plague, to whose inflictions she became, in time, as accustomed, as persons sometimes do to the neuralgia or sick headache.

St. Clare took the same kind of amusement in the child that a man might in the tricks of a parrot or a pointer. Topsy, whenever her sins brought her into disgrace in other quarters, always took refuge behind his chair; and St. Clare, in one way or other, would make peace for her. From him she got many a stray picayune, which she laid out in nuts and candies, and distributed, with careless generosity, to all the children in the family; for Topsy, to do her justice, was good-natured and liberal, and only spiteful in self-defence. She is fairly introduced into our corps de ballet, and will figure, from time to time, in her turn, with other performers.

div.head:
Chapter XXI
Kentuck
div.p: Our readers may not be unwilling to glance back, for a brief interval, at Uncle Tomâ€™s Cabin, on the Kentucky farm, and see what has been transpiring among those whom he had left behind.

It was late in the summer afternoon, and the doors and windows of the large parlor all stood open, to invite any stray breeze, that might feel in a good humor, to enter. Mr. Shelby sat in a large hall opening into the room, and running through the whole length of the house, to a balcony on either end. Leisurely tipped back on one chair, with his heels in another, he was enjoying his after-dinner cigar. Mrs. Shelby sat in the door, busy about some fine sewing; she seemed like one who had something on her mind, which she was seeking an opportunity to introduce.
â€œDo you know,â€ she said, â€œthat Chloe has had a letter from Tom?â€
â€œAh! has she? Tom â€™s got some friend there, it seems. How is the old boy?â€
â€œHe has been bought by a very fine family, I should think,â€ said Mrs. Shelby,â€”â€œis kindly treated, and has not much to do.â€
â€œAh! well, Iâ€™m glad of it,â€”very glad,â€ said Mr. Shelby, heartily. â€œTom, I suppose, will get reconciled to a Southern residence;â€”hardly want to come up here again.â€
â€œOn the contrary he inquires very anxiously,â€ said Mrs. Shelby, â€œwhen the money for his redemption is to be raised.â€

â€œIâ€™m sure I donâ€™t know,â€ said Mr. Shelby. â€œOnce get business running wrong, there does seem to be no end to it. Itâ€™s like jumping from one bog to another, all through a swamp; borrow of one to pay another, and then borrow of another to pay one,â€”and these confounded notes falling due before a man has time to smoke a cigar and turn round,â€”dunning letters and dunning messages,â€”all scamper and hurry-scurry.â€
â€œIt does seem to me, my dear, that something might be done to straighten matters. Suppose we sell off all the horses, and sell one of your farms, and pay up square?â€
â€œO, ridiculous, Emily! You are the finest woman in Kentucky; but still you havenâ€™t sense to know that you donâ€™t understand business;â€”women never do, and never can.

â€œBut, at least,â€ said Mrs. Shelby, â€œcould not you give me some little insight into yours; a list of all your debts, at least, and of all that is owed to you, and let me try and see if I canâ€™t help you to economize.â€

â€œO, bother! donâ€™t plague me, Emily!â€”I canâ€™t tell exactly. I know somewhere about what things are likely to be; but thereâ€™s no trimming and squaring my affairs, as Chloe trims crust off her pies. You donâ€™t know anything about business, I tell you.â€

And Mr. Shelby, not knowing any other way of enforcing his ideas, raised his voice,â€”a mode of arguing very convenient and convincing, when a gentleman is discussing matters of business with his wife.

Mrs. Shelby ceased talking, with something of a sigh. The fact was, that though her husband had stated she was a woman, she had a clear, energetic, practical mind, and a force of character every way superior to that of her husband; so that it would not have been so very absurd a supposition, to have allowed her capable of managing, as Mr. Shelby supposed. Her heart was set on performing her promise to Tom and Aunt Chloe, and she sighed as discouragements thickened around her.
â€œDonâ€™t you think we might in some way contrive to raise that money? Poor Aunt Chloe! her heart is so set on it!â€

â€œIâ€™m sorry, if it is. I think I was premature in promising. Iâ€™m not sure, now, but itâ€™s the best way to tell Chloe, and let her make up her mind to it. Tomâ€™ll have another wife, in a year or two; and she had better take up with somebody else.â€
â€œMr. Shelby, I have taught my people that their marriages are as sacred as ours. I never could think of giving Chloe such advice.â€
â€œItâ€™s a pity, wife, that you have burdened them with a morality above their condition and prospects. I always thought so.â€
â€œItâ€™s only the morality of the Bible, Mr. Shelby.â€
â€œWell, well, Emily, I donâ€™t pretend to interfere with your religious notions; only they seem extremely unfitted for people in that condition.â€

â€œThey are, indeed,â€ said Mrs. Shelby, â€œand that is why, from my soul, I hate the whole thing. I tell you, my dear, I cannot absolve myself from the promises I make to these helpless creatures. If I can get the money no other way I will take music-scholars;â€”I could get enough, I know, and earn the money myself.â€
â€œYou wouldnâ€™t degrade yourself that way, Emily? I never could consent to it.â€
â€œDegrade! would it degrade me as much as to break my faith with the helpless? No, indeed!â€
â€œWell, you are always heroic and transcendental,â€ said Mr. Shelby, â€œbut I think you had better think before you undertake such a piece of Quixotism.â€
Here the conversation was interrupted by the appearance of Aunt Chloe, at the end of the verandah.
â€œIf you please, Missis,â€ said she.
â€œWell, Chloe, what is it?â€ said her mistress, rising, and going to the end of the balcony.
â€œIf Missis would come and look at dis yer lot oâ€™ poetry.â€

Chloe had a particular fancy for calling poultry poetry,â€”an application of language in which she always persisted, notwithstanding frequent corrections and advisings from the young members of the family.
â€œLa sakes!â€ she would say, â€œI canâ€™t see; one jis good as turry,â€”poetry suthin good, any how;â€ and so poetry Chloe continued to call it.
Mrs. Shelby smiled as she saw a prostrate lot of chickens and ducks, over which Chloe stood, with a very grave face of consideration.
â€œIâ€™m a thinkin whether Missis would be a havin a chicken pie oâ€™ dese yer.â€
â€œReally, Aunt Chloe, I donâ€™t much care;â€”serve them any way you like.â€

Chloe stood handling them over abstractedly; it was quite evident that the chickens were not what she was thinking of. At last, with the short laugh with which her tribe often introduce a doubtful proposal, she said,
â€œLaws me, Missis! what should Masâ€™r and Missis be a troublin theirselves â€™bout de money, and not a usin whatâ€™s right in der hands?â€ and Chloe laughed again.

â€œI donâ€™t understand you, Chloe,â€ said Mrs. Shelby, nothing doubting, from her knowledge of Chloeâ€™s manner, that she had heard every word of the conversation that had passed between her and her husband.
â€œWhy, laws me, Missis!â€ said Chloe, laughing again, â€œother folks hires out der niggers and makes money on â€™em! Donâ€™t keep sich a tribe eatin â€™em out of house and home.â€
â€œWell, Chloe, who do you propose that we should hire out?â€

â€œLaws! I anâ€™t a proposin nothin; only Sam he said der was one of dese yer perfectioners, dey calls â€™em, in Louisville, said he wanted a good hand at cake and pastry; and said heâ€™d give four dollars a week to one, he did.â€
â€œWell, Chloe.â€

â€œWell, laws, I â€™s a thinkin, Missis, itâ€™s time Sally was put along to be doinâ€™ something. Sally â€™s been under my care, now, dis some time, and she does most as well as me, considerin; and if Missis would only let me go, I would help fetch up de money. I anâ€™t afraid to put my cake, nor pies nother, â€™long side no perfectionerâ€™s.
â€œConfectionerâ€™s, Chloe.â€
â€œLaw sakes, Missis! â€™tanâ€™t no odds;â€”words is so curis, canâ€™t never get â€™em right!â€
â€œBut, Chloe, do you want to leave your children?â€
â€œLaws, Missis! de boys is big enough to do dayâ€™s works; dey does well enough; and Sally, sheâ€™ll take de baby,â€”sheâ€™s such a peart young un, she wonâ€™t take no lookin arter.â€
â€œLouisville is a good way off.â€
â€œLaw sakes! whoâ€™s afeard?â€”itâ€™s down river, somer near my old man, perhaps?â€ said Chloe, speaking the last in the tone of a question, and looking at Mrs. Shelby.
â€œNo, Chloe; itâ€™s many a hundred miles off,â€ said Mrs. Shelby.
Chloeâ€™s countenance fell.
â€œNever mind; your going there shall bring you nearer, Chloe. Yes, you may go; and your wages shall every cent of them be laid aside for your husbandâ€™s redemption.â€
As when a bright sunbeam turns a dark cloud to silver, so Chloeâ€™s dark face brightened immediately,â€”it really shone.

â€œLaws! if Missis isnâ€™t too good! I was thinking of dat ar very thing; cause I shouldnâ€™t need no clothes, nor shoes, nor nothin,â€”I could save every cent. How many weeks is der in a year, Missis?â€
â€œFifty-two,â€ said Mrs. Shelby.
â€œLaws! now, dere is? and four dollars for each on em. Why, how much â€™d dat ar be?â€
â€œTwo hundred and eight dollars,â€ said Mrs. Shelby.
â€œWhy-e!â€ said Chloe, with an accent of surprise and delight; â€œand how long would it take me to work it out, Missis?â€
â€œSome four or five years, Chloe; but, then, you neednâ€™t do it all,â€”I shall add something to it.â€

â€œI wouldnâ€™t hear to Missisâ€™ givin lessons nor nothin. Masâ€™râ€™s quite right in dat ar;â€”â€˜t wouldnâ€™t do, no ways. I hope none our family ever be brought to dat ar, while I â€™s got hands.â€
â€œDonâ€™t fear, Chloe; Iâ€™ll take care of the honor of the family,â€ said Mrs. Shelby, smiling. â€œBut when do you expect to go?â€

â€œWell, I want spectin nothin; only Sam, heâ€™s a gwine to de river with some colts, and he said I could go â€™long with him; so I jes put my things together. If Missis was willin, Iâ€™d go with Sam tomorrow morning, if Missis would write my pass, and write me a commendation.â€
â€œWell, Chloe, Iâ€™ll attend to it, if Mr. Shelby has no objections. I must speak to him.â€
Mrs. Shelby went up stairs, and Aunt Chloe, delighted, went out to her cabin, to make her preparation.

â€œLaw sakes, Masâ€™r George! ye didnâ€™t know I â€™s a gwine to Louisville tomorrow!â€ she said to George, as entering her cabin, he found her busy in sorting over her babyâ€™s clothes. â€œI thought Iâ€™d jis look over sisâ€™s things, and get â€™em straightened up. But Iâ€™m gwine, Masâ€™r George,â€”gwine to have four dollars a week; and Missis is gwine to lay it all up, to buy back my old man agin!â€
â€œWhew!â€ said George, â€œhereâ€™s a stroke of business, to be sure! How are you going?â€
â€œTomorrow, wid Sam. And now, Masâ€™r George, I knows youâ€™ll jis sit down and write to my old man, and tell him all about it,â€”wonâ€™t ye?â€

â€œTo be sure,â€ said George; â€œUncle Tomâ€™ll be right glad to hear from us. Iâ€™ll go right in the house, for paper and ink; and then, you know, Aunt Chloe, I can tell about the new colts and all.â€
â€œSartin, sartin, Masâ€™r George; you go â€™long, and Iâ€™ll get ye up a bit oâ€™ chicken, or some sich; ye wonâ€™t have many more suppers wid yer poor old aunty.â€

div.head:
Chapter XXII
â€œThe Grass Witherethâ€”the Flower Fadethâ€
div.p: Life passes, with us all, a day at a time; so it passed with our friend Tom, till two years were gone. Though parted from all his soul held dear, and though often yearning for what lay beyond, still was he never positively and consciously miserable; for, so well is the harp of human feeling strung, that nothing but a crash that breaks every string can wholly mar its harmony; and, on looking back to seasons which in review appear to us as those of deprivation and trial, we can remember that each hour, as it glided, brought its diversions and alleviations, so that, though not happy wholly, we were not, either, wholly miserable.

Tom read, in his only literary cabinet, of one who had â€œlearned in whatsoever state he was, therewith to be content.â€ It seemed to him good and reasonable doctrine, and accorded well with the settled and thoughtful habit which he had acquired from the reading of that same book.

His letter homeward, as we related in the last chapter, was in due time answered by Master George, in a good, round, school-boy hand, that Tom said might be read â€œmost acrost the room.â€ It contained various refreshing items of home intelligence, with which our reader is fully acquainted: stated how Aunt Chloe had been hired out to a confectioner in Louisville, where her skill in the pastry line was gaining wonderful sums of money, all of which, Tom was informed, was to be laid up to go to make up the sum of his redemption money; Mose and Pete were thriving, and the baby was trotting all about the house, under the care of Sally and the family generally.
Tomâ€™s cabin was shut up for the present; but George expatiated brilliantly on ornaments and additions to be made to it when Tom came back.

The rest of this letter gave a list of Georgeâ€™s school studies, each one headed by a flourishing capital; and also told the names of four new colts that appeared on the premises since Tom left; and stated, in the same connection, that father and mother were well. The style of the letter was decidedly concise and terse; but Tom thought it the most wonderful specimen of composition that had appeared in modern times. He was never tired of looking at it, and even held a council with Eva on the expediency of getting it framed, to hang up in his room. Nothing but the difficulty of arranging it so that both sides of the page would show at once stood in the way of this undertaking.

The friendship between Tom and Eva had grown with the childâ€™s growth. It would be hard to say what place she held in the soft, impressible heart of her faithful attendant. He loved her as something frail and earthly, yet almost worshipped her as something heavenly and divine. He gazed on her as the Italian sailor gazes on his image of the child Jesus,â€”with a mixture of reverence and tenderness; and to humor her graceful fancies, and meet those thousand simple wants which invest childhood like a many-colored rainbow, was Tomâ€™s chief delight. In the market, at morning, his eyes were always on the flower-stalls for rare bouquets for her, and the choicest peach or orange was slipped into his pocket to give to her when he came back; and the sight that pleased him most was her sunny head looking out the gate for his distant approach, and her childish questions,â€”â€œWell, Uncle Tom, what have you got for me today?â€

Nor was Eva less zealous in kind offices, in return. Though a child, she was a beautiful reader;â€”a fine musical ear, a quick poetic fancy, and an instinctive sympathy with whatâ€™s grand and noble, made her such a reader of the Bible as Tom had never before heard. At first, she read to please her humble friend; but soon her own earnest nature threw out its tendrils, and wound itself around the majestic book; and Eva loved it, because it woke in her strange yearnings, and strong, dim emotions, such as impassioned, imaginative children love to feel.

The parts that pleased her most were the Revelations and the Prophecies,â€”parts whose dim and wondrous imagery, and fervent language, impressed her the more, that she questioned vainly of their meaning;â€”and she and her simple friend, the old child and the young one, felt just alike about it. All that they knew was, that they spoke of a glory to be revealed,â€”a wondrous something yet to come, wherein their soul rejoiced, yet knew not why; and though it be not so in the physical, yet in moral science that which cannot be understood is not always profitless. For the soul awakes, a trembling stranger, between two dim eternities,â€”the eternal past, the eternal future. The light shines only on a small space around her; therefore, she needs must yearn towards the unknown; and the voices and shadowy movings which come to her from out the cloudy pillar of inspiration have each one echoes and answers in her own expecting nature. Its mystic imagery are so many talismans and gems inscribed with unknown hieroglyphics; she folds them in her bosom, and expects to read them when she passes beyond the veil.
LITTLE EVA READING THE BIBLE TO UNCLE TOM IN THE ARBOR.

At this time in our story, the whole St. Clare establishment is, for the time being, removed to their villa on Lake Pontchartrain. The heats of summer had driven all who were able to leave the sultry and unhealthy city, to seek the shores of the lake, and its cool sea-breezes.

St. Clareâ€™s villa was an East Indian cottage, surrounded by light verandahs of bamboo-work, and opening on all sides into gardens and pleasure-grounds. The common sitting-room opened on to a large garden, fragrant with every picturesque plant and flower of the tropics, where winding paths ran down to the very shores of the lake, whose silvery sheet of water lay there, rising and falling in the sunbeams,â€”a picture never for an hour the same, yet every hour more beautiful.

It is now one of those intensely golden sunsets which kindles the whole horizon into one blaze of glory, and makes the water another sky. The lake lay in rosy or golden streaks, save where white-winged vessels glided hither and thither, like so many spirits, and little golden stars twinkled through the glow, and looked down at themselves as they trembled in the water.

Tom and Eva were seated on a little mossy seat, in an arbor, at the foot of the garden. It was Sunday evening, and Evaâ€™s Bible lay open on her knee. She read,â€”â€œAnd I saw a sea of glass, mingled with fire.â€
â€œTom,â€ said Eva, suddenly stopping, and pointing to the lake, â€œthere â€™t is.â€
â€œWhat, Miss Eva?â€
â€œDonâ€™t you see,â€”there?â€ said the child, pointing to the glassy water, which, as it rose and fell, reflected the golden glow of the sky. â€œThereâ€™s a â€™sea of glass, mingled with fire.â€™â€
â€œTrue enough, Miss Eva,â€ said Tom; and Tom sangâ€”

â€œO, had I the wings of the morning,
Â Â Â Â Iâ€™d fly away to Canaanâ€™s shore;
Bright angels should convey me home,
Â Â Â Â To the new Jerusalem.â€
â€œWhere do you suppose new Jerusalem is, Uncle Tom?â€ said Eva.
â€œO, up in the clouds, Miss Eva.â€

â€œThen I think I see it,â€ said Eva. â€œLook in those clouds!â€”they look like great gates of pearl; and you can see beyond themâ€”far, far offâ€”itâ€™s all gold. Tom, sing about â€™spirits bright.â€™â€
Tom sung the words of a well-known Methodist hymn,

â€œI see a band of spirits bright,
Â Â Â Â That taste the glories there;
They all are robed in spotless white,
Â Â Â Â And conquering palms they bear.â€
â€œUncle Tom, Iâ€™ve seen them,â€ said Eva.
Tom had no doubt of it at all; it did not surprise him in the least. If Eva had told him she had been to heaven, he would have thought it entirely probable.
â€œThey come to me sometimes in my sleep, those spirits;â€ and Evaâ€™s eyes grew dreamy, and she hummed, in a low voice,

â€œThey are all robed in spotless white,
Â Â Â Â And conquering palms they bear.â€
â€œUncle Tom,â€ said Eva, â€œIâ€™m going there.â€
â€œWhere, Miss Eva?â€
The child rose, and pointed her little hand to the sky; the glow of evening lit her golden hair and flushed cheek with a kind of unearthly radiance, and her eyes were bent earnestly on the skies.
â€œIâ€™m going there,â€ she said, â€œto the spirits bright, Tom; Iâ€™m going, before long.â€

The faithful old heart felt a sudden thrust; and Tom thought how often he had noticed, within six months, that Evaâ€™s little hands had grown thinner, and her skin more transparent, and her breath shorter; and how, when she ran or played in the garden, as she once could for hours, she became soon so tired and languid. He had heard Miss Ophelia speak often of a cough, that all her medicaments could not cure; and even now that fervent cheek and little hand were burning with hectic fever; and yet the thought that Evaâ€™s words suggested had never come to him till now.

Has there ever been a child like Eva? Yes, there have been; but their names are always on grave-stones, and their sweet smiles, their heavenly eyes, their singular words and ways, are among the buried treasures of yearning hearts. In how many families do you hear the legend that all the goodness and graces of the living are nothing to the peculiar charms of one who is not. It is as if heaven had an especial band of angels, whose office it was to sojourn for a season here, and endear to them the wayward human heart, that they might bear it upward with them in their homeward flight. When you see that deep, spiritual light in the eye,â€”when the little soul reveals itself in words sweeter and wiser than the ordinary words of children,â€”hope not to retain that child; for the seal of heaven is on it, and the light of immortality looks out from its eyes.
Even so, beloved Eva! fair star of thy dwelling! Thou art passing away; but they that love thee dearest know it not.
The colloquy between Tom and Eva was interrupted by a hasty call from Miss Ophelia.
â€œEvaâ€”Eva!â€”why, child, the dew is falling; you mustnâ€™t be out there!â€
Eva and Tom hastened in.

Miss Ophelia was old, and skilled in the tactics of nursing. She was from New England, and knew well the first guileful footsteps of that soft, insidious disease, which sweeps away so many of the fairest and loveliest, and, before one fibre of life seems broken, seals them irrevocably for death.
She had noted the slight, dry cough, the daily brightening cheek; nor could the lustre of the eye, and the airy buoyancy born of fever, deceive her.
She tried to communicate her fears to St. Clare; but he threw back her suggestions with a restless petulance, unlike his usual careless good-humor.
â€œDonâ€™t be croaking, Cousin,â€”I hate it!â€ he would say; â€œdonâ€™t you see that the child is only growing. Children always lose strength when they grow fast.â€
â€œBut she has that cough!â€
â€œO! nonsense of that cough!â€”it is not anything. She has taken a little cold, perhaps.â€
â€œWell, that was just the way Eliza Jane was taken, and Ellen and Maria Sanders.â€

â€œO! stop these hobgoblinâ€™ nurse legends. You old hands got so wise, that a child cannot cough, or sneeze, but you see desperation and ruin at hand. Only take care of the child, keep her from the night air, and donâ€™t let her play too hard, and sheâ€™ll do well enough.â€

So St. Clare said; but he grew nervous and restless. He watched Eva feverishly day by day, as might be told by the frequency with which he repeated over that â€œthe child was quite wellâ€â€”that there wasnâ€™t anything in that cough,â€”it was only some little stomach affection, such as children often had. But he kept by her more than before, took her oftener to ride with him, brought home every few days some receipt or strengthening mixture,â€”â€œnot,â€ he said, â€œthat the child needed it, but then it would not do her any harm.â€

If it must be told, the thing that struck a deeper pang to his heart than anything else was the daily increasing maturity of the childâ€™s mind and feelings. While still retaining all a childâ€™s fanciful graces, yet she often dropped, unconsciously, words of such a reach of thought, and strange unworldly wisdom, that they seemed to be an inspiration. At such times, St. Clare would feel a sudden thrill, and clasp her in his arms, as if that fond clasp could save her; and his heart rose up with wild determination to keep her, never to let her go.

The childâ€™s whole heart and soul seemed absorbed in works of love and kindness. Impulsively generous she had always been; but there was a touching and womanly thoughtfulness about her now, that every one noticed. She still loved to play with Topsy, and the various colored children; but she now seemed rather a spectator than an actor of their plays, and she would sit for half an hour at a time, laughing at the odd tricks of Topsy,â€”and then a shadow would seem to pass across her face, her eyes grew misty, and her thoughts were afar.
â€œMamma,â€ she said, suddenly, to her mother, one day, â€œwhy donâ€™t we teach our servants to read?â€
â€œWhat a question child! People never do.â€
â€œWhy donâ€™t they?â€ said Eva.
â€œBecause it is no use for them to read. It donâ€™t help them to work any better, and they are not made for anything else.â€
â€œBut they ought to read the Bible, mamma, to learn Godâ€™s will.â€
â€œO! they can get that read to them all they need.â€
â€œIt seems to me, mamma, the Bible is for every one to read themselves. They need it a great many times when there is nobody to read it.â€
â€œEva, you are an odd child,â€ said her mother.
â€œMiss Ophelia has taught Topsy to read,â€ continued Eva.
â€œYes, and you see how much good it does. Topsy is the worst creature I ever saw!â€
â€œHereâ€™s poor Mammy!â€ said Eva. â€œShe does love the Bible so much, and wishes so she could read! And what will she do when I canâ€™t read to her?â€
Marie was busy, turning over the contents of a drawer, as she answered,

â€œWell, of course, by and by, Eva, you will have other things to think of besides reading the Bible round to servants. Not but that is very proper; Iâ€™ve done it myself, when I had health. But when you come to be dressing and going into company, you wonâ€™t have time. See here!â€ she added, â€œthese jewels Iâ€™m going to give you when you come out. I wore them to my first ball. I can tell you, Eva, I made a sensation.â€
Eva took the jewel-case, and lifted from it a diamond necklace. Her large, thoughtful eyes rested on them, but it was plain her thoughts were elsewhere.
â€œHow sober you look child!â€ said Marie.
â€œAre these worth a great deal of money, mamma?â€
â€œTo be sure, they are. Father sent to France for them. They are worth a small fortune.â€
â€œI wish I had them,â€ said Eva, â€œto do what I pleased with!â€
â€œWhat would you do with them?â€
â€œIâ€™d sell them, and buy a place in the free states, and take all our people there, and hire teachers, to teach them to read and write.â€
Eva was cut short by her motherâ€™s laughing.
â€œSet up a boarding-school! Wouldnâ€™t you teach them to play on the piano, and paint on velvet?â€

â€œIâ€™d teach them to read their own Bible, and write their own letters, and read letters that are written to them,â€ said Eva, steadily. â€œI know, mamma, it does come very hard on them that they canâ€™t do these things. Tom feels itâ€”Mammy does,â€”a great many of them do. I think itâ€™s wrong.â€
â€œCome, come, Eva; you are only a child! You donâ€™t know anything about these things,â€ said Marie; â€œbesides, your talking makes my head ache.â€
Marie always had a headache on hand for any conversation that did not exactly suit her.
Eva stole away; but after that, she assiduously gave Mammy reading lessons.

div.head:
Chapter XXIII
Henrique
div.p: About this time, St. Clareâ€™s brother Alfred, with his eldest son, a boy of twelve, spent a day or two with the family at the lake.

No sight could be more singular and beautiful than that of these twin brothers. Nature, instead of instituting resemblances between them, had made them opposites on every point; yet a mysterious tie seemed to unite them in a closer friendship than ordinary.

They used to saunter, arm in arm, up and down the alleys and walks of the garden. Augustine, with his blue eyes and golden hair, his ethereally flexible form and vivacious features; and Alfred, dark-eyed, with haughty Roman profile, firmly-knit limbs, and decided bearing. They were always abusing each otherâ€™s opinions and practices, and yet never a whit the less absorbed in each otherâ€™s society; in fact, the very contrariety seemed to unite them, like the attraction between opposite poles of the magnet.

Henrique, the eldest son of Alfred, was a noble, dark-eyed, princely boy, full of vivacity and spirit; and, from the first moment of introduction, seemed to be perfectly fascinated by the spirituelle graces of his cousin Evangeline.

Eva had a little pet pony, of a snowy whiteness. It was easy as a cradle, and as gentle as its little mistress; and this pony was now brought up to the back verandah by Tom, while a little mulatto boy of about thirteen led along a small black Arabian, which had just been imported, at a great expense, for Henrique.
Henrique had a boyâ€™s pride in his new possession; and, as he advanced and took the reins out of the hands of his little groom, he looked carefully over him, and his brow darkened.
â€œWhatâ€™s this, Dodo, you little lazy dog! you havenâ€™t rubbed my horse down, this morning.â€
â€œYes, Masâ€™r,â€ said Dodo, submissively; â€œhe got that dust on his own self.â€
â€œYou rascal, shut your mouth!â€ said Henrique, violently raising his riding-whip. â€œHow dare you speak?â€

The boy was a handsome, bright-eyed mulatto, of just Henriqueâ€™s size, and his curling hair hung round a high, bold forehead. He had white blood in his veins, as could be seen by the quick flush in his cheek, and the sparkle of his eye, as he eagerly tried to speak.
â€œMasâ€™r Henrique!â€”â€ he began.
Henrique struck him across the face with his riding-whip, and, seizing one of his arms, forced him on to his knees, and beat him till he was out of breath.
â€œThere, you impudent dog! Now will you learn not to answer back when I speak to you? Take the horse back, and clean him properly. Iâ€™ll teach you your place!â€

â€œYoung Masâ€™r,â€ said Tom, â€œI specs what he was gwine to say was, that the horse would roll when he was bringing him up from the stable; heâ€™s so full of spirits,â€”thatâ€™s the way he got that dirt on him; I looked to his cleaning.â€
â€œYou hold your tongue till youâ€™re asked to speak!â€ said Henrique, turning on his heel, and walking up the steps to speak to Eva, who stood in her riding-dress.
â€œDear Cousin, Iâ€™m sorry this stupid fellow has kept you waiting,â€ he said. â€œLetâ€™s sit down here, on this seat till they come. Whatâ€™s the matter, Cousin?â€”you look sober.â€
â€œHow could you be so cruel and wicked to poor Dodo?â€ asked Eva.
â€œCruel,â€”wicked!â€ said the boy, with unaffected surprise. â€œWhat do you mean, dear Eva?â€
â€œI donâ€™t want you to call me dear Eva, when you do so,â€ said Eva.

â€œDear Cousin, you donâ€™t know Dodo; itâ€™s the only way to manage him, heâ€™s so full of lies and excuses. The only way is to put him down at once,â€”not let him open his mouth; thatâ€™s the way papa manages.â€
â€œBut Uncle Tom said it was an accident, and he never tells what isnâ€™t true.â€
â€œHeâ€™s an uncommon old nigger, then!â€ said Henrique. â€œDodo will lie as fast as he can speak.â€
â€œYou frighten him into deceiving, if you treat him so.â€
â€œWhy, Eva, youâ€™ve really taken such a fancy to Dodo, that I shall be jealous.â€
â€œBut you beat him,â€”and he didnâ€™t deserve it.â€

â€œO, well, it may go for some time when he does, and donâ€™t get it. A few cuts never come amiss with Dodo,â€”heâ€™s a regular spirit, I can tell you; but I wonâ€™t beat him again before you, if it troubles you.â€
Eva was not satisfied, but found it in vain to try to make her handsome cousin understand her feelings.
Dodo soon appeared, with the horses.
â€œWell, Dodo, youâ€™ve done pretty well, this time,â€ said his young master, with a more gracious air. â€œCome, now, and hold Miss Evaâ€™s horse while I put her on to the saddle.â€
Dodo came and stood by Evaâ€™s pony. His face was troubled; his eyes looked as if he had been crying.
Henrique, who valued himself on his gentlemanly adroitness in all matters of gallantry, soon had his fair cousin in the saddle, and, gathering the reins, placed them in her hands.
But Eva bent to the other side of the horse, where Dodo was standing, and said, as he relinquished the reins,â€”â€œThatâ€™s a good boy, Dodo;â€”thank you!â€
Dodo looked up in amazement into the sweet young face; the blood rushed to his cheeks, and the tears to his eyes.
â€œHere, Dodo,â€ said his master, imperiously.
Dodo sprang and held the horse, while his master mounted.
â€œThereâ€™s a picayune for you to buy candy with, Dodo,â€ said Henrique; â€œgo get some.â€

And Henrique cantered down the walk after Eva. Dodo stood looking after the two children. One had given him money; and one had given him what he wanted far more,â€”a kind word, kindly spoken. Dodo had been only a few months away from his mother. His master had bought him at a slave warehouse, for his handsome face, to be a match to the handsome pony; and he was now getting his breaking in, at the hands of his young master.
The scene of the beating had been witnessed by the two brothers St. Clare, from another part of the garden.
Augustineâ€™s cheek flushed; but he only observed, with his usual sarcastic carelessness.
â€œI suppose thatâ€™s what we may call republican education, Alfred?â€
â€œHenrique is a devil of a fellow, when his bloodâ€™s up,â€ said Alfred, carelessly.
â€œI suppose you consider this an instructive practice for him,â€ said Augustine, drily.

â€œI couldnâ€™t help it, if I didnâ€™t. Henrique is a regular little tempest;â€”his mother and I have given him up, long ago. But, then, that Dodo is a perfect sprite,â€”no amount of whipping can hurt him.â€
â€œAnd this by way of teaching Henrique the first verse of a republicanâ€™s catechism, â€™All men are born free and equal!â€™â€
â€œPoh!â€ said Alfred; â€œone of Tom Jeffersonâ€™s pieces of French sentiment and humbug. Itâ€™s perfectly ridiculous to have that going the rounds among us, to this day.â€
â€œI think it is,â€ said St. Clare, significantly.

â€œBecause,â€ said Alfred, â€œwe can see plainly enough that all men are not born free, nor born equal; they are born anything else. For my part, I think half this republican talk sheer humbug. It is the educated, the intelligent, the wealthy, the refined, who ought to have equal rights and not the canaille.â€
â€œIf you can keep the canaille of that opinion,â€ said Augustine. â€œThey took their turn once, in France.â€
â€œOf course, they must be kept down, consistently, steadily, as I should,â€ said Alfred, setting his foot hard down as if he were standing on somebody.
â€œIt makes a terrible slip when they get up,â€ said Augustine,â€”â€œin St. Domingo, for instance.â€

â€œPoh!â€ said Alfred, â€œweâ€™ll take care of that, in this country. We must set our face against all this educating, elevating talk, that is getting about now; the lower class must not be educated.â€

â€œThat is past praying for,â€ said Augustine; â€œeducated they will be, and we have only to say how. Our system is educating them in barbarism and brutality. We are breaking all humanizing ties, and making them brute beasts; and, if they get the upper hand, such we shall find them.â€
â€œThey shall never get the upper hand!â€ said Alfred.
â€œThatâ€™s right,â€ said St. Clare; â€œput on the steam, fasten down the escape-valve, and sit on it, and see where youâ€™ll land.â€
â€œWell,â€ said Alfred, â€œwe will see. Iâ€™m not afraid to sit on the escape-valve, as long as the boilers are strong, and the machinery works well.â€

â€œThe nobles in Louis XVI.â€˜s time thought just so; and Austria and Pius IX. think so now; and, some pleasant morning, you may all be caught up to meet each other in the air, when the boilers burst.â€
â€œDies declarabit,â€ said Alfred, laughing.

â€œI tell you,â€ said Augustine, â€œif there is anything that is revealed with the strength of a divine law in our times, it is that the masses are to rise, and the under class become the upper one.â€

â€œThatâ€™s one of your red republican humbugs, Augustine! Why didnâ€™t you ever take to the stump;â€”youâ€™d make a famous stump orator! Well, I hope I shall be dead before this millennium of your greasy masses comes on.â€

â€œGreasy or not greasy, they will govern you, when their time comes,â€ said Augustine; â€œand they will be just such rulers as you make them. The French noblesse chose to have the people â€™sans culottes,â€™ and they had â€™sans culotteâ€™ governors to their heartsâ€™ content. The people of Haytiâ€”â€

â€œO, come, Augustine! as if we hadnâ€™t had enough of that abominable, contemptible Hayti! [1] The Haytiens were not Anglo Saxons; if they had been there would have been another story. The Anglo Saxon is the dominant race of the world, and is to be so.â€

[1] In August 1791, as a consequence of the French Revolution, the black slaves and mulattoes on Haiti rose in revolt against the whites, and in the period of turmoil that followed enormous cruelties were practised by both sides. The â€œEmperorâ€ Dessalines, come to power in 1804, massacred all the whites on the island. Haitian bloodshed became an argument to show the barbarous nature of the Negro, a doctrine Wendell Phillips sought to combat in his celebrated lecture on Toussaint Lâ€™Ouverture.

â€œWell, there is a pretty fair infusion of Anglo Saxon blood among our slaves, now,â€ said Augustine. â€œThere are plenty among them who have only enough of the African to give a sort of tropical warmth and fervor to our calculating firmness and foresight. If ever the San Domingo hour comes, Anglo Saxon blood will lead on the day. Sons of white fathers, with all our haughty feelings burning in their veins, will not always be bought and sold and traded. They will rise, and raise with them their motherâ€™s race.â€
â€œStuff!â€”nonsense!â€

â€œWell,â€ said Augustine, â€œthere goes an old saying to this effect, â€™As it was in the days of Noah so shall it be;â€”they ate, they drank, they planted, they builded, and knew not till the flood came and took them.â€™â€

â€œOn the whole, Augustine, I think your talents might do for a circuit rider,â€ said Alfred, laughing. â€œNever you fear for us; possession is our nine points. Weâ€™ve got the power. This subject race,â€ said he, stamping firmly, â€œis down and shall stay down! We have energy enough to manage our own powder.â€

â€œSons trained like your Henrique will be grand guardians of your powder-magazines,â€ said Augustine,â€”â€œso cool and self-possessed! The proverb says, â€™They that cannot govern themselves cannot govern others.â€™â€

â€œThere is a trouble thereâ€ said Alfred, thoughtfully; â€œthereâ€™s no doubt that our system is a difficult one to train children under. It gives too free scope to the passions, altogether, which, in our climate, are hot enough. I find trouble with Henrique. The boy is generous and warm-hearted, but a perfect fire-cracker when excited. I believe I shall send him North for his education, where obedience is more fashionable, and where he will associate more with equals, and less with dependents.â€
â€œSince training children is the staple work of the human race,â€ said Augustine, â€œI should think it something of a consideration that our system does not work well there.â€

â€œIt does not for some things,â€ said Alfred; â€œfor others, again, it does. It makes boys manly and courageous; and the very vices of an abject race tend to strengthen in them the opposite virtues. I think Henrique, now, has a keener sense of the beauty of truth, from seeing lying and deception the universal badge of slavery.â€
â€œA Christian-like view of the subject, certainly!â€ said Augustine.
â€œItâ€™s true, Christian-like or not; and is about as Christian-like as most other things in the world,â€ said Alfred.
â€œThat may be,â€ said St. Clare.
â€œWell, thereâ€™s no use in talking, Augustine. I believe weâ€™ve been round and round this old track five hundred times, more or less. What do you say to a game of backgammon?â€
The two brothers ran up the verandah steps, and were soon seated at a light bamboo stand, with the backgammon-board between them. As they were setting their men, Alfred said,
â€œI tell you, Augustine, if I thought as you do, I should do something.â€
â€œI dare say you would,â€”you are one of the doing sort,â€”but what?â€
â€œWhy, elevate your own servants, for a specimen,â€ said Alfred, with a half-scornful smile.

â€œYou might as well set Mount Ã†tna on them flat, and tell them to stand up under it, as tell me to elevate my servants under all the superincumbent mass of society upon them. One man can do nothing, against the whole action of a community. Education, to do anything, must be a state education; or there must be enough agreed in it to make a current.â€
â€œYou take the first throw,â€ said Alfred; and the brothers were soon lost in the game, and heard no more till the scraping of horsesâ€™ feet was heard under the verandah.

â€œThere come the children,â€ said Augustine, rising. â€œLook here, Alf! Did you ever see anything so beautiful?â€ And, in truth, it was a beautiful sight. Henrique, with his bold brow, and dark, glossy curls, and glowing cheek, was laughing gayly as he bent towards his fair cousin, as they came on. She was dressed in a blue riding dress, with a cap of the same color. Exercise had given a brilliant hue to her cheeks, and heightened the effect of her singularly transparent skin, and golden hair.
â€œGood heavens! what perfectly dazzling beauty!â€ said Alfred. â€œI tell you, Auguste, wonâ€™t she make some hearts ache, one of these days?â€
â€œShe will, too truly,â€”God knows Iâ€™m afraid so!â€ said St. Clare, in a tone of sudden bitterness, as he hurried down to take her off her horse.
â€œEva darling! youâ€™re not much tired?â€ he said, as he clasped her in his arms.
â€œNo, papa,â€ said the child; but her short, hard breathing alarmed her father.
â€œHow could you ride so fast, dear?â€”you know itâ€™s bad for you.â€
â€œI felt so well, papa, and liked it so much, I forgot.â€
St. Clare carried her in his arms into the parlor, and laid her on the sofa.
â€œHenrique, you must be careful of Eva,â€ said he; â€œyou mustnâ€™t ride fast with her.â€
â€œIâ€™ll take her under my care,â€ said Henrique, seating himself by the sofa, and taking Evaâ€™s hand.
Eva soon found herself much better. Her father and uncle resumed their game, and the children were left together.

â€œDo you know, Eva, Iâ€™m sorry papa is only going to stay two days here, and then I shanâ€™t see you again for ever so long! If I stay with you, Iâ€™d try to be good, and not be cross to Dodo, and so on. I donâ€™t mean to treat Dodo ill; but, you know, Iâ€™ve got such a quick temper. Iâ€™m not really bad to him, though. I give him a picayune, now and then; and you see he dresses well. I think, on the whole, Dodo â€™s pretty well off.â€
â€œWould you think you were well off, if there were not one creature in the world near you to love you?â€
â€œI?â€”Well, of course not.â€
â€œAnd you have taken Dodo away from all the friends he ever had, and now he has not a creature to love him;â€”nobody can be good that way.â€
â€œWell, I canâ€™t help it, as I know of. I canâ€™t get his mother and I canâ€™t love him myself, nor anybody else, as I know of.â€
â€œWhy canâ€™t you?â€ said Eva.
â€œLove Dodo! Why, Eva, you wouldnâ€™t have me! I may like him well enough; but you donâ€™t love your servants.â€
â€œI do, indeed.â€
â€œHow odd!â€
â€œDonâ€™t the Bible say we must love everybody?â€
â€œO, the Bible! To be sure, it says a great many such things; but, then, nobody ever thinks of doing them,â€”you know, Eva, nobody does.â€
Eva did not speak; her eyes were fixed and thoughtful for a few moments.
â€œAt any rate,â€ she said, â€œdear Cousin, do love poor Dodo, and be kind to him, for my sake!â€

â€œI could love anything, for your sake, dear Cousin; for I really think you are the loveliest creature that I ever saw!â€ And Henrique spoke with an earnestness that flushed his handsome face. Eva received it with perfect simplicity, without even a change of feature; merely saying, â€œIâ€™m glad you feel so, dear Henrique! I hope you will remember.â€
The dinner-bell put an end to the interview.

div.head:
Chapter XXIV
Foreshadowings
div.p: Two days after this, Alfred St. Clare and Augustine parted; and Eva, who had been stimulated, by the society of her young cousin, to exertions beyond her strength, began to fail rapidly. St. Clare was at last willing to call in medical advice,â€”a thing from which he had always shrunk, because it was the admission of an unwelcome truth.
But, for a day or two, Eva was so unwell as to be confined to the house; and the doctor was called.

Marie St. Clare had taken no notice of the childâ€™s gradually decaying health and strength, because she was completely absorbed in studying out two or three new forms of disease to which she believed she herself was a victim. It was the first principle of Marieâ€™s belief that nobody ever was or could be so great a sufferer as herself; and, therefore, she always repelled quite indignantly any suggestion that any one around her could be sick. She was always sure, in such a case, that it was nothing but laziness, or want of energy; and that, if they had had the suffering she had, they would soon know the difference.
Miss Ophelia had several times tried to awaken her maternal fears about Eva; but to no avail.
â€œI donâ€™t see as anything ails the child,â€ she would say; â€œshe runs about, and plays.â€
â€œBut she has a cough.â€

â€œCough! you donâ€™t need to tell me about a cough. Iâ€™ve always been subject to a cough, all my days. When I was of Evaâ€™s age, they thought I was in a consumption. Night after night, Mammy used to sit up with me. O! Evaâ€™s cough is not anything.â€
â€œBut she gets weak, and is short-breathed.â€
â€œLaw! Iâ€™ve had that, years and years; itâ€™s only a nervous affection.â€
â€œBut she sweats so, nights!â€

â€œWell, I have, these ten years. Very often, night after night, my clothes will be wringing wet. There wonâ€™t be a dry thread in my night-clothes and the sheets will be so that Mammy has to hang them up to dry! Eva doesnâ€™t sweat anything like that!â€
Miss Ophelia shut her mouth for a season. But, now that Eva was fairly and visibly prostrated, and a doctor called, Marie, all on a sudden, took a new turn.

â€œShe knew it,â€ she said; â€œshe always felt it, that she was destined to be the most miserable of mothers. Here she was, with her wretched health, and her only darling child going down to the grave before her eyes;â€â€”and Marie routed up Mammy nights, and rumpussed and scolded, with more energy than ever, all day, on the strength of this new misery.
â€œMy dear Marie, donâ€™t talk so!â€ said St. Clare. â€œYou ought not to give up the case so, at once.â€
â€œYou have not a motherâ€™s feelings, St. Clare! You never could understand me!â€”you donâ€™t now.â€
â€œBut donâ€™t talk so, as if it were a gone case!â€
â€œI canâ€™t take it as indifferently as you can, St. Clare. If you donâ€™t feel when your only child is in this alarming state, I do. Itâ€™s a blow too much for me, with all I was bearing before.â€

â€œItâ€™s true,â€ said St. Clare, â€œthat Eva is very delicate, that I always knew; and that she has grown so rapidly as to exhaust her strength; and that her situation is critical. But just now she is only prostrated by the heat of the weather, and by the excitement of her cousinâ€™s visit, and the exertions she made. The physician says there is room for hope.â€

â€œWell, of course, if you can look on the bright side, pray do; itâ€™s a mercy if people havenâ€™t sensitive feelings, in this world. I am sure I wish I didnâ€™t feel as I do; it only makes me completely wretched! I wish I could be as easy as the rest of you!â€

And the â€œrest of themâ€ had good reason to breathe the same prayer, for Marie paraded her new misery as the reason and apology for all sorts of inflictions on every one about her. Every word that was spoken by anybody, everything that was done or was not done everywhere, was only a new proof that she was surrounded by hard-hearted, insensible beings, who were unmindful of her peculiar sorrows. Poor Eva heard some of these speeches; and nearly cried her little eyes out, in pity for her mamma, and in sorrow that she should make her so much distress.

In a week or two, there was a great improvement of symptoms,â€”one of those deceitful lulls, by which her inexorable disease so often beguiles the anxious heart, even on the verge of the grave. Evaâ€™s step was again in the garden,â€”in the balconies; she played and laughed again,â€”and her father, in a transport, declared that they should soon have her as hearty as anybody. Miss Ophelia and the physician alone felt no encouragement from this illusive truce. There was one other heart, too, that felt the same certainty, and that was the little heart of Eva. What is it that sometimes speaks in the soul so calmly, so clearly, that its earthly time is short? Is it the secret instinct of decaying nature, or the soulâ€™s impulsive throb, as immortality draws on? Be it what it may, it rested in the heart of Eva, a calm, sweet, prophetic certainty that Heaven was near; calm as the light of sunset, sweet as the bright stillness of autumn, there her little heart reposed, only troubled by sorrow for those who loved her so dearly.
For the child, though nursed so tenderly, and though life was unfolding before her with every brightness that love and wealth could give, had no regret for herself in dying.

In that book which she and her simple old friend had read so much together, she had seen and taken to her young heart the image of one who loved the little child; and, as she gazed and mused, He had ceased to be an image and a picture of the distant past, and come to be a living, all-surrounding reality. His love enfolded her childish heart with more than mortal tenderness; and it was to Him, she said, she was going, and to his home.

But her heart yearned with sad tenderness for all that she was to leave behind. Her father most,â€”for Eva, though she never distinctly thought so, had an instinctive perception that she was more in his heart than any other. She loved her mother because she was so loving a creature, and all the selfishness that she had seen in her only saddened and perplexed her; for she had a childâ€™s implicit trust that her mother could not do wrong. There was something about her that Eva never could make out; and she always smoothed it over with thinking that, after all, it was mamma, and she loved her very dearly indeed.

She felt, too, for those fond, faithful servants, to whom she was as daylight and sunshine. Children do not usually generalize; but Eva was an uncommonly mature child, and the things that she had witnessed of the evils of the system under which they were living had fallen, one by one, into the depths of her thoughtful, pondering heart. She had vague longings to do something for them,â€”to bless and save not only them, but all in their condition,â€”longings that contrasted sadly with the feebleness of her little frame.
â€œUncle Tom,â€ she said, one day, when she was reading to her friend, â€œI can understand why Jesus wanted to die for us.â€
â€œWhy, Miss Eva?â€
â€œBecause Iâ€™ve felt so, too.â€
â€œWhat is it Miss Eva?â€”I donâ€™t understand.â€

â€œI canâ€™t tell you; but, when I saw those poor creatures on the boat, you know, when you came up and I,â€”some had lost their mothers, and some their husbands, and some mothers cried for their little childrenâ€”and when I heard about poor Prue,â€”oh, wasnâ€™t that dreadful!â€”and a great many other times, Iâ€™ve felt that I would be glad to die, if my dying could stop all this misery. I would die for them, Tom, if I could,â€ said the child, earnestly, laying her little thin hand on his.
Tom looked at the child with awe; and when she, hearing her fatherâ€™s voice, glided away, he wiped his eyes many times, as he looked after her.
â€œItâ€™s jest no use tryinâ€™ to keep Miss Eva here,â€ he said to Mammy, whom he met a moment after. â€œSheâ€™s got the Lordâ€™s mark in her forehead.â€

â€œAh, yes, yes,â€ said Mammy, raising her hands; â€œIâ€™ve allers said so. She wasnâ€™t never like a child thatâ€™s to liveâ€”there was allers something deep in her eyes. Iâ€™ve told Missis so, many the time; itâ€™s a cominâ€™ true,â€”we all sees it,â€”dear, little, blessed lamb!â€

Eva came tripping up the verandah steps to her father. It was late in the afternoon, and the rays of the sun formed a kind of glory behind her, as she came forward in her white dress, with her golden hair and glowing cheeks, her eyes unnaturally bright with the slow fever that burned in her veins.

St. Clare had called her to show a statuette that he had been buying for her; but her appearance, as she came on, impressed him suddenly and painfully. There is a kind of beauty so intense, yet so fragile, that we cannot bear to look at it. Her father folded her suddenly in his arms, and almost forgot what he was going to tell her.
â€œEva, dear, you are better now-a-days,â€”are you not?â€
â€œPapa,â€ said Eva, with sudden firmness â€œIâ€™ve had things I wanted to say to you, a great while. I want to say them now, before I get weaker.â€
St. Clare trembled as Eva seated herself in his lap. She laid her head on his bosom, and said,
â€œItâ€™s all no use, papa, to keep it to myself any longer. The time is coming that I am going to leave you. I am going, and never to come back!â€ and Eva sobbed.

â€œO, now, my dear little Eva!â€ said St. Clare, trembling as he spoke, but speaking cheerfully, â€œyouâ€™ve got nervous and low-spirited; you mustnâ€™t indulge such gloomy thoughts. See here, Iâ€™ve bought a statuette for you!â€

â€œNo, papa,â€ said Eva, putting it gently away, â€œdonâ€™t deceive yourself!â€”I am not any better, I know it perfectly well,â€”and I am going, before long. I am not nervous,â€”I am not low-spirited. If it were not for you, papa, and my friends, I should be perfectly happy. I want to go,â€”I long to go!â€
â€œWhy, dear child, what has made your poor little heart so sad? You have had everything, to make you happy, that could be given you.â€

â€œI had rather be in heaven; though, only for my friendsâ€™ sake, I would be willing to live. There are a great many things here that make me sad, that seem dreadful to me; I had rather be there; but I donâ€™t want to leave you,â€”it almost breaks my heart!â€
â€œWhat makes you sad, and seems dreadful, Eva?â€
â€œO, things that are done, and done all the time. I feel sad for our poor people; they love me dearly, and they are all good and kind to me. I wish, papa, they were all free.â€
â€œWhy, Eva, child, donâ€™t you think they are well enough off now?â€

â€œO, but, papa, if anything should happen to you, what would become of them? There are very few men like you, papa. Uncle Alfred isnâ€™t like you, and mamma isnâ€™t; and then, think of poor old Prueâ€™s owners! What horrid things people do, and can do!â€ and Eva shuddered.
â€œMy dear child, you are too sensitive. Iâ€™m sorry I ever let you hear such stories.â€

â€œO, thatâ€™s what troubles me, papa. You want me to live so happy, and never to have any pain,â€”never suffer anything,â€”not even hear a sad story, when other poor creatures have nothing but pain and sorrow, all their lives;â€”it seems selfish.
