It was a new kind of work there,â€”a deed of charity, small as it was; but it woke an answering touch in their hearts,â€”an expression of womanly kindness came over their hard faces; they mixed his cake for him, and tended its baking; and Tom sat down by the light of the fire, and drew out his Bible,â€”for he had need for comfort.
â€œWhatâ€™s that?â€ said one of the woman.
â€œA Bible,â€ said Tom.
â€œGood Lord! hanâ€™t seen un since I was in Kentuck.â€
â€œWas you raised in Kentuck?â€ said Tom, with interest.
â€œYes, and well raised, too; never â€™spected to come to dis yer!â€ said the woman, sighing.
â€œWhatâ€™s dat ar book, any way?â€ said the other woman.
â€œWhy, the Bible.â€
â€œLaws a me! whatâ€™s dat?â€ said the woman.

â€œDo tell! you never hearn on â€™t?â€ said the other woman. â€œI used to har Missis a readinâ€™ on â€™t, sometimes, in Kentuck; but, laws oâ€™ me! we donâ€™t har nothinâ€™ here but crackinâ€™ and swarinâ€™.â€
â€œRead a piece, anyways!â€ said the first woman, curiously, seeing Tom attentively poring over it.
Tom read,â€”â€œCome unto Me, all ye that labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.â€
â€œThemâ€™s good words, enough,â€ said the woman; â€œwho says â€™em?â€
â€œThe Lord,â€ said Tom.

â€œI jest wish I knowâ€™d whar to find Him,â€ said the woman. â€œI would go; â€™pears like I never should get rested again. My flesh is fairly sore, and I tremble all over, every day, and Samboâ€™s allers a jawinâ€™ at me, â€™cause I doesnâ€™t pick faster; and nights itâ€™s most midnight â€™fore I can get my supper; and den â€™pears like I donâ€™t turn over and shut my eyes, â€™fore I hear de horn blow to get up, and at it agin in de morninâ€™. If I knew whar de Lor was, Iâ€™d tell him.â€
â€œHeâ€™s here, heâ€™s everywhere,â€ said Tom.
â€œLor, you anâ€™t gwine to make me believe dat ar! I know de Lord anâ€™t here,â€ said the woman; â€œâ€˜tanâ€™t no use talking, though. Iâ€™s jest gwine to camp down, and sleep while I ken.â€
The women went off to their cabins, and Tom sat alone, by the smouldering fire, that flickered up redly in his face.

The silver, fair-browed moon rose in the purple sky, and looked down, calm and silent, as God looks on the scene of misery and oppression,â€”looked calmly on the lone black man, as he sat, with his arms folded, and his Bible on his knee.

â€œIs God HERE?â€ Ah, how is it possible for the untaught heart to keep its faith, unswerving, in the face of dire misrule, and palpable, unrebuked injustice? In that simple heart waged a fierce conflict; the crushing sense of wrong, the foreshadowing, of a whole life of future misery, the wreck of all past hopes, mournfully tossing in the soulâ€™s sight, like dead corpses of wife, and child, and friend, rising from the dark wave, and surging in the face of the half-drowned mariner! Ah, was it easy here to believe and hold fast the great password of Christian faith, that â€œGod IS, and is the REWARDER of them that diligently seek Himâ€?

Tom rose, disconsolate, and stumbled into the cabin that had been allotted to him. The floor was already strewn with weary sleepers, and the foul air of the place almost repelled him; but the heavy night-dews were chill, and his limbs weary, and, wrapping about him a tattered blanket, which formed his only bed-clothing, he stretched himself in the straw and fell asleep.

In dreams, a gentle voice came over his ear; he was sitting on the mossy seat in the garden by Lake Pontchartrain, and Eva, with her serious eyes bent downward, was reading to him from the Bible; and he heard her read.

â€œWhen thou passest through the waters, I will be with thee, and the rivers they shall not overflow thee; when thou walkest through the fire, thou shalt not be burned, neither shall the flame kindle upon thee; for I am the Lord thy God, the Holy One of Israel, thy Saviour.â€

Gradually the words seemed to melt and fade, as in a divine music; the child raised her deep eyes, and fixed them lovingly on him, and rays of warmth and comfort seemed to go from them to his heart; and, as if wafted on the music, she seemed to rise on shining wings, from which flakes and spangles of gold fell off like stars, and she was gone.

Tom woke. Was it a dream? Let it pass for one. But who shall say that that sweet young spirit, which in life so yearned to comfort and console the distressed, was forbidden of God to assume this ministry after death?

It is a beautiful belief,
Â Â Â Â That ever round our head
Are hovering, on angel wings,
Â Â Â Â The spirits of the dead.

div.head:
CHAPTER XXXIII
Cassy
div.p: â€œAnd behold, the tears of such as were oppressed, and they had no comforter; and on the side of their oppressors there was power, but they had no comforter.â€â€”ECCL. 4:1

It took but a short time to familiarize Tom with all that was to be hoped or feared in his new way of life. He was an expert and efficient workman in whatever he undertook; and was, both from habit and principle, prompt and faithful. Quiet and peaceable in his disposition, he hoped, by unremitting diligence, to avert from himself at least a portion of the evils of his condition. He saw enough of abuse and misery to make him sick and weary; but he determined to toil on, with religious patience, committing himself to Him that judgeth righteously, not without hope that some way of escape might yet be opened to him.

Legree took a silent note of Tomâ€™s availability. He rated him as a first-class hand; and yet he felt a secret dislike to him,â€”the native antipathy of bad to good. He saw, plainly, that when, as was often the case, his violence and brutality fell on the helpless, Tom took notice of it; for, so subtle is the atmosphere of opinion, that it will make itself felt, without words; and the opinion even of a slave may annoy a master. Tom in various ways manifested a tenderness of feeling, a commiseration for his fellow-sufferers, strange and new to them, which was watched with a jealous eye by Legree. He had purchased Tom with a view of eventually making him a sort of overseer, with whom he might, at times, intrust his affairs, in short absences; and, in his view, the first, second, and third requisite for that place, was hardness. Legree made up his mind, that, as Tom was not hard to his hand, he would harden him forthwith; and some few weeks after Tom had been on the place, he determined to commence the process.

One morning, when the hands were mustered for the field, Tom noticed, with surprise, a new comer among them, whose appearance excited his attention. It was a woman, tall and slenderly formed, with remarkably delicate hands and feet, and dressed in neat and respectable garments. By the appearance of her face, she might have been between thirty-five and forty; and it was a face that, once seen, could never be forgotten,â€”one of those that, at a glance, seem to convey to us an idea of a wild, painful, and romantic history. Her forehead was high, and her eyebrows marked with beautiful clearness. Her straight, well-formed nose, her finely-cut mouth, and the graceful contour of her head and neck, showed that she must once have been beautiful; but her face was deeply wrinkled with lines of pain, and of proud and bitter endurance. Her complexion was sallow and unhealthy, her cheeks thin, her features sharp, and her whole form emaciated. But her eye was the most remarkable feature,â€”so large, so heavily black, overshadowed by long lashes of equal darkness, and so wildly, mournfully despairing. There was a fierce pride and defiance in every line of her face, in every curve of the flexible lip, in every motion of her body; but in her eye was a deep, settled night of anguish,â€”an expression so hopeless and unchanging as to contrast fearfully with the scorn and pride expressed by her whole demeanor.

Where she came from, or who she was, Tom did not know. The first he did know, she was walking by his side, erect and proud, in the dim gray of the dawn. To the gang, however, she was known; for there was much looking and turning of heads, and a smothered yet apparent exultation among the miserable, ragged, half-starved creatures by whom she was surrounded.
â€œGot to come to it, at last,â€”glad of it!â€ said one.
â€œHe! he! he!â€ said another; â€œyouâ€™ll know how good it is, Misse!â€
â€œWeâ€™ll see her work!â€
â€œWonder if sheâ€™ll get a cutting up, at night, like the rest of us!â€
â€œIâ€™d be glad to see her down for a flogging, Iâ€™ll bound!â€ said another.

The woman took no notice of these taunts, but walked on, with the same expression of angry scorn, as if she heard nothing. Tom had always lived among refined, and cultivated people, and he felt intuitively, from her air and bearing, that she belonged to that class; but how or why she could be fallen to those degrading circumstances, he could not tell. The woman neither looked at him nor spoke to him, though, all the way to the field, she kept close at his side.

Tom was soon busy at his work; but, as the woman was at no great distance from him, he often glanced an eye to her, at her work. He saw, at a glance, that a native adroitness and handiness made the task to her an easier one than it proved to many. She picked very fast and very clean, and with an air of scorn, as if she despised both the work and the disgrace and humiliation of the circumstances in which she was placed.

In the course of the day, Tom was working near the mulatto woman who had been bought in the same lot with himself. She was evidently in a condition of great suffering, and Tom often heard her praying, as she wavered and trembled, and seemed about to fall down. Tom silently as he came near to her, transferred several handfuls of cotton from his own sack to hers.
â€œO, donâ€™t, donâ€™t!â€ said the woman, looking surprised; â€œitâ€™ll get you into trouble.â€

Just then Sambo came up. He seemed to have a special spite against this woman; and, flourishing his whip, said, in brutal, guttural tones, â€œWhat dis yer, Luce,â€”foolinâ€™ aâ€™â€ and, with the word, kicking the woman with his heavy cowhide shoe, he struck Tom across the face with his whip.
Tom silently resumed his task; but the woman, before at the last point of exhaustion, fainted.

â€œIâ€™ll bring her to!â€ said the driver, with a brutal grin. â€œIâ€™ll give her something better than camphire!â€ and, taking a pin from his coat-sleeve, he buried it to the head in her flesh. The woman groaned, and half rose. â€œGet up, you beast, and work, will yer, or Iâ€™ll show yer a trick more!â€
The woman seemed stimulated, for a few moments, to an unnatural strength, and worked with desperate eagerness.
â€œSee that you keep to dat ar,â€ said the man, â€œor yerâ€™ll wish yerâ€™s dead tonight, I reckin!â€
â€œThat I do now!â€ Tom heard her say; and again he heard her say, â€œO, Lord, how long! O, Lord, why donâ€™t you help us?â€
At the risk of all that he might suffer, Tom came forward again, and put all the cotton in his sack into the womanâ€™s.
â€œO, you mustnâ€™t! you donno what theyâ€™ll do to ye!â€ said the woman.
â€œI can bar it!â€ said Tom, â€œbetter â€™n you;â€ and he was at his place again. It passed in a moment.

Suddenly, the stranger woman whom we have described, and who had, in the course of her work, come near enough to hear Tomâ€™s last words, raised her heavy black eyes, and fixed them, for a second, on him; then, taking a quantity of cotton from her basket, she placed it in his.

â€œYou know nothing about this place,â€ she said, â€œor you wouldnâ€™t have done that. When youâ€™ve been here a month, youâ€™ll be done helping anybody; youâ€™ll find it hard enough to take care of your own skin!â€
â€œThe Lord forbid, Missis!â€ said Tom, using instinctively to his field companion the respectful form proper to the high bred with whom he had lived.
â€œThe Lord never visits these parts,â€ said the woman, bitterly, as she went nimbly forward with her work; and again the scornful smile curled her lips.
But the action of the woman had been seen by the driver, across the field; and, flourishing his whip, he came up to her.
â€œWhat! what!â€ he said to the woman, with an air of triumph, â€œYou a foolinâ€™? Go along! yer under me now,â€”mind yourself, or yerâ€™ll cotch it!â€

A glance like sheet-lightning suddenly flashed from those black eyes; and, facing about, with quivering lip and dilated nostrils, she drew herself up, and fixed a glance, blazing with rage and scorn, on the driver.
â€œDog!â€ she said, â€œtouch me, if you dare! Iâ€™ve power enough, yet, to have you torn by the dogs, burnt alive, cut to inches! Iâ€™ve only to say the word!â€
â€œWhat de devil you here for, den?â€ said the man, evidently cowed, and sullenly retreating a step or two. â€œDidnâ€™t mean no harm, Misse Cassy!â€
â€œKeep your distance, then!â€ said the woman. And, in truth, the man seemed greatly inclined to attend to something at the other end of the field, and started off in quick time.

The woman suddenly turned to her work, and labored with a despatch that was perfectly astonishing to Tom. She seemed to work by magic. Before the day was through, her basket was filled, crowded down, and piled, and she had several times put largely into Tomâ€™s. Long after dusk, the whole weary train, with their baskets on their heads, defiled up to the building appropriated to the storing and weighing the cotton. Legree was there, busily conversing with the two drivers.

â€œDat ar Tomâ€™s gwine to make a powerful deal oâ€™ trouble; kept a puttinâ€™ into Lucyâ€™s basket.â€”One oâ€™ these yer dat will get all der niggers to feelinâ€™ â€™bused, if Masir donâ€™t watch him!â€ said Sambo.
â€œHey-dey! The black cuss!â€ said Legree. â€œHeâ€™ll have to get a breakinâ€™ in, wonâ€™t he, boys?â€
Both negroes grinned a horrid grin, at this intimation.
â€œAy, ay! Let Masâ€™r Legree alone, for breakinâ€™ in! De debil heself couldnâ€™t beat Masâ€™r at dat!â€ said Quimbo.
â€œWal, boys, the best way is to give him the flogging to do, till he gets over his notions. Break him in!â€
â€œLord, Masâ€™râ€™ll have hard work to get dat out oâ€™ him!â€
â€œItâ€™ll have to come out of him, though!â€ said Legree, as he rolled his tobacco in his mouth.
â€œNow, darâ€™s Lucy,â€”de aggravatinest, ugliest wench on de place!â€ pursued Sambo.
â€œTake care, Sam; I shall begin to think whatâ€™s the reason for your spite agin Lucy.â€
â€œWell, Masâ€™r knows she sot herself up agin Masâ€™r, and wouldnâ€™t have me, when he telled her to.â€

â€œIâ€™d a flogged her into â€™t,â€ said Legree, spitting, â€œonly thereâ€™s such a press oâ€™ work, it donâ€™t seem wuth a while to upset her jist now. Sheâ€™s slender; but these yer slender gals will bear half killinâ€™ to get their own way!â€
â€œWal, Lucy was real aggravatinâ€™ and lazy, sulkinâ€™ round; wouldnâ€™t do nothin,â€”and Tom he stuck up for her.â€
â€œHe did, eh! Wal, then, Tom shall have the pleasure of flogging her. Itâ€™ll be a good practice for him, and he wonâ€™t put it on to the gal like you devils, neither.â€
â€œHo, ho! haw! haw! haw!â€ laughed both the sooty wretches; and the diabolical sounds seemed, in truth, a not unapt expression of the fiendish character which Legree gave them.
â€œWal, but, Masâ€™r, Tom and Misse Cassy, and dey among â€™em, filled Lucyâ€™s basket. I ruther guess der weight â€™s in it, Masâ€™r!â€
â€œI do the weighing!â€ said Legree, emphatically.
Both the drivers again laughed their diabolical laugh.
â€œSo!â€ he added, â€œMisse Cassy did her dayâ€™s work.â€
â€œShe picks like de debil and all his angels!â€
â€œSheâ€™s got â€™em all in her, I believe!â€ said Legree; and, growling a brutal oath, he proceeded to the weighing-room.
Slowly the weary, dispirited creatures, wound their way into the room, and, with crouching reluctance, presented their baskets to be weighed.
Legree noted on a slate, on the side of which was pasted a list of names, the amount.
Tomâ€™s basket was weighed and approved; and he looked, with an anxious glance, for the success of the woman he had befriended.
Tottering with weakness, she came forward, and delivered her basket. It was of full weight, as Legree well perceived; but, affecting anger, he said,
â€œWhat, you lazy beast! short again! stand aside, youâ€™ll catch it, pretty soon!â€
The woman gave a groan of utter despair, and sat down on a board.

The person who had been called Misse Cassy now came forward, and, with a haughty, negligent air, delivered her basket. As she delivered it, Legree looked in her eyes with a sneering yet inquiring glance.

She fixed her black eyes steadily on him, her lips moved slightly, and she said something in French. What it was, no one knew; but Legreeâ€™s face became perfectly demoniacal in its expression, as she spoke; he half raised his hand, as if to strike,â€”a gesture which she regarded with fierce disdain, as she turned and walked away.

â€œAnd now,â€ said Legree, â€œcome here, you Tom. You see, I telled ye I didnâ€™t buy ye jest for the common work; I mean to promote ye, and make a driver of ye; and tonight ye may jest as well begin to get yer hand in. Now, ye jest take this yer gal and flog her; yeâ€™ve seen enough onâ€™t to know how.â€
â€œI beg Masâ€™râ€™s pardon,â€ said Tom; â€œhopes Masâ€™r wonâ€™t set me at that. Itâ€™s what I anâ€™t used to,â€”never did,â€”and canâ€™t do, no way possible.â€

â€œYeâ€™ll larn a pretty smart chance of things ye never did know, before Iâ€™ve done with ye!â€ said Legree, taking up a cowhide, and striking Tom a heavy blow cross the cheek, and following up the infliction by a shower of blows.
â€œThere!â€ he said, as he stopped to rest; â€œnow, will ye tell me ye canâ€™t do it?â€

â€œYes, Masâ€™r,â€ said Tom, putting up his hand, to wipe the blood, that trickled down his face. â€œIâ€™m willinâ€™ to work, night and day, and work while thereâ€™s life and breath in me; but this yer thing I canâ€™t feel it right to do;â€”and, Masâ€™r, I never shall do it,â€”never!â€

Tom had a remarkably smooth, soft voice, and a habitually respectful manner, that had given Legree an idea that he would be cowardly, and easily subdued. When he spoke these last words, a thrill of amazement went through every one; the poor woman clasped her hands, and said, â€œO Lord!â€ and every one involuntarily looked at each other and drew in their breath, as if to prepare for the storm that was about to burst.

Legree looked stupefied and confounded; but at last burst forth,â€”â€œWhat! ye blasted black beast! tell me ye donâ€™t think it right to do what I tell ye! What have any of you cussed cattle to do with thinking whatâ€™s right? Iâ€™ll put a stop to it! Why, what do ye think ye are? May be ye think yeâ€™r a gentleman master, Tom, to be a telling your master whatâ€™s right, and what ainâ€™t! So you pretend itâ€™s wrong to flog the gal!â€

â€œI think so, Masâ€™r,â€ said Tom; â€œthe poor critturâ€™s sick and feeble; â€™t would be downright cruel, and itâ€™s what I never will do, nor begin to. Masâ€™r, if you mean to kill me, kill me; but, as to my raising my hand agin any one here, I never shall,â€”Iâ€™ll die first!â€

Tom spoke in a mild voice, but with a decision that could not be mistaken. Legree shook with anger; his greenish eyes glared fiercely, and his very whiskers seemed to curl with passion; but, like some ferocious beast, that plays with its victim before he devours it, he kept back his strong impulse to proceed to immediate violence, and broke out into bitter raillery.

â€œWell, hereâ€™s a pious dog, at last, let down among us sinners!â€”a saint, a gentleman, and no less, to talk to us sinners about our sins! Powerful holy critter, he must be! Here, you rascal, you make believe to be so pious,â€”didnâ€™t you never hear, out of yer Bible, â€™Servants, obey yer mastersâ€™? Anâ€™t I yer master? Didnâ€™t I pay down twelve hundred dollars, cash, for all there is inside yer old cussed black shell? Anâ€™t yer mine, now, body and soul?â€ he said, giving Tom a violent kick with his heavy boot; â€œtell me!â€

In the very depth of physical suffering, bowed by brutal oppression, this question shot a gleam of joy and triumph through Tomâ€™s soul. He suddenly stretched himself up, and, looking earnestly to heaven, while the tears and blood that flowed down his face mingled, he exclaimed,

â€œNo! no! no! my soul anâ€™t yours, Masâ€™r! You havenâ€™t bought it,â€”ye canâ€™t buy it! Itâ€™s been bought and paid for, by one that is able to keep it;â€”no matter, no matter, you canâ€™t harm me!â€
â€œI canâ€™t!â€ said Legree, with a sneer; â€œweâ€™ll see,â€”weâ€™ll see! Here, Sambo, Quimbo, give this dog such a breakinâ€™ in as he wonâ€™t get over, this month!â€

The two gigantic negroes that now laid hold of Tom, with fiendish exultation in their faces, might have formed no unapt personification of powers of darkness. The poor woman screamed with apprehension, and all rose, as by a general impulse, while they dragged him unresisting from the place.

div.head:
CHAPTER XXXIV
The Quadroonâ€™s Story
div.p: And behold the tears of such as are oppressed; and on the side of their oppressors there was power. Wherefore I praised the dead that are already dead more than the living that are yet alive.â€”ECCL. 4:1.

It was late at night, and Tom lay groaning and bleeding alone, in an old forsaken room of the gin-house, among pieces of broken machinery, piles of damaged cotton, and other rubbish which had there accumulated.

The night was damp and close, and the thick air swarmed with myriads of mosquitos, which increased the restless torture of his wounds; whilst a burning thirstâ€”a torture beyond all othersâ€”filled up the uttermost measure of physical anguish.
â€œO, good Lord! Do look down,â€”give me the victory!â€”give me the victory over all!â€ prayed poor Tom, in his anguish.
A footstep entered the room, behind him, and the light of a lantern flashed on his eyes.
â€œWhoâ€™s there? O, for the Lordâ€™s massy, please give me some water!â€
The woman Cassyâ€”for it was she,â€”set down her lantern, and, pouring water from a bottle, raised his head, and gave him drink. Another and another cup were drained, with feverish eagerness.
CASSY MINISTERING TO UNCLE TOM AFTER HIS WHIPPING.
â€œDrink all ye want,â€ she said; â€œI knew how it would be. It isnâ€™t the first time Iâ€™ve been out in the night, carrying water to such as you.â€
â€œThank you, Missis,â€ said Tom, when he had done drinking.

â€œDonâ€™t call me Missis! Iâ€™m a miserable slave, like yourself,â€”a lower one than you can ever be!â€ said she, bitterly; â€œbut now,â€ said she, going to the door, and dragging in a small pallaise, over which she had spread linen cloths wet with cold water, â€œtry, my poor fellow, to roll yourself on to this.â€
Stiff with wounds and bruises, Tom was a long time in accomplishing this movement; but, when done, he felt a sensible relief from the cooling application to his wounds.

The woman, whom long practice with the victims of brutality had made familiar with many healing arts, went on to make many applications to Tomâ€™s wounds, by means of which he was soon somewhat relieved.
â€œNow,â€ said the woman, when she had raised his head on a roll of damaged cotton, which served for a pillow, â€œthereâ€™s the best I can do for you.â€

Tom thanked her; and the woman, sitting down on the floor, drew up her knees, and embracing them with her arms, looked fixedly before her, with a bitter and painful expression of countenance. Her bonnet fell back, and long wavy streams of black hair fell around her singular and melancholy-face.

â€œItâ€™s no use, my poor fellow!â€ she broke out, at last, â€œitâ€™s of no use, this youâ€™ve been trying to do. You were a brave fellow,â€”you had the right on your side; but itâ€™s all in vain, and out of the question, for you to struggle. You are in the devilâ€™s hands;â€”he is the strongest, and you must give up!â€

Give up! and, had not human weakness and physical agony whispered that, before? Tom started; for the bitter woman, with her wild eyes and melancholy voice, seemed to him an embodiment of the temptation with which he had been wrestling.
â€œO Lord! O Lord!â€ he groaned, â€œhow can I give up?â€

â€œThereâ€™s no use calling on the Lord,â€”he never hears,â€ said the woman, steadily; â€œthere isnâ€™t any God, I believe; or, if there is, heâ€™s taken sides against us. All goes against us, heaven and earth. Everything is pushing us into hell. Why shouldnâ€™t we go?â€
Tom closed his eyes, and shuddered at the dark, atheistic words.

â€œYou see,â€ said the woman, â€œyou donâ€™t know anything about itâ€”I do. Iâ€™ve been on this place five years, body and soul, under this manâ€™s foot; and I hate him as I do the devil! Here you are, on a lone plantation, ten miles from any other, in the swamps; not a white person here, who could testify, if you were burned alive,â€”if you were scalded, cut into inch-pieces, set up for the dogs to tear, or hung up and whipped to death. Thereâ€™s no law here, of God or man, that can do you, or any one of us, the least good; and, this man! thereâ€™s no earthly thing that heâ€™s too good to do. I could make any oneâ€™s hair rise, and their teeth chatter, if I should only tell what Iâ€™ve seen and been knowing to, here,â€”and itâ€™s no use resisting! Did I want to live with him? Wasnâ€™t I a woman delicately bred; and he,â€”God in heaven! what was he, and is he? And yet, Iâ€™ve lived with him, these five years, and cursed every moment of my life,â€”night and day! And now, heâ€™s got a new one,â€”a young thing, only fifteen, and she brought up, she says, piously. Her good mistress taught her to read the Bible; and sheâ€™s brought her Bible hereâ€”to hell with her!â€â€”and the woman laughed a wild and doleful laugh, that rung, with a strange, supernatural sound, through the old ruined shed.
Tom folded his hands; all was darkness and horror.
â€œO Jesus! Lord Jesus! have you quite forgot us poor critturs?â€ burst forth, at last;â€”â€œhelp, Lord, I perish!â€
The woman sternly continued:

â€œAnd what are these miserable low dogs you work with, that you should suffer on their account? Every one of them would turn against you, the first time they got a chance. They are all of â€™em as low and cruel to each other as they can be; thereâ€™s no use in your suffering to keep from hurting them.â€

â€œPoor critturs!â€ said Tom,â€”â€œwhat made â€™em cruel?â€”and, if I give out, I shall get used to â€™t, and grow, little by little, just like â€™em! No, no, Missis! Iâ€™ve lost everything,â€”wife, and children, and home, and a kind Masâ€™r,â€”and he would have set me free, if heâ€™d only lived a week longer; Iâ€™ve lost everything in this world, and itâ€™s clean gone, forever,â€”and now I canâ€™t lose Heaven, too; no, I canâ€™t get to be wicked, besides all!â€
â€œBut it canâ€™t be that the Lord will lay sin to our account,â€ said the woman; â€œhe wonâ€™t charge it to us, when weâ€™re forced to it; heâ€™ll charge it to them that drove us to it.â€

â€œYes,â€ said Tom; â€œbut that wonâ€™t keep us from growing wicked. If I get to be as hard-hearted as that arâ€™ Sambo, and as wicked, it wonâ€™t make much odds to me how I come so; itâ€™s the beinâ€™ so,â€”that arâ€™s what Iâ€™m a dreadinâ€™.â€
The woman fixed a wild and startled look on Tom, as if a new thought had struck her; and then, heavily groaning, said,
â€œO God aâ€™ mercy! you speak the truth! Oâ€”Oâ€”O!â€â€”and, with groans, she fell on the floor, like one crushed and writhing under the extremity of mental anguish.
There was a silence, a while, in which the breathing of both parties could be heard, when Tom faintly said, â€œO, please, Missis!â€
The woman suddenly rose up, with her face composed to its usual stern, melancholy expression.
â€œPlease, Missis, I saw â€™em throw my coat in that arâ€™ corner, and in my coat-pocket is my Bible;â€”if Missis would please get it for me.â€
Cassy went and got it. Tom opened, at once, to a heavily marked passage, much worn, of the last scenes in the life of Him by whose stripes we are healed.
â€œIf Missis would only be so good as read that arâ€™,â€”itâ€™s better than water.â€

Cassy took the book, with a dry, proud air, and looked over the passage. She then read aloud, in a soft voice, and with a beauty of intonation that was peculiar, that touching account of anguish and of glory. Often, as she read, her voice faltered, and sometimes failed her altogether, when she would stop, with an air of frigid composure, till she had mastered herself. When she came to the touching words, â€œFather forgive them, for they know not what they do,â€ she threw down the book, and, burying her face in the heavy masses of her hair, she sobbed aloud, with a convulsive violence.
Tom was weeping, also, and occasionally uttering a smothered ejaculation.
â€œIf we only could keep up to that arâ€™!â€ said Tom;â€”â€œit seemed to come so natural to him, and we have to fight so hard for â€™t! O Lord, help us! O blessed Lord Jesus, do help us!â€

â€œMissis,â€ said Tom, after a while, â€œI can see that, some how, youâ€™re quite â€™bove me in everything; but thereâ€™s one thing Missis might learn even from poor Tom. Ye said the Lord took sides against us, because he lets us be â€™bused and knocked round; but ye see what come on his own Son,â€”the blessed Lord of Glory,â€”wanâ€™t he allays poor? and have we, any on us, yet come so low as he come? The Lord hanâ€™t forgot us,â€”Iâ€™m sartinâ€™ oâ€™ that arâ€™. If we suffer with him, we shall also reign, Scripture says; but, if we deny Him, he also will deny us. Didnâ€™t they all suffer?â€”the Lord and all his? It tells how they was stoned and sawn asunder, and wandered about in sheep-skins and goat-skins, and was destitute, afflicted, tormented. Sufferinâ€™ anâ€™t no reason to make us think the Lordâ€™s turned agin us; but jest the contrary, if only we hold on to him, and doesnâ€™t give up to sin.â€
â€œBut why does he put us where we canâ€™t help but sin?â€ said the woman.
â€œI think we can help it,â€ said Tom.

â€œYouâ€™ll see,â€ said Cassy; â€œwhatâ€™ll you do? Tomorrow theyâ€™ll be at you again. I know â€™em; Iâ€™ve seen all their doings; I canâ€™t bear to think of all theyâ€™ll bring you to;â€”and theyâ€™ll make you give out, at last!â€
â€œLord Jesus!â€ said Tom, â€œyou will take care of my soul? O Lord, do!â€”donâ€™t let me give out!â€

â€œO dear!â€ said Cassy; â€œIâ€™ve heard all this crying and praying before; and yet, theyâ€™ve been broken down, and brought under. Thereâ€™s Emmeline, sheâ€™s trying to hold on, and youâ€™re trying,â€”but what use? You must give up, or be killed by inches.â€

â€œWell, then, I will die!â€ said Tom. â€œSpin it out as long as they can, they canâ€™t help my dying, some time!â€”and, after that, they canâ€™t do no more. Iâ€™m clar, Iâ€™m set! I know the Lordâ€™ll help me, and bring me through.â€
The woman did not answer; she sat with her black eyes intently fixed on the floor.

â€œMay be itâ€™s the way,â€ she murmured to herself; â€œbut those that have given up, thereâ€™s no hope for them!â€”none! We live in filth, and grow loathsome, till we loathe ourselves! And we long to die, and we donâ€™t dare to kill ourselves!â€”No hope! no hope! no hope?â€”this girl now,â€”just as old as I was!

â€œYou see me now,â€ she said, speaking to Tom very rapidly; â€œsee what I am! Well, I was brought up in luxury; the first I remember is, playing about, when I was a child, in splendid parlors,â€”when I was kept dressed up like a doll, and company and visitors used to praise me. There was a garden opening from the saloon windows; and there I used to play hide-and-go-seek, under the orange-trees, with my brothers and sisters. I went to a convent, and there I learned music, French and embroidery, and what not; and when I was fourteen, I came out to my fatherâ€™s funeral. He died very suddenly, and when the property came to be settled, they found that there was scarcely enough to cover the debts; and when the creditors took an inventory of the property, I was set down in it. My mother was a slave woman, and my father had always meant to set me free; but he had not done it, and so I was set down in the list. Iâ€™d always known who I was, but never thought much about it. Nobody ever expects that a strong, healthy man is going to die. My father was a well man only four hours before he died;â€”it was one of the first cholera cases in New Orleans. The day after the funeral, my fatherâ€™s wife took her children, and went up to her fatherâ€™s plantation. I thought they treated me strangely, but didnâ€™t know. There was a young lawyer who they left to settle the business; and he came every day, and was about the house, and spoke very politely to me. He brought with him, one day, a young man, whom I thought the handsomest I had ever seen. I shall never forget that evening. I walked with him in the garden. I was lonesome and full of sorrow, and he was so kind and gentle to me; and he told me that he had seen me before I went to the convent, and that he had loved me a great while, and that he would be my friend and protector;â€”in short, though he didnâ€™t tell me, he had paid two thousand dollars for me, and I was his property,â€”I became his willingly, for I loved him. Loved!â€ said the woman, stopping. â€œO, how I did love that man! How I love him now,â€”and always shall, while I breathe! He was so beautiful, so high, so noble! He put me into a beautiful house, with servants, horses, and carriages, and furniture, and dresses. Everything that money could buy, he gave me; but I didnâ€™t set any value on all that,â€”I only cared for him. I loved him better than my God and my own soul, and, if I tried, I couldnâ€™t do any other way from what he wanted me to.

â€œI wanted only one thingâ€”I did want him to marry me. I thought, if he loved me as he said he did, and if I was what he seemed to think I was, he would be willing to marry me and set me free. But he convinced me that it would be impossible; and he told me that, if we were only faithful to each other, it was marriage before God. If that is true, wasnâ€™t I that manâ€™s wife? Wasnâ€™t I faithful? For seven years, didnâ€™t I study every look and motion, and only live and breathe to please him? He had the yellow fever, and for twenty days and nights I watched with him. I alone,â€”and gave him all his medicine, and did everything for him; and then he called me his good angel, and said Iâ€™d saved his life. We had two beautiful children. The first was a boy, and we called him Henry. He was the image of his father,â€”he had such beautiful eyes, such a forehead, and his hair hung all in curls around it; and he had all his fatherâ€™s spirit, and his talent, too. Little Elise, he said, looked like me. He used to tell me that I was the most beautiful woman in Louisiana, he was so proud of me and the children. He used to love to have me dress them up, and take them and me about in an open carriage, and hear the remarks that people would make on us; and he used to fill my ears constantly with the fine things that were said in praise of me and the children. O, those were happy days! I thought I was as happy as any one could be; but then there came evil times. He had a cousin come to New Orleans, who was his particular friend,â€”he thought all the world of him;â€”but, from the first time I saw him, I couldnâ€™t tell why, I dreaded him; for I felt sure he was going to bring misery on us. He got Henry to going out with him, and often he would not come home nights till two or three oâ€™clock. I did not dare say a word; for Henry was so high spirited, I was afraid to. He got him to the gaming-houses; and he was one of the sort that, when he once got a going there, there was no holding back. And then he introduced him to another lady, and I saw soon that his heart was gone from me. He never told me, but I saw it,â€”I knew it, day after day,â€”I felt my heart breaking, but I could not say a word! At this, the wretch offered to buy me and the children of Henry, to clear off his gambling debts, which stood in the way of his marrying as he wished;â€”and he sold us. He told me, one day, that he had business in the country, and should be gone two or three weeks. He spoke kinder than usual, and said he should come back; but it didnâ€™t deceive me. I knew that the time had come; I was just like one turned into stone; I couldnâ€™t speak, nor shed a tear. He kissed me and kissed the children, a good many times, and went out. I saw him get on his horse, and I watched him till he was quite out of sight; and then I fell down, and fainted.

â€œThen he came, the cursed wretch! he came to take possession. He told me that he had bought me and my children; and showed me the papers. I cursed him before God, and told him Iâ€™d die sooner than live with him.â€

â€œâ€˜Just as you please,â€™ said he; â€˜but, if you donâ€™t behave reasonably, Iâ€™ll sell both the children, where you shall never see them again.â€™ He told me that he always had meant to have me, from the first time he saw me; and that he had drawn Henry on, and got him in debt, on purpose to make him willing to sell me. That he got him in love with another woman; and that I might know, after all that, that he should not give up for a few airs and tears, and things of that sort.

â€œI gave up, for my hands were tied. He had my children;â€”whenever I resisted his will anywhere, he would talk about selling them, and he made me as submissive as he desired. O, what a life it was! to live with my heart breaking, every day,â€”to keep on, on, on, loving, when it was only misery; and to be bound, body and soul, to one I hated. I used to love to read to Henry, to play to him, to waltz with him, and sing to him; but everything I did for this one was a perfect drag,â€”yet I was afraid to refuse anything. He was very imperious, and harsh to the children. Elise was a timid little thing; but Henry was bold and high-spirited, like his father, and he had never been brought under, in the least, by any one. He was always finding fault, and quarrelling with him; and I used to live in daily fear and dread. I tried to make the child respectful;â€”I tried to keep them apart, for I held on to those children like death; but it did no good. He sold both those children. He took me to ride, one day, and when I came home, they were nowhere to be found! He told me he had sold them; he showed me the money, the price of their blood. Then it seemed as if all good forsook me. I raved and cursed,â€”cursed God and man; and, for a while, I believe, he really was afraid of me. But he didnâ€™t give up so. He told me that my children were sold, but whether I ever saw their faces again, depended on him; and that, if I wasnâ€™t quiet, they should smart for it. Well, you can do anything with a woman, when youâ€™ve got her children. He made me submit; he made me be peaceable; he flattered me with hopes that, perhaps, he would buy them back; and so things went on, a week or two. One day, I was out walking, and passed by the calaboose; I saw a crowd about the gate, and heard a childâ€™s voice,â€”and suddenly my Henry broke away from two or three men who were holding him, and ran, screaming, and caught my dress. They came up to him, swearing dreadfully; and one man, whose face I shall never forget, told him that he wouldnâ€™t get away so; that he was going with him into the calaboose, and heâ€™d get a lesson there heâ€™d never forget. I tried to beg and plead,â€”they only laughed; the poor boy screamed and looked into my face, and held on to me, until, in tearing him off, they tore the skirt of my dress half away; and they carried him in, screaming â€™Mother! mother! mother!â€™ There was one man stood there seemed to pity me. I offered him all the money I had, if heâ€™d only interfere. He shook his head, and said that the boy had been impudent and disobedient, ever since he bought him; that he was going to break him in, once for all. I turned and ran; and every step of the way, I thought that I heard him scream. I got into the house; ran, all out of breath, to the parlor, where I found Butler. I told him, and begged him to go and interfere. He only laughed, and told me the boy had got his deserts. Heâ€™d got to be broken in,â€”the sooner the better; â€™what did I expect?â€™ he asked.

â€œIt seemed to me something in my head snapped, at that moment. I felt dizzy and furious. I remember seeing a great sharp bowie-knife on the table; I remember something about catching it, and flying upon him; and then all grew dark, and I didnâ€™t know any more,â€”not for days and days.

â€œWhen I came to myself, I was in a nice room,â€”but not mine. An old black woman tended me; and a doctor came to see me, and there was a great deal of care taken of me. After a while, I found that he had gone away, and left me at this house to be sold; and thatâ€™s why they took such pains with me.

â€œI didnâ€™t mean to get well, and hoped I shouldnâ€™t; but, in spite of me the fever went off and I grew healthy, and finally got up. Then, they made me dress up, every day; and gentlemen used to come in and stand and smoke their cigars, and look at me, and ask questions, and debate my price. I was so gloomy and silent, that none of them wanted me. They threatened to whip me, if I wasnâ€™t gayer, and didnâ€™t take some pains to make myself agreeable. At length, one day, came a gentleman named Stuart. He seemed to have some feeling for me; he saw that something dreadful was on my heart, and he came to see me alone, a great many times, and finally persuaded me to tell him. He bought me, at last, and promised to do all he could to find and buy back my children. He went to the hotel where my Henry was; they told him he had been sold to a planter up on Pearl River; that was the last that I ever heard. Then he found where my daughter was; an old woman was keeping her. He offered an immense sum for her, but they would not sell her. Butler found out that it was for me he wanted her; and he sent me word that I should never have her. Captain Stuart was very kind to me; he had a splendid plantation, and took me to it. In the course of a year, I had a son born. O, that child!â€”how I loved it! How just like my poor Henry the little thing looked! But I had made up my mind,â€”yes, I had. I would never again let a child live to grow up! I took the little fellow in my arms, when he was two weeks old, and kissed him, and cried over him; and then I gave him laudanum, and held him close to my bosom, while he slept to death. How I mourned and cried over it! and who ever dreamed that it was anything but a mistake, that had made me give it the laudanum? but itâ€™s one of the few things that Iâ€™m glad of, now. I am not sorry, to this day; he, at least, is out of pain. What better than death could I give him, poor child! After a while, the cholera came, and Captain Stuart died; everybody died that wanted to live,â€”and I,â€”I, though I went down to deathâ€™s door,â€”I lived! Then I was sold, and passed from hand to hand, till I grew faded and wrinkled, and I had a fever; and then this wretch bought me, and brought me here,â€”and here I am!â€

The woman stopped. She had hurried on through her story, with a wild, passionate utterance; sometimes seeming to address it to Tom, and sometimes speaking as in a soliloquy. So vehement and overpowering was the force with which she spoke, that, for a season, Tom was beguiled even from the pain of his wounds, and, raising himself on one elbow, watched her as she paced restlessly up and down, her long black hair swaying heavily about her, as she moved.

â€œYou tell me,â€ she said, after a pause, â€œthat there is a God,â€”a God that looks down and sees all these things. May be itâ€™s so. The sisters in the convent used to tell me of a day of judgment, when everything is coming to light;â€”wonâ€™t there be vengeance, then!

â€œThey think itâ€™s nothing, what we suffer,â€”nothing, what our children suffer! Itâ€™s all a small matter; yet Iâ€™ve walked the streets when it seemed as if I had misery enough in my one heart to sink the city. Iâ€™ve wished the houses would fall on me, or the stones sink under me. Yes! and, in the judgment day, I will stand up before God, a witness against those that have ruined me and my children, body and soul!

â€œWhen I was a girl, I thought I was religious; I used to love God and prayer. Now, Iâ€™m a lost soul, pursued by devils that torment me day and night; they keep pushing me on and onâ€”and Iâ€™ll do it, too, some of these days!â€ she said, clenching her hand, while an insane light glanced in her heavy black eyes. â€œIâ€™ll send him where he belongs,â€”a short way, too,â€”one of these nights, if they burn me alive for it!â€ A wild, long laugh rang through the deserted room, and ended in a hysteric sob; she threw herself on the floor, in convulsive sobbing and struggles.
In a few moments, the frenzy fit seemed to pass off; she rose slowly, and seemed to collect herself.
â€œCan I do anything more for you, my poor fellow?â€ she said, approaching where Tom lay; â€œshall I give you some more water?â€
There was a graceful and compassionate sweetness in her voice and manner, as she said this, that formed a strange contrast with the former wildness.
Tom drank the water, and looked earnestly and pitifully into her face.
â€œO, Missis, I wish youâ€™d go to him that can give you living waters!â€
â€œGo to him! Where is he? Who is he?â€ said Cassy.
â€œHim that you read of to me,â€”the Lord.â€

â€œI used to see the picture of him, over the altar, when I was a girl,â€ said Cassy, her dark eyes fixing themselves in an expression of mournful reverie; â€œbut, he isnâ€™t here! thereâ€™s nothing here, but sin and long, long, long despair! O!â€ She laid her hand on her breast and drew in her breath, as if to lift a heavy weight.
Tom looked as if he would speak again; but she cut him short, with a decided gesture.
â€œDonâ€™t talk, my poor fellow. Try to sleep, if you can.â€ And, placing water in his reach, and making whatever little arrangements for his comforts she could, Cassy left the shed.

div.head:
CHAPTER XXXV
The Tokens
div.p:
â€œAnd slight, withal, may be the things that bring
Back on the heart the weight which it would fling
Aside forever; it may be a sound,
A flower, the wind, the ocean, which shall wound,â€”
Striking the electric chain wherewith weâ€™re darkly bound.â€
Childe Haroldâ€™s Pilgrimage, Can. 4.

The sitting-room of Legreeâ€™s establishment was a large, long room, with a wide, ample fireplace. It had once been hung with a showy and expensive paper, which now hung mouldering, torn and discolored, from the damp walls. The place had that peculiar sickening, unwholesome smell, compounded of mingled damp, dirt and decay, which one often notices in close old houses. The wall-paper was defaced, in spots, by slops of beer and wine; or garnished with chalk memorandums, and long sums footed up, as if somebody had been practising arithmetic there. In the fireplace stood a brazier full of burning charcoal; for, though the weather was not cold, the evenings always seemed damp and chilly in that great room; and Legree, moreover, wanted a place to light his cigars, and heat his water for punch. The ruddy glare of the charcoal displayed the confused and unpromising aspect of the room,â€”saddles, bridles, several sorts of harness, riding-whips, overcoats, and various articles of clothing, scattered up and down the room in confused variety; and the dogs, of whom we have before spoken, had encamped themselves among them, to suit their own taste and convenience.
Legree was just mixing himself a tumbler of punch, pouring his hot water from a cracked and broken-nosed pitcher, grumbling, as he did so,
â€œPlague on that Sambo, to kick up this yer row between me and the new hands! The fellow wonâ€™t be fit to work for a week, now,â€”right in the press of the season!â€
â€œYes, just like you,â€ said a voice, behind his chair. It was the woman Cassy, who had stolen upon his soliloquy.
â€œHah! you she-devil! youâ€™ve come back, have you?â€
â€œYes, I have,â€ she said, coolly; â€œcome to have my own way, too!â€
â€œYou lie, you jade! Iâ€™ll be up to my word. Either behave yourself, or stay down to the quarters, and fare and work with the rest.â€
â€œIâ€™d rather, ten thousand times,â€ said the woman, â€œlive in the dirtiest hole at the quarters, than be under your hoof!â€

â€œBut you are under my hoof, for all that,â€ said he, turning upon her, with a savage grin; â€œthatâ€™s one comfort. So, sit down here on my knee, my dear, and hear to reason,â€ said he, laying hold on her wrist.

â€œSimon Legree, take care!â€ said the woman, with a sharp flash of her eye, a glance so wild and insane in its light as to be almost appalling. â€œYouâ€™re afraid of me, Simon,â€ she said, deliberately; â€œand youâ€™ve reason to be! But be careful, for Iâ€™ve got the devil in me!â€
The last words she whispered in a hissing tone, close to his ear.

â€œGet out! I believe, to my soul, you have!â€ said Legree, pushing her from him, and looking uncomfortably at her. â€œAfter all, Cassy,â€ he said, â€œwhy canâ€™t you be friends with me, as you used to?â€
â€œUsed to!â€ said she, bitterly. She stopped short,â€”a word of choking feelings, rising in her heart, kept her silent.

Cassy had always kept over Legree the kind of influence that a strong, impassioned woman can ever keep over the most brutal man; but, of late, she had grown more and more irritable and restless, under the hideous yoke of her servitude, and her irritability, at times, broke out into raving insanity; and this liability made her a sort of object of dread to Legree, who had that superstitious horror of insane persons which is common to coarse and uninstructed minds. When Legree brought Emmeline to the house, all the smouldering embers of womanly feeling flashed up in the worn heart of Cassy, and she took part with the girl; and a fierce quarrel ensued between her and Legree. Legree, in a fury, swore she should be put to field service, if she would not be peaceable. Cassy, with proud scorn, declared she would go to the field. And she worked there one day, as we have described, to show how perfectly she scorned the threat.

Legree was secretly uneasy, all day; for Cassy had an influence over him from which he could not free himself. When she presented her basket at the scales, he had hoped for some concession, and addressed her in a sort of half conciliatory, half scornful tone; and she had answered with the bitterest contempt.
The outrageous treatment of poor Tom had roused her still more; and she had followed Legree to the house, with no particular intention, but to upbraid him for his brutality.
â€œI wish, Cassy,â€ said Legree, â€œyouâ€™d behave yourself decently.â€

â€œYou talk about behaving decently! And what have you been doing?â€”you, who havenâ€™t even sense enough to keep from spoiling one of your best hands, right in the most pressing season, just for your devilish temper!â€
â€œI was a fool, itâ€™s a fact, to let any such brangle come up,â€ said Legree; â€œbut, when the boy set up his will, he had to be broke in.â€
â€œI reckon you wonâ€™t break him in!â€

â€œWonâ€™t I?â€ said Legree, rising, passionately. â€œIâ€™d like to know if I wonâ€™t? Heâ€™ll be the first nigger that ever came it round me! Iâ€™ll break every bone in his body, but he shall give up!â€
Just then the door opened, and Sambo entered. He came forward, bowing, and holding out something in a paper.
â€œWhatâ€™s that, you dog?â€ said Legree.
â€œItâ€™s a witch thing, Masâ€™r!â€
â€œA what?â€
â€œSomething that niggers gets from witches. Keeps â€™em from feelinâ€™ when they â€™s flogged. He had it tied round his neck, with a black string.â€
Legree, like most godless and cruel men, was superstitious. He took the paper, and opened it uneasily.
There dropped out of it a silver dollar, and a long, shining curl of fair hair,â€”hair which, like a living thing, twined itself round Legreeâ€™s fingers.

â€œDamnation!â€ he screamed, in sudden passion, stamping on the floor, and pulling furiously at the hair, as if it burned him. â€œWhere did this come from? Take it off!â€”burn it up!â€”burn it up!â€ he screamed, tearing it off, and throwing it into the charcoal. â€œWhat did you bring it to me for?â€
Sambo stood, with his heavy mouth wide open, and aghast with wonder; and Cassy, who was preparing to leave the apartment, stopped, and looked at him in perfect amazement.

â€œDonâ€™t you bring me any more of your devilish things!â€ said he, shaking his fist at Sambo, who retreated hastily towards the door; and, picking up the silver dollar, he sent it smashing through the window-pane, out into the darkness.
Sambo was glad to make his escape. When he was gone, Legree seemed a little ashamed of his fit of alarm. He sat doggedly down in his chair, and began sullenly sipping his tumbler of punch.
Cassy prepared herself for going out, unobserved by him; and slipped away to minister to poor Tom, as we have already related.

And what was the matter with Legree? and what was there in a simple curl of fair hair to appall that brutal man, familiar with every form of cruelty? To answer this, we must carry the reader backward in his history. Hard and reprobate as the godless man seemed now, there had been a time when he had been rocked on the bosom of a mother,â€”cradled with prayers and pious hymns,â€”his now seared brow bedewed with the waters of holy baptism. In early childhood, a fair-haired woman had led him, at the sound of Sabbath bell, to worship and to pray. Far in New England that mother had trained her only son, with long, unwearied love, and patient prayers. Born of a hard-tempered sire, on whom that gentle woman had wasted a world of unvalued love, Legree had followed in the steps of his father. Boisterous, unruly, and tyrannical, he despised all her counsel, and would none of her reproof; and, at an early age, broke from her, to seek his fortunes at sea. He never came home but once, after; and then, his mother, with the yearning of a heart that must love something, and has nothing else to love, clung to him, and sought, with passionate prayers and entreaties, to win him from a life of sin, to his soulâ€™s eternal good.

That was Legreeâ€™s day of grace; then good angels called him; then he was almost persuaded, and mercy held him by the hand. His heart inly relented,â€”there was a conflict,â€”but sin got the victory, and he set all the force of his rough nature against the conviction of his conscience. He drank and swore,â€”was wilder and more brutal than ever. And, one night, when his mother, in the last agony of her despair, knelt at his feet, he spurned her from him,â€”threw her senseless on the floor, and, with brutal curses, fled to his ship. The next Legree heard of his mother was, when, one night, as he was carousing among drunken companions, a letter was put into his hand. He opened it, and a lock of long, curling hair fell from it, and twined about his fingers. The letter told him his mother was dead, and that, dying, she blest and forgave him.

There is a dread, unhallowed necromancy of evil, that turns things sweetest and holiest to phantoms of horror and affright. That pale, loving mother,â€”her dying prayers, her forgiving love,â€”wrought in that demoniac heart of sin only as a damning sentence, bringing with it a fearful looking for of judgment and fiery indignation. Legree burned the hair, and burned the letter; and when he saw them hissing and crackling in the flame, inly shuddered as he thought of everlasting fires. He tried to drink, and revel, and swear away the memory; but often, in the deep night, whose solemn stillness arraigns the bad soul in forced communion with herself, he had seen that pale mother rising by his bedside, and felt the soft twining of that hair around his fingers, till the cold sweat would roll down his face, and he would spring from his bed in horror. Ye who have wondered to hear, in the same evangel, that God is love, and that God is a consuming fire, see ye not how, to the soul resolved in evil, perfect love is the most fearful torture, the seal and sentence of the direst despair?

â€œBlast it!â€ said Legree to himself, as he sipped his liquor; â€œwhere did he get that? If it didnâ€™t look just likeâ€”whoo! I thought Iâ€™d forgot that. Curse me, if I think thereâ€™s any such thing as forgetting anything, any how,â€”hang it! Iâ€™m lonesome! I mean to call Em. She hates meâ€”the monkey! I donâ€™t care,â€”Iâ€™ll make her come!â€

Legree stepped out into a large entry, which went up stairs, by what had formerly been a superb winding staircase; but the passage-way was dirty and dreary, encumbered with boxes and unsightly litter. The stairs, uncarpeted, seemed winding up, in the gloom, to nobody knew where! The pale moonlight streamed through a shattered fanlight over the door; the air was unwholesome and chilly, like that of a vault.

Legree stopped at the foot of the stairs, and heard a voice singing. It seemed strange and ghostlike in that dreary old house, perhaps because of the already tremulous state of his nerves. Hark! what is it?
A wild, pathetic voice, chants a hymn common among the slaves:

â€œO thereâ€™ll be mourning, mourning, mourning,
O thereâ€™ll be mourning, at the judgment-seat of Christ!â€
â€œBlast the girl!â€ said Legree. â€œIâ€™ll choke her.â€”Em! Em!â€ he called, harshly; but only a mocking echo from the walls answered him. The sweet voice still sung on:

â€œParents and children there shall part!
Parents and children there shall part!
Â Â Â Â Shall part to meet no more!â€
And clear and loud swelled through the empty halls the refrain,

â€œO thereâ€™ll be mourning, mourning, mourning,
O thereâ€™ll be mourning, at the judgment-seat of Christ!â€

Legree stopped. He would have been ashamed to tell of it, but large drops of sweat stood on his forehead, his heart beat heavy and thick with fear; he even thought he saw something white rising and glimmering in the gloom before him, and shuddered to think what if the form of his dead mother should suddenly appear to him.

â€œI know one thing,â€ he said to himself, as he stumbled back in the sitting-room, and sat down; â€œIâ€™ll let that fellow alone, after this! What did I want of his cussed paper? I bâ€™lieve I am bewitched, sure enough! Iâ€™ve been shivering and sweating, ever since! Where did he get that hair? It couldnâ€™t have been that! I burnt that up, I know I did! It would be a joke, if hair could rise from the dead!â€

Ah, Legree! that golden tress was charmed; each hair had in it a spell of terror and remorse for thee, and was used by a mightier power to bind thy cruel hands from inflicting uttermost evil on the helpless!
â€œI say,â€ said Legree, stamping and whistling to the dogs, â€œwake up, some of you, and keep me company!â€ but the dogs only opened one eye at him, sleepily, and closed it again.

â€œIâ€™ll have Sambo and Quimbo up here, to sing and dance one of their hell dances, and keep off these horrid notions,â€ said Legree; and, putting on his hat, he went on to the verandah, and blew a horn, with which he commonly summoned his two sable drivers.

Legree was often wont, when in a gracious humor, to get these two worthies into his sitting-room, and, after warming them up with whiskey, amuse himself by setting them to singing, dancing or fighting, as the humor took him.

It was between one and two oâ€™clock at night, as Cassy was returning from her ministrations to poor Tom, that she heard the sound of wild shrieking, whooping, halloing, and singing, from the sitting-room, mingled with the barking of dogs, and other symptoms of general uproar.

She came up on the verandah steps, and looked in. Legree and both the drivers, in a state of furious intoxication, were singing, whooping, upsetting chairs, and making all manner of ludicrous and horrid grimaces at each other.

She rested her small, slender hand on the window-blind, and looked fixedly at them;â€”there was a world of anguish, scorn, and fierce bitterness, in her black eyes, as she did so. â€œWould it be a sin to rid the world of such a wretch?â€ she said to herself.
She turned hurriedly away, and, passing round to a back door, glided up stairs, and tapped at Emmelineâ€™s door.

div.head:
CHAPTER XXXVI
Emmeline and Cassy
div.p: Cassy entered the room, and found Emmeline sitting, pale with fear, in the furthest corner of it. As she came in, the girl started up nervously; but, on seeing who it was, rushed forward, and catching her arm, said, â€œO Cassy, is it you? Iâ€™m so glad youâ€™ve come! I was afraid it wasâ€”. O, you donâ€™t know what a horrid noise there has been, down stairs, all this evening!â€
â€œI ought to know,â€ said Cassy, dryly. â€œIâ€™ve heard it often enough.â€
â€œO Cassy! do tell me,â€”couldnâ€™t we get away from this place? I donâ€™t care where,â€”into the swamp among the snakes,â€”anywhere! Couldnâ€™t we get somewhere away from here?â€
â€œNowhere, but into our graves,â€ said Cassy.
â€œDid you ever try?â€
â€œIâ€™ve seen enough of trying and what comes of it,â€ said Cassy.
â€œIâ€™d be willing to live in the swamps, and gnaw the bark from trees. I anâ€™t afraid of snakes! Iâ€™d rather have one near me than him,â€ said Emmeline, eagerly.
â€œThere have been a good many here of your opinion,â€ said Cassy; â€œbut you couldnâ€™t stay in the swamps,â€”youâ€™d be tracked by the dogs, and brought back, and thenâ€”thenâ€”â€
â€œWhat would he do?â€ said the girl, looking, with breathless interest, into her face.

â€œWhat wouldnâ€™t he do, youâ€™d better ask,â€ said Cassy. â€œHeâ€™s learned his trade well, among the pirates in the West Indies. You wouldnâ€™t sleep much, if I should tell you things Iâ€™ve seen,â€”things that he tells of, sometimes, for good jokes. Iâ€™ve heard screams here that I havenâ€™t been able to get out of my head for weeks and weeks. Thereâ€™s a place way out down by the quarters, where you can see a black, blasted tree, and the ground all covered with black ashes. Ask anyone what was done there, and see if they will dare to tell you.â€
â€œO! what do you mean?â€
â€œI wonâ€™t tell you. I hate to think of it. And I tell you, the Lord only knows what we may see tomorrow, if that poor fellow holds out as heâ€™s begun.â€
â€œHorrid!â€ said Emmeline, every drop of blood receding from her cheeks. â€œO, Cassy, do tell me what I shall do!â€
â€œWhat Iâ€™ve done. Do the best you can,â€”do what you must,â€”and make it up in hating and cursing.â€
â€œHe wanted to make me drink some of his hateful brandy,â€ said Emmeline; â€œand I hate it soâ€”â€
â€œYouâ€™d better drink,â€ said Cassy. â€œI hated it, too; and now I canâ€™t live without it. One must have something;â€”things donâ€™t look so dreadful, when you take that.â€
â€œMother used to tell me never to touch any such thing,â€ said Emmeline.

â€œMother told you!â€ said Cassy, with a thrilling and bitter emphasis on the word mother. â€œWhat use is it for mothers to say anything? You are all to be bought and paid for, and your souls belong to whoever gets you. Thatâ€™s the way it goes. I say, drink brandy; drink all you can, and itâ€™ll make things come easier.â€
â€œO, Cassy! do pity me!â€

â€œPity you!â€”donâ€™t I? Havenâ€™t I a daughter,â€”Lord knows where she is, and whose she is, now,â€”going the way her mother went, before her, I suppose, and that her children must go, after her! Thereâ€™s no end to the curseâ€”forever!â€
â€œI wish Iâ€™d never been born!â€ said Emmeline, wringing her hands.

â€œThatâ€™s an old wish with me,â€ said Cassy. â€œIâ€™ve got used to wishing that. Iâ€™d die, if I dared to,â€ she said, looking out into the darkness, with that still, fixed despair which was the habitual expression of her face when at rest.
â€œIt would be wicked to kill oneâ€™s self,â€ said Emmeline.

â€œI donâ€™t know why,â€”no wickeder than things we live and do, day after day. But the sisters told me things, when I was in the convent, that make me afraid to die. If it would only be the end of us, why, thenâ€”â€
Emmeline turned away, and hid her face in her hands.

While this conversation was passing in the chamber, Legree, overcome with his carouse, had sunk to sleep in the room below. Legree was not an habitual drunkard. His coarse, strong nature craved, and could endure, a continual stimulation, that would have utterly wrecked and crazed a finer one. But a deep, underlying spirit of cautiousness prevented his often yielding to appetite in such measure as to lose control of himself.

This night, however, in his feverish efforts to banish from his mind those fearful elements of woe and remorse which woke within him, he had indulged more than common; so that, when he had discharged his sable attendants, he fell heavily on a settle in the room, and was sound asleep.

O! how dares the bad soul to enter the shadowy world of sleep?â€”that land whose dim outlines lie so fearfully near to the mystic scene of retribution! Legree dreamed. In his heavy and feverish sleep, a veiled form stood beside him, and laid a cold, soft hand upon him. He thought he knew who it was; and shuddered, with creeping horror, though the face was veiled. Then he thought he felt that hair twining round his fingers; and then, that it slid smoothly round his neck, and tightened and tightened, and he could not draw his breath; and then he thought voices whispered to him,â€”whispers that chilled him with horror. Then it seemed to him he was on the edge of a frightful abyss, holding on and struggling in mortal fear, while dark hands stretched up, and were pulling him over; and Cassy came behind him laughing, and pushed him. And then rose up that solemn veiled figure, and drew aside the veil. It was his mother; and she turned away from him, and he fell down, down, down, amid a confused noise of shrieks, and groans, and shouts of demon laughter,â€”and Legree awoke.

Calmly the rosy hue of dawn was stealing into the room. The morning star stood, with its solemn, holy eye of light, looking down on the man of sin, from out the brightening sky. O, with what freshness, what solemnity and beauty, is each new day born; as if to say to insensate man, â€œBehold! thou hast one more chance! Strive for immortal glory!â€ There is no speech nor language where this voice is not heard; but the bold, bad man heard it not. He woke with an oath and a curse. What to him was the gold and purple, the daily miracle of morning! What to him the sanctity of the star which the Son of God has hallowed as his own emblem? Brute-like, he saw without perceiving; and, stumbling forward, poured out a tumbler of brandy, and drank half of it.
â€œIâ€™ve had a hâ€”l of a night!â€ he said to Cassy, who just then entered from an opposite door.
â€œYouâ€™ll get plenty of the same sort, by and by,â€ said she, dryly.
â€œWhat do you mean, you minx?â€
â€œYouâ€™ll find out, one of these days,â€ returned Cassy, in the same tone. â€œNow Simon, Iâ€™ve one piece of advice to give you.â€
â€œThe devil, you have!â€
â€œMy advice is,â€ said Cassy, steadily, as she began adjusting some things about the room, â€œthat you let Tom alone.â€
â€œWhat business is â€™t of yours?â€

â€œWhat? To be sure, I donâ€™t know what it should be. If you want to pay twelve hundred for a fellow, and use him right up in the press of the season, just to serve your own spite, itâ€™s no business of mine, Iâ€™ve done what I could for him.â€
â€œYou have? What business have you meddling in my matters?â€

â€œNone, to be sure. Iâ€™ve saved you some thousands of dollars, at different times, by taking care of your hands,â€”thatâ€™s all the thanks I get. If your crop comes shorter into market than any of theirs, you wonâ€™t lose your bet, I suppose? Tompkins wonâ€™t lord it over you, I suppose,â€”and youâ€™ll pay down your money like a lady, wonâ€™t you? I think I see you doing it!â€

Legree, like many other planters, had but one form of ambition,â€”to have in the heaviest crop of the season,â€”and he had several bets on this very present season pending in the next town. Cassy, therefore, with womanâ€™s tact, touched the only string that could be made to vibrate.
â€œWell, Iâ€™ll let him off at what heâ€™s got,â€ said Legree; â€œbut he shall beg my pardon, and promise better fashions.â€
â€œThat he wonâ€™t do,â€ said Cassy.
â€œWonâ€™t,â€”eh?â€
â€œNo, he wonâ€™t,â€ said Cassy.
â€œIâ€™d like to know why, Mistress,â€ said Legree, in the extreme of scorn.
â€œBecause heâ€™s done right, and he knows it, and wonâ€™t say heâ€™s done wrong.â€
â€œWho a cuss cares what he knows? The nigger shall say what I please, orâ€”â€
â€œOr, youâ€™ll lose your bet on the cotton crop, by keeping him out of the field, just at this very press.â€
â€œBut he will give up,â€”course, he will; donâ€™t I know what niggers is? Heâ€™ll beg like a dog, this morning.â€
â€œHe wonâ€™t, Simon; you donâ€™t know this kind. You may kill him by inches,â€”you wonâ€™t get the first word of confession out of him.â€
â€œWeâ€™ll see,â€”where is he?â€ said Legree, going out.
â€œIn the waste-room of the gin-house,â€ said Cassy.

Legree, though he talked so stoutly to Cassy, still sallied forth from the house with a degree of misgiving which was not common with him. His dreams of the past night, mingled with Cassyâ€™s prudential suggestions, considerably affected his mind. He resolved that nobody should be witness of his encounter with Tom; and determined, if he could not subdue him by bullying, to defer his vengeance, to be wreaked in a more convenient season.

The solemn light of dawnâ€”the angelic glory of the morning-starâ€”had looked in through the rude window of the shed where Tom was lying; and, as if descending on that star-beam, came the solemn words, â€œI am the root and offspring of David, and the bright and morning star.â€ The mysterious warnings and intimations of Cassy, so far from discouraging his soul, in the end had roused it as with a heavenly call. He did not know but that the day of his death was dawning in the sky; and his heart throbbed with solemn throes of joy and desire, as he thought that the wondrous all, of which he had often pondered,â€”the great white throne, with its ever radiant rainbow; the white-robed multitude, with voices as many waters; the crowns, the palms, the harps,â€”might all break upon his vision before that sun should set again. And, therefore, without shuddering or trembling, he heard the voice of his persecutor, as he drew near.

â€œWell, my boy,â€ said Legree, with a contemptuous kick, â€œhow do you find yourself? Didnâ€™t I tell yer I could larn yer a thing or two? How do yer like itâ€”eh? How did yer whaling agree with yer, Tom? Anâ€™t quite so crank as ye was last night. Ye couldnâ€™t treat a poor sinner, now, to a bit of sermon, could ye,â€”eh?â€
Tom answered nothing.
â€œGet up, you beast!â€ said Legree, kicking him again.
This was a difficult matter for one so bruised and faint; and, as Tom made efforts to do so, Legree laughed brutally.
â€œWhat makes ye so spry, this morning, Tom? Cotched cold, may be, last night.â€
Tom by this time had gained his feet, and was confronting his master with a steady, unmoved front.
â€œThe devil, you can!â€ said Legree, looking him over. â€œI believe you havenâ€™t got enough yet. Now, Tom, get right down on yer knees and beg my pardon, for yer shines last night.â€
Tom did not move.
â€œDown, you dog!â€ said Legree, striking him with his riding-whip.
â€œMasâ€™r Legree,â€ said Tom, â€œI canâ€™t do it. I did only what I thought was right. I shall do just so again, if ever the time comes. I never will do a cruel thing, come what may.â€

â€œYes, but ye donâ€™t know what may come, Master Tom. Ye think what youâ€™ve got is something. I tell you â€™tanâ€™t anything,â€”nothing â€™t all. How would ye like to be tied to a tree, and have a slow fire lit up around ye;â€”wouldnâ€™t that be pleasant,â€”eh, Tom?â€

â€œMasâ€™r,â€ said Tom, â€œI know ye can do dreadful things; but,â€â€”he stretched himself upward and clasped his hands,â€”â€œbut, after yeâ€™ve killed the body, there anâ€™t no more ye can do. And O, thereâ€™s all ETERNITY to come, after that!â€

ETERNITY,â€”the word thrilled through the black manâ€™s soul with light and power, as he spoke; it thrilled through the sinnerâ€™s soul, too, like the bite of a scorpion. Legree gnashed on him with his teeth, but rage kept him silent; and Tom, like a man disenthralled, spoke, in a clear and cheerful voice,

â€œMasâ€™r Legree, as ye bought me, Iâ€™ll be a true and faithful servant to ye. Iâ€™ll give ye all the work of my hands, all my time, all my strength; but my soul I wonâ€™t give up to mortal man. I will hold on to the Lord, and put his commands before all,â€”die or live; you may be sure on â€™t. Masâ€™r Legree, I ainâ€™t a grain afeard to die. Iâ€™d as soon die as not. Ye may whip me, starve me, burn me,â€”itâ€™ll only send me sooner where I want to go.â€
â€œIâ€™ll make ye give out, though, â€™fore Iâ€™ve done!â€ said Legree, in a rage.
â€œI shall have help,â€ said Tom; â€œyouâ€™ll never do it.â€
â€œWho the devilâ€™s going to help you?â€ said Legree, scornfully.
â€œThe Lord Almighty,â€ said Tom.
â€œDâ€”n you!â€ said Legree, as with one blow of his fist he felled Tom to the earth.

A cold soft hand fell on Legreeâ€™s at this moment. He turned,â€”it was Cassyâ€™s; but the cold soft touch recalled his dream of the night before, and, flashing through the chambers of his brain, came all the fearful images of the night-watches, with a portion of the horror that accompanied them.
â€œWill you be a fool?â€ said Cassy, in French. â€œLet him go! Let me alone to get him fit to be in the field again. Isnâ€™t it just as I told you?â€

They say the alligator, the rhinoceros, though enclosed in bullet-proof mail, have each a spot where they are vulnerable; and fierce, reckless, unbelieving reprobates, have commonly this point in superstitious dread.
Legree turned away, determined to let the point go for the time.
â€œWell, have it your own way,â€ he said, doggedly, to Cassy.

â€œHark, ye!â€ he said to Tom; â€œI wonâ€™t deal with ye now, because the business is pressing, and I want all my hands; but I never forget. Iâ€™ll score it against ye, and sometime Iâ€™ll have my pay out oâ€™ yer old black hide,â€”mind ye!â€
Legree turned, and went out.
â€œThere you go,â€ said Cassy, looking darkly after him; â€œyour reckoningâ€™s to come, yet!â€”My poor fellow, how are you?â€
â€œThe Lord God hath sent his angel, and shut the lionâ€™s mouth, for this time,â€ said Tom.

â€œFor this time, to be sure,â€ said Cassy; â€œbut now youâ€™ve got his ill will upon you, to follow you day in, day out, hanging like a dog on your throat,â€”sucking your blood, bleeding away your life, drop by drop. I know the man.â€

div.head:
CHAPTER XXXVII
Liberty
div.p: â€œNo matter with what solemnities he may have been devoted upon the altar of slavery, the moment he touches the sacred soil of Britain, the altar and the God sink together in the dust, and he stands redeemed, regenerated, and disenthralled, by the irresistible genius of universal emancipation.â€â€”Curran. [1]
[1] John Philpot Curran (1750-1817), Irish orator and judge who worked for Catholic emancipation.
A while we must leave Tom in the hands of his persecutors, while we turn to pursue the fortunes of George and his wife, whom we left in friendly hands, in a farmhouse on the road-side.
Tom Loker we left groaning and touzling in a most immaculately clean Quaker bed, under the motherly supervision of Aunt Dorcas, who found him to the full as tractable a patient as a sick bison.

Imagine a tall, dignified, spiritual woman, whose clear muslin cap shades waves of silvery hair, parted on a broad, clear forehead, which overarches thoughtful gray eyes. A snowy handkerchief of lisse crape is folded neatly across her bosom; her glossy brown silk dress rustles peacefully, as she glides up and down the chamber.
â€œThe devil!â€ says Tom Loker, giving a great throw to the bedclothes.
â€œI must request thee, Thomas, not to use such language,â€ says Aunt Dorcas, as she quietly rearranged the bed.
â€œWell, I wonâ€™t, granny, if I can help it,â€ says Tom; â€œbut it is enough to make a fellow swear,â€”so cursedly hot!â€
Dorcas removed a comforter from the bed, straightened the clothes again, and tucked them in till Tom looked something like a chrysalis; remarking, as she did so,
â€œI wish, friend, thee would leave off cursing and swearing, and think upon thy ways.â€

â€œWhat the devil,â€ said Tom, â€œshould I think of them for? Last thing ever I want to think ofâ€”hang it all!â€ And Tom flounced over, untucking and disarranging everything, in a manner frightful to behold.
â€œThat fellow and gal are here, I sâ€™pose,â€ said he, sullenly, after a pause.
â€œThey are so,â€ said Dorcas.
â€œTheyâ€™d better be off up to the lake,â€ said Tom; â€œthe quicker the better.â€
â€œProbably they will do so,â€ said Aunt Dorcas, knitting peacefully.

â€œAnd hark ye,â€ said Tom; â€œweâ€™ve got correspondents in Sandusky, that watch the boats for us. I donâ€™t care if I tell, now. I hope they will get away, just to spite Marks,â€”the cursed puppy!â€”dâ€”n him!â€
â€œThomas!â€ said Dorcas.

â€œI tell you, granny, if you bottle a fellow up too tight, I shall split,â€ said Tom. â€œBut about the gal,â€”tell â€™em to dress her up some way, soâ€™s to alter her. Her descriptionâ€™s out in Sandusky.â€
â€œWe will attend to that matter,â€ said Dorcas, with characteristic composure.

As we at this place take leave of Tom Loker, we may as well say, that, having lain three weeks at the Quaker dwelling, sick with a rheumatic fever, which set in, in company with his other afflictions, Tom arose from his bed a somewhat sadder and wiser man; and, in place of slave-catching, betook himself to life in one of the new settlements, where his talents developed themselves more happily in trapping bears, wolves, and other inhabitants of the forest, in which he made himself quite a name in the land. Tom always spoke reverently of the Quakers. â€œNice people,â€ he would say; â€œwanted to convert me, but couldnâ€™t come it, exactly. But, tell ye what, stranger, they do fix up a sick fellow first rate,â€”no mistake. Make jist the tallest kind oâ€™ broth and knicknacks.â€

As Tom had informed them that their party would be looked for in Sandusky, it was thought prudent to divide them. Jim, with his old mother, was forwarded separately; and a night or two after, George and Eliza, with their child, were driven privately into Sandusky, and lodged beneath a hospital roof, preparatory to taking their last passage on the lake.

Their night was now far spent, and the morning star of liberty rose fair before them!â€”electric word! What is it? Is there anything more in it than a nameâ€”a rhetorical flourish? Why, men and women of America, does your heartâ€™s blood thrill at that word, for which your fathers bled, and your braver mothers were willing that their noblest and best should die?

Is there anything in it glorious and dear for a nation, that is not also glorious and dear for a man? What is freedom to a nation, but freedom to the individuals in it? What is freedom to that young man, who sits there, with his arms folded over his broad chest, the tint of African blood in his cheek, its dark fires in his eyes,â€”what is freedom to George Harris? To your fathers, freedom was the right of a nation to be a nation. To him, it is the right of a man to be a man, and not a brute; the right to call the wife of his bosom his wife, and to protect her from lawless violence; the right to protect and educate his child; the right to have a home of his own, a religion of his own, a character of his own, unsubject to the will of another.
